body.head: CHARACTERS OF THE PLAY
body.stage: RICHFORD , son to Pembroke , afterwards Earl
HUBERT DE BURGH , afterwards Earl of Kent
GERSA , an officer under De Burgh
ELEANOR , Countess of Albemarle , wife of Albemarle
Lords and ladies of the court , bishops , barons , priests , citizens , soldiers , & c .

div.head: SCENE 1 . Room in the earl of Pembroke 's castle . Pembroke in bed .

stage.stage: Richford and Albemarle attending .

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: The king has come ?

lg.l: He waits upon your grace
As a good servant ; with demeanor speaks
True sorrow you are brought so low .

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: StoutlyHa ! Low ?

lg.l: Sir , but in body . Pembroke 's mounting mind
Can never be struck down .

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: He 's sad , you say ?

lg.l: In tears , your grace . He weeps more like a son
Than sovereign .
A son ! Where is the son
Would weep for Pembroke ?
Here , my dearest father !
Here are the tears would water thy affliction
Till it be washed from thy endangered body .
Here is the heart would give its younger blood
To make thine leap with health . Without you , sir ,
I am no more than is the gaudy bloom
Of some stout tree the axe has brought to ground .
O , wilt forgive the many pains I 've cost thee ?
First touch my hand and swear by highest God
That you will serve the king .
O , slight condition !
I take this noble hand that ne'er was raised
‘ Gainst country , throne or God , and by that God ,
I vow to serve the king .
For the last time
I 'll trust and pardon you . If you make black
Your soul with violation of this oath ,
I , safe beyond the stars , shall know it not ,
Nor die again to think on ‘ t. Men , weep not
That ye lack sons , but weep when your wives bear them !

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: I 'll vouch for him , your grace .

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: Thanks , Albemarle .

lg.l: Will you , my kindest father , say a word
To bring me to the graces of the king ?

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: Ay , son .

sp.speaker: Rich
sp.p: Now , sir ?

lg.l: Nay , I 'm not dying yet ,
And wish to keep my last words for his ears .
There 's holy magic in the passing tongue
That stamps its truth unrasurable . So
Would I grave Henry 's heart .

sp.speaker: Rich
sp.p: But , sir ——

lg.l: I 'll wait
My hour . Who comes with him ?
The legate , Gualo ,
To-day arrived from Rome .
And I not told ?
Already I am dead . These ears , that kings
Engaged , are now contracted to the worm
Permits no forfeiture . Well , well , his message ?
The cardinal assures us that the pope
Will cast his power with Henry . Though he loves
This praying Louis , well he knows our right .

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: The pope our friend ? I thank thee , Heaven ! England , take up thy heart ! Thou yet mayst hope !Enter bishop of Winchester

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: God save great Pembroke !

lg.l: He alone can do it .
Lord Albemarle , and my new-graced son ,
Will ‘ t please you walk within ?

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: We are your servants .Exeunt Richford and Albemarle , left

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: Now , Winchester ?

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: You sent for me , your grace . I have made haste .

lg.l: Ay , you 'd trot fast enough
To see me die .
Nay , sir , I hope you 've called
Me to your service .
So I have , my lord .
A task unfinished I must leave to you .
Here is the key to yonder cabinet .
Pray you unlock it ... and take out the packet
Your eye 's now on .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: This , sir ?

lg.l: Ay , that is it .
‘ Twas Henry Second , grandsire of this Henry ,
Gave me that packet . Sir , you know the tale
Of princess Adelais who journeyed here
As the betrothed of Richard , Henry 's son .
Alack , she never was his bride . Some say
That Henry loved her ... I know not ... but she
Returned to France , her reason wandering .
“ If she recover , ” said the king to me ,
“ Give her this packet ; should she die , break seal
And learn what you shall do . ” She did not die ,
Nor can I say she lives , so sad her state .
Her age was bare fifteen when she left England ,
Her face a lily and her eyes a flood ;
She now must be midway her fifth decade ,
A time , I 've heard , when subtle changes work
Within the mind . A beauteous soul ! O God ,
Restore her now , or lift her e'en to thee !
... Take you the packet , and the king 's command .
But first your oath . Deceit has sapped my faith
So oft I could believe the devil himself
Wears gown and mitre . Peter des Roches , will you
Be true ?

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: I swear by Heaven .

lg.l: That is done ,
As well as't can be done . Call in my son
And Albemarle .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: My lords !

div.stage: Re-enter Richford and Albemarle

lg.l: Now let us talk
Of England . O , this fleet , this fleet , rigged out
By warlike Constance in monk Louis ’ name !
I see it nearing now , leaping the waves ,
On , on , and none to meet it ! Cowards all .
What do ye here , ye three , loitering about
A sick man 's bed ? A man almost a corpse .
I would not have a servant waste himself
To give me drink while England needs his sword .
My father lord , we have our men abroad
Rousing the country for a stout defence .
To meet the French with our poor ships were madness ;
But let them land we 'll give them such a rap ——
What ? Land your enemy ? O , fools and cowards !
... I 've given my life for England . Now you 'll cast
My heart-dear bargain into Louis ’ hand
As ‘ twere a snood slipped from an easy maid .
Fool man ! to puff his days out jousting Fate ,
Who waits but his bare death to start her mock
Of horrid pleasantries . Then does she make
Dice of the miser 's bones , carousal cups
Of the ascetic 's skull , a hangman 's scoff
Of clerics ’ prayer-fed sons ; and proudest sires ,
Who sentried their blue blood , peer back through dust
To see all Babylon pour to their line .
And now she 'll bid my war-ghost eyes behold
The land held with my life become a field
For foes at holiday !

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: Compose yourself , your grace .

lg.l: Gualo has come , but where is he will set
This power its task , and play it for this isle ?
I can not say that wisdom dies with me ,
But I could wish more proof of sager mind
Than e'er I 've had from this small audience .
Lord Bishop , you are left custodian
Of Henry 's ripening youth .
Nor shall I fail
To be your worthy heir in this high duty ,
For still I shall consult with your great spirit ,
Praying your ghost be mover of my deeds .
I 've spoken to the king . He 'll give you love
For love . But who shall be lord chancellor ?
There 's little choice . And yet there 's one , De Burgh ,
If camp and field could spare him ——
Sir , a man
No older than our sons ?
By your good leave ,
Age is no patent to respect and place
If virtue go not with it . Whitened hairs
Make honor radiant , but vice thereby
Is viler still . Ay , there are some ——
Peace , father ,
And save thy strength for us .
Ah , son , I 've been
A careless holder all my life , and still
With my last hour play spendthrift . Well , here be
Three friends of England — Gualo makes a fourth —
And trusting you I ease my bones to death .

div.stage: Enter attendant with a letter , which he gives to Pembroke

lg.l: De Burgh ! O gallant soul !
Now am I young !
With forty ships he 'll meet the fleet of France !
I live again , for courage is not dead !
Nay — help — ah , I am gone . I 'll hasten on
And plead in Heaven for his victory .

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: Ah ... dead ?

sp.speaker: Rich
sp.p: In truth .

lg.l: I 'll go and tell the king .
My joyful tears he will translate to grief ,
And think I weep a friend 's death , not a foe 's
Whose only act of friendship was to die .

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: How now , my lord ? Does your good purpose hold ?

lg.l: It has the falling sickness , Albemarle ,
And now lies low as earth .
Then set thy foot
Upon it that it rise no more .

sp.speaker: Rich
sp.p: ‘ Tis done .

lg.l: What fools are they who think that dying men
Speak oracles to pivot action on ,
When death 's decay so blurs each fading sense
They know but darkly of the world about ,
And of realities all plain to us
Build visions substanceless to gull our faith .
Grant that they do take note of things unseen ,
‘ Tis with their faces to another world ,
And what they speak is strange and ill advice
To us whose work is still ‘ mong men of earth .
You need not clear your way to me . I 've not
A scruple in my soul would trip a gnat .
Speak out your heart .

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: You are great Pembroke now . But Richford took an oath to serve the king .

sp.speaker: Rich
sp.p: And he — is Louis .

lg.l: Till we find hour fit
To cast his yoke and take a sovereign
Of our election .

sp.speaker: Rich
sp.p: Royal Albemarle !

lg.l: Here stand we then . De Burgh we count as dead .
Le Moine has orders to strike off his head
Soon as he 's taken . Now we get the king
To Dover fort , on pretence to defend it .
There the besieging French will take him prisoner ,
And ship him straight to Calais — or to Heaven .
Devils ! dogs ! beasts !
Now these devoted bones
Will never lie at peace in English earth .
My country ! Must the foreign foot be set
Once more upon thy neck , and thine own sons
Pour sulphur to thy wounds ? The king ! the king !
What , vipers , do you hear ? Call in the king !

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: We must not , sir .

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: Ho , here ! The king !

div.stage: Rises from bed , starts forward and falls back speechless . Enter Henry , Gualo , Winchester , and attendants . Albemarle and Richford stand together . Pembroke dies pointing to them and gazing at the king .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: My lords , what does this mean ?

lg.l: This noble man
Wished much to say a word of grace for me
And his forgiven son . Alas , black death
Has stolen the balm that might have eased our way
Into your heart .
Fear not , my lords . I 'll trust you ,
Even as he wished .
O , Pembroke , couldst thou leave me ?

div.stage: Curtain

div.head: SCENE 2 . Before Dover castle . Night . Hubert de Burgh walking

stage.stage: and listening .

lg.l: But forty ships ! But forty slit-sailed drabs
Of storm and watery danger to meet all France
Fresh-winged upon the sea ! And yet no word
Nor stir of help . Methinks were I the king ,
Or Pembroke with his power in my mouth ,
Each English road should be ablaze to-night
With swift flint-striking hoofs . Now to our shore
Puffs up the wave may prove oblivion 's maw ,
And drink these Dover cliffs as they were sands ,
Yet England sleeps , with one lone heart at watch .
Nay , two , for Roland comes .

div.stage: Enter Roland de Born , dismounted

sp.speaker: Rol
sp.p: You , Hubert ?

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Ay . You bring no aid ?

lg.l: The king is powerless .
Pembroke is dead . The barons to covert slink ,
Saying their loyalty binds them to fight
No farther than the shore . The bishops smirk
Beneath their mitres , roll their eyes and cry
“ God and great Rome , deliver us ! ” which means
Deliver us to Louis , king of monks
And darling of the pope .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: And Albemarle ?

lg.l: Stands by the king , and ready with his men
To meet the foe on land , but not a soul
Will send to sea .
Dissembler ! Well he knows
A victory on the sea means England lost ,
So many traitor hearts will league with France
And sell their country for one castle more .
What now ? We 've little time . ‘ Tis almost day .
The moon is down , and the raw , rising air
Sucks in approaching light . What must be done ?
The Cinque Ports yield me forty ships .
With these
I 'll meet Le Moine .

sp.speaker: Rol
sp.p: O , Hubert , Hubert !

lg.l: Ay ,
My men are all aboard and waiting me .
The garrison I leave to you . Hold it
For honor and the king , nor yield to save
So poor a thing as my unlucky head
Should I go foul at sea . You 'll be the first
The victors will besiege .

sp.speaker: Rol
sp.p: My friend !

lg.l: Tut , man ,
The sea 's a good safe bed . Come in . Some wine
Will take the night-chill from your blood . In , in !

div.stage: Exeunt . Curtain

div.head: SCENE 3 . Within the castle . Stephen , Baldur , Godric , and other

stage.stage: soldiers talking and drinking .

lg.l: As good liquor as ever wet an oath since
Noah was a vintner .

sp.speaker: Bal
sp.p: Vintner ? An you put him in the trade the bishop will have you up for it .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: A groat for your bishop , and that off your grandam 's eyes ! I 'm no little king Henry pulled to mincemeat by his bishops and barons . “ I 'll take off your mitre , ” roars he to his bishop . “ An you take off my mitre , I 'll clap on a helmet , by the lord , ” says my bishop . “ I 'll have your castle ! ” shouts he to his baron . “ An you take my castle , I 'll give you London tower , ” says master baron . Ay , and he would , with the keeper thrown in .

sp.speaker: Bal
sp.p: And you too , if you bite not a bit from your tongue .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: By the mass , I 'll drink the king 's ale , and I 'll take the king 's money , but I 'll fight for none but Hubert de Burgh !

sp.speaker: God
sp.p: And he for the king — so you .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: I care not how you make it . De Burgh is my master . I 'll fight for him and with him and after him , but I 'll wear a red sword for no bishop or baron or little king Harry in Christendom !

sp.speaker: Bal
sp.p: That may be so with more of us than you , but stop your mouth with good ale and let words alone .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: And I 'll go with him to the French court and pull Louis off the king 's stool !SingsHear , boys , hear ! O , hear our captain call ! We 'll away , boys , away ! For the love o ’ the sword and the love o ’ the money , We 'll on to the wars , my brave fellows all , An they take our Jack they will leave our Johnny . Away , boys , away !

div.stage: Enter Hubert and Roland

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: What cheer , my men ? A fair morning for brave hearts . Can you keep this castle for me till I 've had a bout at sea ?

sp.speaker: A soldier
sp.p: That we can , sir !

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: I 'll go with you , sir , by your leave . The castle will wait for us , I give you my word , sir .

lg.l: You have seen the bottom of your glass too often to-night ,
Stephen .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: God bless you , sir , there 's where a soldier keeps his oath to serve God and his country , and he can n't look it over too often . Take me wi ’ you , sir , and I 'll prove you who lifts his glass the highest will wave his sword the longest .KneelsI was your father 's soldier , sir , and hope to die yours .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Nay , I must leave trusty souls behind me . Let those who love me least fight under my eye , but I 'll trust nay good Stephen around the world .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: RisingAy , sir ! Rain arrows , hail bullets , we 'll keep the castle against all weather !

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Presenting RolandThen here 's your brave captain . Follow him now , and farewell , good fellows — farewell , all !Soldiers start out slowly , following RolandAn old soldier .TurningBut you 'll come again , sir ?

sp.speaker: Another
sp.p: Ay , we 'll see you back ?

lg.l: An you come or come not , I kiss my sword to you , Hubert de
Burgh , the bravest knight in all England !

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Why , my hearts , would you start the liquor in my eyes ? I go where there 's brine enough . Twelve hours ’ sail with fortune will bring me back — but if I come not , remember your king !Exeunt soldiersThey know ‘ tis death — they know ‘ tis death . And what Is that ? We are all guests in God 's great house , The Universe , and Death is but his page To show us to the chamber where we sleep . What though the bed be dust , to wake is sure ; Not birds but angels flutter at the eaves And call us , singing .Enter GersaGersa , what success ?

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.p: The bags are all aboard , sir .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: And portioned to every vessel ?

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.p: Ay , sir .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Well despatched ?

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.p: The men heaved as though the sacks held all the pope 's treasury and they were to take their pay out of it .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Yet they found the contents not so heavy as gold , I hope .

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.p: Nor so light as feathers , sir .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: But I pray they 'll fly as well , and more to the purpose . Aboard with you now . I 'll not be long behind you .Exit GersaIf this , my careful stratagem , should fail , God help the friendless boy on England 's throne ! Now Pembroke 's noble strength must e'en to coffin ; And Isabel across the sea cares not , But happier in a gentler husband 's love Takes little thought of John of England 's heir , Who has his father 's beauty , not his heart ,— Just so much of that proud and guilty blood As makes him kingly nor corrupts his own . ... But , come , my soul ! Prepare thee for a world Of rarer breath , lest thou too rudely go To th ’ high conclave of spirits . Father ?

div.stage: Enter friar Sebastian

lg.l: Seb . Son ,
Art ready for the sacrament ?
I lack
A prayer of thine to make me so . Give me
Such blessing as you 'd lay upon me were
Death couchant for my heart , and on my brow
Drop thou the holy unguent that doth fit
The body for the last touch of the soul .
Seb . My love is to thy mortal frailty bound ,
And first I 'll bless thee as an earthly father ,
Praying that thou mayst smite thine enemies .
Rol Your pardon , Hubert . Lady Albemarle
Is here , and begs for instant sight of you .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: My sister ? I will see her .Exit RolandWait you , father . The world must still intrude on Heaven 's affairs .

div.stage: Exit friar through large folding doors rear as lady Albemarle enters left

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . Brother ! Is Glaia here ?

lg.l: She is . But why
This eagerness ?
Alb . My lord says that you go
To meet the French . Is ‘ t true ?
In one hour 's time
I count myself at sea .
Alb . Then what — O , where
Shall I hide Glaia ?
Hide ? Is ‘ t evermore hide
That spotless maid , born but to be a star
To human eyes ?
Alb . Nay , born to be my shame ,
And constant , killing fear !
She will be safe .
Roland de Born , who now will guard this castle ,
Holds Glaia as the heart in his own body .
Ay , she is safe ,— but if the danger nears ,
She 'll be conducted back to Greenot woods ——

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . Roland de Born ? What knows he ?

lg.l: Only this ,
That Glaia , weary of skies , rests foot on earth .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . He does not love her , Hubert ? Say not that !

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Thy daughter is so honored .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . No !

lg.l: She has
His noble love , and he my happy wish
That he may make her wife .
Alb . Then thou art false ,
And I look on my grave .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: What , Eleanor ?

lg.l: Alb . You know my place , and how I queen the court ,
A virtuous mark that lords point out to wives ,
Bidding them walk as Albemarle 's good dame .
Now let me take my seat on the lowest step ,
And none too humble to mock me going up .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: What 's this to do with Roland 's love for Glaia ?

lg.l: Alb . O , let them scorn ! Tis nothing ! But my husband —
Brother , I never dreamed thy cruelty
Would give me to his vengeance .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Cruelty ?

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . O , see me at his feet — bleeding and broken ——

lg.l: Not while I wear a sword ! But how have I
Disturbed thee ? What have said ? I 've threshed my words ,
But find no devil in them .
Alb . O , this Roland ,
If he wive Glaia must ferret out my shame —
Pry her life ope — who is she ?— whence she came ?—
Till all my secret blushes ‘ fore his eye .
Though he learn all , thy honor in his breast
Is safe as gem that at earth 's centre burns .
Alb . Nay , I 'll not live ! You know not Albemarle !
He 'll scourge me through the court in rags to match
My tattered virtue ,— then the rack — fire — screws —
The Scotch boot — O , the world 's not dear enough
To purchase so . I will not live !
I swear
That Roland cares so much for Glaia 's birth
As to be glad she 's born . And at my word
He will receive her questionless and dumb ,
Nor ever doubt , or weigh his promised faith .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . Why , is there such a man in all the world ?

lg.l: He sees her as one looks upon a rose ,
And thinks not of the mould that bore it , or what
The tale that dews and winds could tell .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . ‘ Tis strange .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: As strange as truth .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . I must — I do believe you .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: And bless his suit ?

lg.l: Alb . Ay , let him wed her straight .
What waits he for ? Let her be lost in him ,
This rare , this unmatched wonder of a man ,
And I will cast this shadow from my life ,
Heave off the weight that seventeen years I 've borne ,
And walk the lighter , for I 've known what ‘ tis
To step high ‘ neath a load . O , let them wed
As soon as may be , Hubert . Why not now ?

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: He waits to win her heart .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . Cares he for that ? You can command her , Hubert .

lg.l: But will not .
She is a plant of Nature 's tenderest love ,
And must be won to bloom by softest airs ,
Else shall we risk the gentle life and see
No buds unfold .
Alb . I understand her not ,
Nor try . She is a part of strangest days ,
That like to burning dreams bewilder as
They scar the recollection . She 's more kin
To those strange creatures of the wood that peeped
About my shelter when she lay a babe
Than to my blood . Yet she is mine — my daughter .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Wilt you not see her ?

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . No .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: You will find her up .

lg.l: Alb . Why should I see her ? Give a stranger 's kiss ,
And hear her stiffly say “ Your ladyship ” ?
If she would love me !

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Do not weep .

lg.l: Alb . You think
I do not suffer .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: I 've no wish to think so .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . I 'm nearly mad at times ! But I must go .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: HesitatingHow is — the princess ?

lg.l: Alb . Margaret ? O , well ,
But every day more full of starts and whims .
Last night the king was with us ——

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Ah , the king ?

lg.l: Alb . She gave him stinted welcome . Then my lord
Came in with news of the advancing fleet ,
And danger to the throne , concluding with
Your aim to put to sea , and at that point
She swooned quite prettily and pleased the king .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: She swooned ?

lg.l: Alb . Most properly , the king being by
To know it was for him .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: O — ay , for him !

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . Who else ? I hope they 'll soon be wed .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Be wed ? Henry is young .

lg.l: Alb . But old enough being king .
And Albemarle is pressing for the marriage .
‘ Tis now ten years since Margaret came from Scotland
To be his charge . A pretty child — do you
Remember ? But now grown from beauty , pale
And fanciful . You 've seen the change ?
To me
She never changes but to show herself
More beautiful .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . You have not seen it ? Pah ! Now I must go . Good brother , fare you well . You 've given me comfort .Kisses him

lg.l: Farewell , Eleanor .
Art gone , my sister , and no word of love
For one who looks on death ? It is the fear
That keeps so constant with her makes her hard
And unlike woman — unlike Margaret .
... Last night the king was with her — and she swooned .
But not for him . By Heaven , ‘ twas not for him !
lg.stage: Sits by table , bowing his head upon it
lg.l: O Margaret ! Not one dear word ? Not one ?

div.stage: Enter Margaret , veiled

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Ah !Steps toward him , throwing off her veilHubert ?

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Starting upPrincess ! Here ? You here ?

lg.l: Couldst think I 'd let thee go till I had said
“ God save thee ” to thy face ?

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: You risk too much !

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Risk , Hubert ?

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: O , what have you done ?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: What done ?

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: The king will think ——

lg.l: The king will think as I do ,
That ‘ tis most natural to pay adieu
To friends .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: But Albemarle ——

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Approves our friendship . I do not understand .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Yet you came veiled .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: ‘ Twas early — and the air was pricking chill . I — thought — do you go soon ?

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: That you should come !

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Soon , Hubert ?

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Ay , at once .

lg.l: At once . Why then ,
Farewell .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Stay ! Ah — I mean — why did you come ?

lg.l: My soul ! I think I came that you might wish
Me back again . Was it so wrong of me ?
Are we not friends ? And if I came in hope
To ease adieu with unction of a tear
I know none else would shed ——
O , Margaret !
Pray God that I deserve this ! Now I go
So light I 'll hardly need my ship 's good wings
To bear me .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: The earl doubts not your victory . How many ships go with you ?

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: All we have . The ports hold not a single vessel from me .

lg.l: And the enemy 's ? I hope they are enough
To make your victory noble .
I 've no doubt
They count up bravely .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Not too many , sir !

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: The battle will not shame me .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: But how many ?

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: As yet we have no word but rumor 's .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Ah ! Tell me you 'll win .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Then help me by not doubting .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: I must not doubt — for if — I did ——

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: What then ?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Nay , I 'll not stay to tell you . I must go . I keep you from the battle and your fame . You have forgiven me my morning ride ? Faith , but you frowned !

lg.l: I thought how many eyes
Were on the king 's betrothed .
Choose better words ,
My friend . I am not yet the king 's betrothed ,
And I — had you the time ——
Nay , all my life
Is yours .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Hear then . I will not wed the king .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: A princess can not choose .

lg.l: Then I 'll not be
A princess !

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Margaret !

lg.l: A princess ? Nay ,
I 'll be no more a woman , if that means
To cage my soul in circle of a court
And fawn on turnkey humor for my life !
Scotland is lost to me . I 'll not go there
To meet my dangerous brother 's wrath . No , no !
But there are forests — I can fly to them ,
And dig my food from Nature 's generous earth ,
Thrive on her berries , drink from her clear streams ,
Sleep ‘ neath the royal coverlet of her leaves ,
And make some honest friends ‘ mong her kind creatures
That we call dumb because , forsooth , they speak
By eye and touch and gibber not as we !
... So silent , sir ? Come , will you not advise me ?...
There was a day before the day of kings
When maidens looked where'er their hearts had sped
And found them mates who had no need of crowns
To make them royal , and such a day the world
May see again , but I , alack , must breathe
The present time , and crave the help of state
And craft and gold to get me married ! O ,
The judgment angel gathering up our clay
Will know this period by its broken hearts !
... Hast not a word ? Now should I wed the king ?
He is a gentle youth , and in your care
Would blossom brave in virtues .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Nay ——

lg.l: All hope
For this poor land lies in your grace .
Ah , Hubert ,
Where is there woman strong enough to save
Fair Henry from his flatterers ? Not here .
Wouldst cast me to the pool where he must drown ?
Where canst thou hide thy beauty , Margaret ?
This is wild talk of forests . Where couldst flee ?
What land would shelter thee from England 's love
And Scotland 's rage ? My own — my Margaret —
Where could we go ?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: O , Hubert , we ?

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: I 'm mad . Peace to thee , maiden . I go to my ships .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Forgive me ! I 'll be gone .

div.stage: Re-enter Gersa

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: What ! Not aboard ?

lg.l: Your pardon , sir . We have confirmed reports
The French outnumber us by triple count .
Eighty large ships , the double of our own ,
Besides two score of galleons and small vessels
That in themselves would match us . And ‘ tis sure
Le Moine , the pirate , leads the fleet .
Are all
Now ready ?

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.p: Ay , we wait for you .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Grant me A bare half hour — no — not so much . I shall O'ertake you ere you reach your ship .Exit Gersa . Hubert turns to Margaret and finds that she has faintedMy lady ! Is this , too , for the king ?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: RevivingYou shall not go !

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: I must — and now . Let me but press your hand ——

lg.l: No , no , my lips ! Hubert , let us be true .
Death watches now and will report all lies
To Heaven . Now I must see you go from me ,
Out of my eyes as stars go from the sky ,
And never , never see you come again ,
Let me once hear you say you love me , Hubert ,
And all the years that I must weep for thee
I 'll keep the words as a sweet golden bell
To sound whene'er my ears want music .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Thou art the king 's .

lg.l: Nay , I will lay my head
Upon the block , ere pillow it by his .
Then we 'll be mad together , Margaret .
To go one step in this is to go farthest .
Ah , yesterday I saw a knight I loved
Sink in his blood ; but when he called the name
Of his dear bride , and died as it made sweet
His lips , I thought of you and envied him .
And now , so soon , his fortune is my own .
Come , father !
Art afraid ?
Ah , yes , afraid
That I may lose thee !
Is it hell , or Heaven ?
Good father , when two souls have kissed so close
They in each other lose the form of self ,
And neither body knows its own again ,
Wouldst join them mortally , that being one
They can not go amiss ?
Seb . If they be free ,
My son , to take the vows .

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.p: Thou knowest us .

sp.speaker: Fr
sp.p: Seb . I 've blessed ye both as children .

lg.l: I am free
By my soul 's right , and though a princess born ,
Here choose my lord .
Seb . My daughter , thou art noble ,
And must be written fair though envy keep
The beadroll of thy faults , but ‘ tis poor rank
Not thee stoops to this choice .
I know it , father .
Though it should cost my fortune , name and place ,
I 'd give them all to be his wife one hour .
Seb . Then , by my sacred vows , as I believe
Love is from Heaven , and ‘ tis God himself
Who fosters its sweet growth through all the blood
Till action , thought , yea , life , do hang upon it ,
I 'll bind ye in the dear eternal bonds ,
And bless your union with the holy feast .
Come in with me .
‘ Tis Heaven , Margaret !
ACT II

div.head: SCENE 1 . Within Dover castle . Same room as in act first . Enter

stage.stage: Glaia followed by Eldra .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: O , my lady , up all night , and now ‘ tis barely day you must be going !

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: My good Eldra , you would teach my shadow constancy , for you follow me without let or leave from the sun .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: I follow not you but my orders , mistress . Sir Roland says that I must not leave you .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: The gates are all locked . Does he think me a bird to fly over the walls ?

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: That he does ! The bonniest bird that ever sang in Greenot woods . Is n't Sir Roland a man , my lady ?

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: By his cap and feather , I should not doubt it .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: But a man you may look at , my lady !

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: Pray God I may , madam , for ‘ tis sad to be young and blind .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Ay , but when I look at Sir Roland I could sing again the song that got me a husband .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: What song ? I think you got him with your fair face and honest mind , and he took the song by way of grace with meat .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: True , mistress , I was a fair , canny lass over the border .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: And a fair , canny dame you are now , Eldra . But what was the song ?

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: It was back summat ten jaunts o ’ the sun from Lammas to Lammas . I was standing on the rock hills over Logan frith wi ’ the green woods behind me an ’ lookin ’ out to sea . The waves were runnin ’ high , and the brine in my face gave me such a spirit that in a minute my bonnet was off and I was singing at the top of my voice — O braw , braw knight , come down the glen And awa ’ to kirk wi ’ me ! And Heaven send us seven stout sons To fight for our king on the sea ! It 's a long ballad , but it 's out o ’ my mind now , and who should come up behind me but my man that was to be , and ‘ twas set then and there we must go to the kirk come Sunday . Ay , it got me a husband , but never a son , for only six months away he was drowned at sea — the very sea that I 'd sung so brave t-to ——

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: Do n't cry . He will come sailing back some day with a fortune in his pocket . I do n't believe he was drowned .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: I care not what 's in his pocket , ma'am , if he bring me love in his heart .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: That he will , I am sure . Where is Orson ?

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Bathing his knees in gooseoil , my lady . You kept him at prayers all night for Sir Hubert .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: Why , did we not share his watch ?

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Yes , mistress , but when you fell asleep we had not the heart to wake you .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: O , ho ! I fell asleep , did I ?

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: I should hope you did , my lady . For my part I winked but once , and when I woke up you were ——

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: Asleep ?

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: No , but you were praying so chipper that I knew you were just at it .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: O , false woman ! Do you think I could sleep when Hubert is on the sea ? Call Orson to me .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Orson ! Orson !

div.stage: Enter Orson , walking stiffly

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: Why , Orson , you carry as much dignity as a watchman that has just let in a duke .

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: Mock not affliction got in your service , my lady .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: My service ? When did I tell you to sleep all night on your knees ?

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: Sleep ? Sleep , lady ?

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: Ay , sleep . You are a knave . Bring me my lute .

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: MutteringSleep ! There 's thanks for you !

div.stage: Exit

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Mistress , you must not play your lute here . The king 's men are not like Sir Hubert 's , and your voice will quick tell ‘ em there 's a bird in the bower .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: I am not afraid . What are men but creatures like ourselves ?

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Like ourselves ? La , my lady !

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: There 's no harm in them . You are a foolish dame .

div.stage: Re-enter Orson
Taking lute ] Good Orson , I am sorry if your knees are stiff . You may have the unguent that Sir Roland brought me from Palestine . Go , Eldra , and get it for him .

lg.l: An I give him not gooseoil with a dash of cinnamon ,
I 'm no good servant to my mistress .

div.stage: Exeunt Eldra and Orson

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: I do not like this castle with Hubert away . Sir Roland makes it a prison . If I could get out I should try to find my way to Greenot woods . The doves are nesting now , and the little brown fawns are specked with snow .Plays lute and singsO , lady , let the roses blow In thy pale cheeks for this — That I may to that garden go And pluck them with a kiss . My roses are all plucked , she said , No more shall ever grow , For cold is he and low his head Whose dear love made them blow . Then lay she down where slept her lord Upon the silver heather ; Then sighed the knight , nor said he word , But left the twa together .

div.stage: Enter the king , dressed in black . He gazes at Glaia

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: What is your name , boy ?

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Henry .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: Henry ? That is the king 's name . Are you his soldier ?

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: I fight for him .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: Ah , me !

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Is it not brave to fight ?

lg.l: But kings are wicked
To buy their kingdoms with their subjects ’ lives .
Two days ago they brought a noble knight
Into the castle , bloody and quite dead ,
And when I cried , my Hubert whispered “ Hush ,
‘ Tis for the king . ” Hubert is now at sea —
Mayhap this moment dies — and for the king .
And ‘ twas last night I heard Sir Roland say
“ We 'll hold the castle till each man is down , ”
All for the king . And now you fight for him .
I hate the king !

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: O , do not say that .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Because he loves you .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: He has never seen me . You 're merry , boy .

lg.l: But good kings love their subjects
Before they know them .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: O ! Is Henry good ?

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: He prays to be so .

lg.l: Let him pray , lest he
Grow old in evil like his father , John .
Who is your father , Henry ?

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: He is dead .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: Ah ! But you have a mother .

lg.l: Far away ,
And one who loves me little .
Now I 'll sigh
No more for parents , since I know that they
May die , or prove unkind . I have no kin .
But Hubert loves me .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Lady ——

lg.l: I am Glaia .
That is all I know , but Hubert says
Some day he 'll tell me more . I do not care .
I love to be a mystery to myself .
She 's nobly born , and kept from her estate ;
But how should she be honest Hubert 's charge ?

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: What say you , Henry ?

lg.l: ‘ Tis so strange to find
An angel housing in this black-browed castle ,
Converting war 's grim seat to paradise .
Hast always lived here ?
O , behind these walls ?
No , I 've a home deep in the happy forest .
I do not like this place — these huge black rocks
Piled up so high , with caves i ’ the ground , and holes
To shoot out arrows . I walk on tiptoe here ,
Afraid I 'll wake the ghosts that sleep i ’ the corners .
But in the forest I can shout and run ,
And everything I wake will laugh and sing .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Where is this happy place ?

lg.l: I can not tell .
‘ Twas night when we came here , and Hubert says
That none must know the way . I wonder why .
Do you live in a castle ?
When I 'm not
At wars .
O me , I would not live in one
To please ——

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: The king ?

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: No , not to please the king .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: If he were lonely , Glaia ?

lg.l: Lonely ? O ,
He is to wed the princess Margaret .
Are you not glad ? He 'll not be lonely then .
She 's fair and good , they say .
But not as you .
Her princess feet like well the solid earth .
She is a flower that sips of sun and dew .
But feedeth most from root-cups firm in ground ;
While you are made of music , love , and air ,—
A being of the sky — a lover 's star ,
Although he be a king . The grace of heaven
About your beauty plays , and drops as soft
Upon my eyes as light from the lark 's wing .
But I must leave you now . Sweet , take this gift .
And know my name and place are worthy yours ,
Though you should be a princess , as I think .
See , here 's a jewel in this belt . I dare
To part with it , though wise men say my life
Is safe but when I wear it . ‘ Tis the stone
Of Wales , and blessed by magic of the seers
That in that country dwell .
Then keep it . Ay ,
You must .
No , no ! I have a fear some harm
Will touch you , me away . Keep you the charm ,
And I will take your lute . In lonely hours
I 'll touch the chords and think thou'rt listening .

div.stage: Exit

lg.l: A lovely boy ! O me , these dreadful wars !
Eldra 's a goose to call the king 's men rude .
I wish he had not gone . I 'll play again
And see who 'll come . Ah , now I have no lute .
No matter , I will sing .
O , sweet the day and fair the May ,
But Love he laid him down to weep ——

div.stage: Enter Gregory

lg.l: A pixy sure !
Sweet apparition , wilt fly if I approach ?
Then here I 'll stand , and from this point remote
As frosty Hebrid from the golden East ,
Adore thy seeming substance ! Ah , no answer ?
Advance then , valiant Gregory , and explore .
Flesh ? ‘ S light , ‘ tis flesh ! A very woman , too .
A silent woman . Heavenly miracle !
With lips like twin strawberries ‘ neath one leaf .
The very manner of them begs a kiss .
I ’ faith , they shall not beg .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: You would not kiss me !

lg.l: You wrong me , duck . Why , I 'm a man of mirth
A soldier , sweet . And would not kiss ? Now , now !
You take me for a ghost — or starve-bone saint .
I am not padded — I fill out my coat
And owe but for the cloth . A man , my chick !
Shalt have a kiss .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: O , help me , Eldra ! Help !

div.stage: Stephen runs in , seizes Gregory and shakes him about

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Pricking him with his swordShalt have a kiss , he shall ! A man , my chick ! I fill my coat , I do . ’

lg.l: Hold , sir ! I am
An officer of the king !
Why then , shalt have
More kisses ! ‘ S blood ! I thought thee but a scrub .
A king 's man , sir , shall have more ceremony .

div.stage: Pricks him around the room . Enter Roland

sp.speaker: Rol
sp.p: Stephen ! Brawling here ? You know the orders .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Orders , I take it , sir , do n't count in such a case extraordinary .

sp.speaker: Rol
sp.p: Your extraordinary cases have become quite usual , Stephen .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Be you the judge , sir . This gay blood here was troubling the lady ——

sp.speaker: Rol
sp.p: Glaia ! Then he dies !Drawing his sword

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Orders , orders , sir !

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: He did not touch me , Roland .

lg.l: Touch thee ? If he
No more than looked at thee death is enough .
But had he touched thee ——

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: Art thou cruel , Roland ? I thought thee gentle . Wouldst thou make me hate thee ?

lg.l: You shall not hate me , Glaia .
Let him live .
But take him from my sight .

div.stage: Exeunt Stephen and Gregory

lg.l: O , Roland , now
I love thee !

sp.speaker: Rol
sp.p: Love me , Glaia ?

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: Next to Hubert .

sp.speaker: Rol
sp.p: O , next to Hubert .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: And the boy .

sp.speaker: Rol
sp.p: The boy ?

lg.l: Henry his name is . Such a pretty youth !
He gave me this ,— and see , this jewel here
Is all so precious that it guards the life
Of whoso wears it . He must like me well
To give it me . Dost think he likes me , Roland ?
O God , the king ! ... Give me the baldric , Glaia .
I will return it , for I know the youth .
In truth , I 've seen him wear this very belt .
‘ Twas wrong to take it , Glaia . He belongs
So wholly to the king that you can have
No portion of his love , lest he betray
Himself and thee . Go , get you ready , child ,
To leave this place . For you ‘ tis full of dangers .
Back to the woods ? O happiness ! But I —
Ah , must we go so soon ?

sp.speaker: Rol
sp.p: It was your prayer .

lg.l: But then — I had not — strange ! Why is it , Roland ,
‘ Tis not so merry going as I thought ?
Is't not a little lonely in the woods ?
And yet it never seemed so . Will you come
To see me , Roland ?

sp.speaker: Rol
sp.p: Do you want me , Glaia ?

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: O , yes , dear Roland ! And you 'll bring the boy ? I want to ask if he will be my brother .

lg.l: You must not see him . Go and get you ready .
O , wretched me , to love so frail a thing !
Fragile and pure , thou art not for this world ,
Where the same winds that bring thee breath must blow
Thy gentle life out .
Sovereign liege ,
Count it not boldness if I dare to guess
Your presence here . You come , my lord , to find
This precious property .
I know ‘ tis prized ,
And hold me happy that it met my eye
Before another 's .
Gentle Roland , thanks .
I need not ask if you found aught with this
More precious still .
Nothing that majesty
Might without blushing claim .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Thank you again .AsideI 've found the lover ! ... Is there news from sea ?

lg.l: Uncertain news , that I was on my way
To give to you . Report cries victory
For Hubert , but ‘ tis chance improbable
That he should win , so take a breath , your highness ,
Ere you believe .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: The lords must know of this !

sp.speaker: Rol
sp.p: Your majesty , I have a suit to thee .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: A victory !

lg.l: If you do hold him dear
Who , by report , has won this doubtful battle ,
That saves your kingdom and sets fast your crown ,
I beg you hear me !
Speak , but be not slow ,
Good Roland .
Sire , De Burgh has enemies
Who seek his downfall , for his honesty
Stands rock-like ‘ tween the throne and treachery .
‘ Twas they who wrought to send him feebly forth
‘ Gainst odds so great they left no chance of life
Save by God 's love and favor . If he wins ,
The victor 's garland and his king 's reward
Will further urge their hate to villainy .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Who are these foes ?

lg.l: The earl of Albemarle ,
Pembroke and Winchester .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: My very staff ! What proof hast thou ?

lg.l: I 've nothing for your eye .
But in my heart there is a testament
That makes me bold to name them . I would risk
All but my soul to save you such a friend
And virtuous servant as De Burgh , You may
Condemn me ——

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: First , I 'll watch these lords . But be they false , where , where shall I find friends ?

lg.l: ‘ Mong those who fight your battles , sire , nor fear
To die to save a king .

div.stage: Exit

lg.l: I see a king
Must take some thought to keep his crown on ‘ s head .

div.stage: Re-enter Stephen and Eldra

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Dear man , you can n't deny it ! ‘ Twas you saved my mistress . But for my good man drowned at sea I 'd love you , sweeting .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: And if you love me it must be by way of kiss and part , for my good wife is still in the world , I 've reason to think , and some day I shall run plumb into her bonny white arms . But a kiss , my lass , with a penny to the priest , can do a soldier no harm , and you 'll always find me obliging in everything except matrimony .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Out ! Away ! You old father Longbeard ! You Johnny Hump-back !

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Hump ! ‘ Tis the squint in your eye , my dearie ! I 'm as straight as a poplar in the king 's court .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Squint , sir ? May be so , for I 'm thinkin ’ o ’ my braw handsome man , an ’ ‘ twould make a straight eye squint to see you standin ’ in his place , it would .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: An ’ I 'm thinkin ’ o ’ my bonny little girl , as plump and tender as a partridge at her first nest , and out upon you , my fine , fat waddler !

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: An my man were here you 'd drop to your fours and go like a beast for shame , you would . The prettiest figure ‘ tween here and Jerusalem ! He had an arm ! He could sling a sword ! And such a leg ! Dick Lion-heart never shaped a trimmer stocking . Hair like a raven fannin ’ the wind ! An eye like Sallydeen 's ! For all the world a black coal with a fire in the middle . No watery peepers like present company 's . An his eyes were stars in heaven I could point ‘ em out !

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: O , my sweet wench that 's a waitin ’ for me ! When shall I see her comin ’ with her head up like a highland doe , an ’ cheeks as red as my grandam 's nightcap ? I think o ’ her now as she stood on the high rocks over Logan 's frith singin ’ the song that made the sugar-water start in my heart . And straight I must gallop wi ’ her to the kirk — Hey , what 's the matter , old lady ?

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Nothin ’ — nothin ’ , sir ,— just one o ’ my qualms .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Do you have ‘ em ordinary ? A pity now . My lass , an she lived a thousand years , would not he qualmsy .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Aside‘ Tis Stephen , my own man ! And he does n't know me ! O , I am changed from his ain lassie ! He despises me ! Waddler ! O !

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Chirk up , old duck . When I find my lass ——

div.stage: Re-enter Orson

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: Mistress Eldra , what do you gabbling here and my lady calling you ?

div.stage: Exit Eldra with Orson

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Eldra ? By Pharo 's ghost ! Let me see — ten years . It might be — yes — her very complexion — the pert eye — the little foot — the canny twitch to her lips — and her man drowned at sea . Well , I 'm pickled . She has built up such a Solomon 's glory picture o ’ me that plain Stephen Godfrey will never get another chance . He had an arm ! Ha ! Did I ? An eye like Sallydeen ! A leg like Lion-heart ! Ha !Struts up and downBut now I 'm father Longbeard . Well , I 'll shave off this weeping willow tree anyhow .

div.stage: Re-enter Eldra

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Good sir , are you here yet ?

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: AsideGood sir ! Methinks I grow in favor . Ay , sweet madam .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: AsideHe 's lookin ’ softer now . Well a day , this is a world . Here they brought me and the lady Glaia to make sure we would be safe , and now they 're taking us back for the same reason . Ay me , and a lonely , dreary place it is we 're goin ’ to , with never a civil gentleman like yourself to sit out the night wi ’ a stoop o ’ ale an ’ cakes o ’ my own raisin ’ .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: My good madam , if you will give me the tip o ’ the road , I 'll not be a slow traveller when the business of war will let an honest soldier course to his liking .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: O , ‘ tis secret , sir . My lady is hid away for some reason of God or the devil , and I 'll not be so false as to let a stranger on the track .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Am I a stranger , madam ? Did not my good arm no more than an hour ago procure me warrant for better treatment ? Come ! As you say , there 'll be lonely times , and a discreet companion who knows how to keep his tongue behind his teeth will not come amiss on a rainy day .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: AsideHow can it be harm to tell my own man when the good priest said we were one flesh ? ‘ Twill only be tellin ’ my own ears . Well , sir , if you 'll swear by St. Peter 's thumb and the crucifix you 'll never let anybody know ——

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: By St. Peter 's thumb and the crucifix — and your black eyes , too — I swear !

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Then take the straight road to — O , I 'm afraid !

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Courage , my pretty ! There 's not a cricket to hear you .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: The straight road to Greenot woods , and two miles in the forest where the brook crosses , ride up the stream half a mile to a tall red ash standin ’ alone , and three miles by the path to the right brings you to the place you 'll find me . Now I 've done it ! No , do n't thank me for bein ’ a fool .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Nay , a woman , dearie .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: I must run to my mistress .

div.stage: Exit Eldra , Stephen following

lg.l: Go , Stephen with the Lion 's leg . You 'll haste
If I be not before you . Am I bound
To Margaret ? By others ’ mouths , perhaps .
But certain not at all by oath of mine .
What holy gloom comes here ? Friar Sebastian ,
One time the counsellor to Isabel .
Do you not know me , father ?

sp.speaker: Fr
sp.p: Seb .KneelingGracious king !

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Nay , rise and bless me .

lg.l: Seb . Hear , my sovereign .
This meeting is not chance . I sought thee here
To tell what palsies me to think on .
Speak ,
Then think of it no more .
Seb . ‘ Tis said De Burgh
Has gained the victory ‘ gainst all expectance .
I know that he was sure he went to death ,
Else had he never put unto his lips
The rose that bloomed for one so high above him .
But dreaded death is yet full gracious , sire ,
And sanctions rights too bold for life to claim .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Did Hubert wrong me , father ?

sp.speaker: Fr
sp.p: Seb . Alas , my king !

lg.l: Come , drop your burden even to my heart
That I may know its weight .
Seb . Sire , in the hour
That he spent last on land , I married him
To a most noble lady .
Married ? Ha !
Nor asked consent of me ? Not one
“ By your good leave , my king ” ?
Seb . If in my words
So soon you find affront to majesty ,
I dare not tell you more .
Nay , I 'll forgive him .
Remembering his service ‘ twere too stern
To make contention of his marriage .
Seb . Though he should banish all the woes of England ,
Make sorrow alien , and a tear unknown ,
Yet has he wronged a king . Though happy mothers
Drop on their knees and let no hour pass by
Without its prayer for him , still has he wronged
A king !
Wilt never speak because you speak
So much ?
Seb . Here let me lie , and pray your grace
For two long troubled hearts . When I have spoken
Then set thy foot upon my priestly head ,
But spare them , spare them , sire !
Up ! Rise , I say ,
From this debasement . We shall take good care
To shield your holiness . Now speak !
Seb . One word
Will tell you — one .
And how much time will ‘ t take
To say that word ?
Seb . It is the name of her
Whom knightly Hubert made his wife .
Is it
A long name , father ?

sp.speaker: Fr
sp.p: Seb .On his kneesIt is Margaret .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: RisingOf Scotland ?

sp.speaker: Fr
sp.p: Seb .Covering his headAy , my liege .

lg.l: Deliverance !
Rise , father , rise , and learn that even a king
Is noble enough to suffer and forgive .
Seb . Have I my ears ? Are these your words , my lord ?
Or does some pitying angel alchemize
Them into sounds more fit to reach my weak
And trembling age ?
You hear even as I speak .
‘ Tis true that Hubert pitched his love full high .
Good manners had not o'ershot the royal bow ;
But take my word no harm shall come to him .
Seb . He 'll need a friend , my liege , for dangers stride
In wake of this rash marriage .
Leave them
To me . I 'll try my fledgling wit in this .
Where is the cardinal ?

sp.speaker: Fr
sp.p: Seb . I ’ the western hall .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Here come the lords . But first I 'll speak with Gualo .

div.stage: Exeunt Henry and friar Sebastian , left . At right , enter Albemarle , Winchester and Pembroke

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: To AlbemarleHe has not yet confirmed you chancellor ?

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: No need , so short his reign .

lg.l: We should have news .
By this the battle 's done . I wonder now
How far is Hubert 's head on its long journey
To ocean 's bottom ?
May it please your grace ,
We think ‘ tis best that you stay with the king .
If all desert him ‘ twill look foul in us ,
And it will take an honest English face
To keep the people with us .
True , my lord .
And I will stay with him , for I have gone
A little deeper in his heart than you ,
And can best turn him to advance our plot .
While we ride forth to call men to defence —
In truth to give them hand and foot to Louis —
You wait here with the king ——
I understand .
And you not coming up , perforce be taken .
Then Henry may lay by his crown , or keep ‘ t
To please his jailer 's peeping mammets , or bribe
His turnkey for a slug of meat .
The jail
Where he must lie is small and needs no keeper ;
For who go in so well contented are
They 're never known to set foot forth again .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: Must go so far ? Well , as you please , my lords .

div.stage: Re-enter Henry , with Cardinal Gualo and attendants

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: God save your majesty !

lg.l: My faithful friends ,
Well met .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: Ah , still in black , my liege ?

lg.l: Why not ,
My lord ? When my poor father in the flesh
Was struck by death they dressed me in this hue ;
And heavier cause have I to wear it now ,
When he who gave my soul its dearest light —
My father in nobility above
The blood or happy chance of birth — is gone
To come no more .
But , good , my liege , am I
So little worth that with a strange misfit
I wear his dignity ?
The worthier
You are to wear ‘ t you 'll teach me to regret
His goodness lost , and be more pleased to see
How I prize virtue dead , guessing thereby
How dear is living virtue to my soul .

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: Aside to AlbemarleDoes he suspect ?

lg.l: ‘ Twould trouble us . There are
Some captains in the fort would make a way
For his escape .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: You 've had no news , my lords ?

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: We yet wait word , but rest you easy , sire . Our fleet is safe and proudly bearing home .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Your faith is strong .

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: I have no doubt , my lord .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Were it not well to take this time to plan De Burgh 's reward ?

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: Ay , ‘ twere , your majesty .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: What say you , my lord cardinal ? You first . How should we grace his triumph ? With what honor ?

sp.speaker: Gualo
sp.p: None is too great . I 'd place him next the throne . What think your lordships ?

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: As yourself , my lord .Aside to PembrokeBest humor him .

lg.l: Then further I may speak .
The earl of Kent , who lately met his death ,
Has left no heir to his vast lands and name .
I think that God did so provide this place
For honor of De Burgh . And more than this ,
Let him be made the great lord chancellor ,
And chief justiciary of this troubled realm .

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: Aside to PembrokeAgree . No matter . Gualo 's eye is on us .

lg.l: You speak in happy time , lord cardinal ,
And we embrace your meaning heartily .
This easy payment of so great a debt
Inclines me to forget the dangerous way
De Burgh comes by his honor . We must keep
That ever in our hearts , my worthy lords ,
Lest we grow jealous of his climbing fortune .

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: I hope we 've memories , sire , and honest ones .

lg.l: Well , to forfend the bating of his praise
In my poor mind , I 'll give a lasting proof
Of how I hold him , and here forfeit right
To Margaret 's hand in favor of De Burgh .

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: My liege ! The princess ?

lg.l: He is now an earl ;
And if I not complain , should any here ?

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: But , sire ——

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: Aside to AlbemarleSubmit ! ‘ Tis only for an hour .

lg.l: Pardon me that I thought to save you , sire
From such dear sacrifice .
‘ Tis fit we make it ,
And ask your fair approval , Albemarle .

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: And here I give it , my too gracious king .To an attendantWhist ! Are the horses saddled ?

sp.speaker: Att
sp.p: Ready , sir .

div.stage: Enter Gregory

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Well , captain , well ?

lg.l: The princess Margaret
And lady Albemarle are at the gates .

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: My countess gads for news of her brave brother .

lg.l: A worthy quest .
See them refreshed and lodged ,
But bid them keep their chamber for a time .

div.stage: Exit Gregory

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: To PembrokeWhere are our messengers ? Can they be lost ?

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: We should have heard by now . There 's something wrong .

div.stage: Enter an attendant

sp.speaker: Att
sp.p: Your majesty , a messenger !

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: From sea ?

div.stage: Enter Gersa

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.p: The king ! Where is the king ?

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: Pray use your eyes .

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.p: KneelingYour majesty .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Arise . Your message ?

lg.l: Sire ,
Hubert de Burgh is at the port .

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: AsideHow now ?

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.p: With all his ships but five .

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: To WinchesterBut five ? What 's here ?

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: A witch i ’ the pot , your lordships .

lg.l: For those five
There 's fifty of the French gone to the bottom .
The rest are scattered wide , with crippled sails
Begging the winds for mercy .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Hark , my lords ! Divinity is here .To GersaHow was this done ? What know you of the battle ?

lg.l: When we met
The opposing fleet , we crept by swift and silent ,
As to escape the fight . So near we coursed
We heard the jeers cast on us as we passed .
Well by , we turned , and with the wind at back ,
Bore down full sail and grappled .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Here were men !

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.p: Then , sire , we cut the lime-sacks on our decks ——

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Lime-sacks ?

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.p: Which gave out smarting clouds that rose ——

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Now here were fools !

lg.l: Sire , you forget the wind .
The sweeping breeze took up the stinging lime ,
Clearing our decks , but wrapping round our foes ,
Blinding all eyes .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: St. George !

lg.l: ‘ Twas easy then
To hook our vessels to the great French ships ,
Cut down their rigging and make way at will
O'er the wallowing crew .

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: Must we believe this tale ?

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Goes it against your wish ?

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: Nay , but ‘ tis strange .

lg.l: One hundred knights , eight hundred officers ,
Now wait their doom from you . Le Moine was found
Hid in his ship , and offered mighty sums
For his vile life , but Fitzroy closed the parley
By striking off his head .

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: What ? Le Moine dead ?

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Why so amazed , my lord of Albemarle ? Did you not prophesy a victory ?

lg.l: True , true , my liege , but this surpasses all
My hope of it . Call it a miracle ,
Not victory .
Call it whate'er you will ,
The Lord of Hosts was with this noble knight .
Not knight , but the right noble earl of Kent ,
And for his life our grand justiciary .
Thou art the mavis to a happy dawn .
Come , sing again .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: To Albemarle and PembrokeYour lordships , do you ride ?

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: What tone is this ?

lg.l: A tone you 'll tune to , sir .
Didst think me such a fool to stay and fall
With Henry into Louis ’ hands ? Nay , I 've
No wish to enter that small cell of earth
Which needs no turnkey , as you say .

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: What , sir ?

lg.l: No , by the Lord ! At the first castle where
You planned to stop I had my servants laid
To take you prisoners . It stirs my blood
That you should think I came to the bishopric
By a fool 's wit . Now Rome is at my back ,
And Henry king ! But I 'll make peace with you ,
For I foresee a power in De Burgh
That warns me not to scorn even traitor strength .
Ay , we 've no fear you 'll let this sudden turn
Cut off our fortunes .
Come , my lords . Come , all !
We 'll to the gates to greet the earl of Kent !
ACT III

div.div:
SCENE 1 . Same as in act second . The king , Pembroke , Albemarle , Winchester , and other lords entering . Winchester , and other lords entering .
Hen
The barons are assembling . On to London ,
And call the council . I will join you there .
The revenues long promised shall be paid .
At last I am a king ! Will post , my lords ?
Night shuffles toward the morn .
Pem
You 'll not forget
Your barons ’ suit , my liege .
Hen
Bring the petition . I 'll look at it , and then — will what I will .
Exit
Alb
What new-gown cock is this ?
Pem
Will what I will ! And post you , sirs !
Win
The child that hung at knees
Now stands on the great shoulders of De Burgh ,
And ports himself a giant o'er our heads .
Pem
Ha , so ! This wedge of love ‘ twixt you and Henry
Quite thrusts you out .
Win
True , sir , but I 've in mind
A plot will reach as high as Kent 's new head ,
Which , with your sworn and loyal aid , I 'll push
To fullest stature .
Pem
You have my oath , my lord .
Win
And bond more sure — your spurring need to prick
Kent 's swelling strength . But you , lord Albemarle —
The mighty Kent is brother to your wife ,
Which now may count somewhat to lift your fortunes .
Alb
And when didst see my fortunes lie so low
As need the hoisting hand of friend or kin ?
Nay , our ambitions swear us enemies !
I stand as free , my lord , as any here .
Win
Then hear my plan . You know I carry all
With the archbishop .
Pem
True . If Winchester would
Trust Canterbury to find way .
Win
Through him
We 'll call this council in the name of Rome ,
To kill the canker in the bud of peace
So lately ventured in the track of war ,
And sound abroad that on this holy day
All weapons , armor , and gross sign of blood
Shall be laid by . I will persuade the king
His dignity is touched to be so quick
To fill his purse before he says his prayers ,
And that ‘ tis wise to throw this goodly bait
To hook the common love . Now to this meeting
Let every prelate bear most righteous arms ,
And every baron look well to his sword ;
Then when the unsuspecting king appears ,
Close companied no doubt by his new earl ,
That mushroom minion we will dare accuse
And crop his power as we prize our safety .
Pem
But will not Kent oppose this swordless worship ?
Win
Nay , he 's afflicted with true piety ,
And in the addling flush of high success
Is mellow with the good love of the world .
All men are honest now ! Trust me , he 'll bait
At what his judgment yesterday had scorned .
Alb
But what have we t ’ advance with show of right
Against him ?
Win
Gualo brings the axe — although
He knows it not — that shall behead De Burgh .
Trust me , my lords , and soon you shall know more .
Alb
Work as you will , for while he is in power
We are but puppets and I dance not well .
Win
I 'll ride with Gualo , and begin our move .
Then on to Canterbury . Fare you well ,
Till morning bring our bold designs together .
Exit
Alb
How , Pembroke ? Seest the gull in this ?
Pem
It needs
No second sight , my lord . The barons ’ arms
Outnumber all the feeble prelacy .
Alb
Thinks we 'll stop with Kent when Henry stands
Defenceless ‘ fore us ? Come ! We too must ride .
Pem
Proud Poitevin ! He plots to lose his head ,
And give this land a king indeed !
Alb
My Pembroke !
Exeunt . An attendant opens the large doors , rear , lady Albemarle and the princess Margaret enter
La
Alb . What ! no one here ? We have not seen a soul
But the poor fool who brought us food and wine .
I 'll not endure it ! Are we prisoners ?
Mewed up these hours , when all about there 's stir
As Fate changed hands and rumbled destiny .
Such clattering , shifting , revel , and “ To horse ! ”
And we mope here like toothless dames that long
Have lost the world !
Att
Your ladyship , the king
Will see you here .
La
Alb . That 's better . He shall beg
My pardon . Seats herself
Mar
How canst think of things so slight
When even now your brother may be lost ?
La
Alb . I lose no kingdom with him . That 's your theme ,
And , lord , you do n't neglect it .
Mar
Walking away from herO , for word ! Surely some word has come !
La
Alb . Would I were home !
‘ Twas you , my lady , put this journey on me
With prating of my duty to my brother .
But I know why you came .
Mar
O me , you know ?
La
Alb . That does not mark me wise . A fool might guess .
Mar
O , I am lost ! Dear lady , be my friend !
La
Alb . Why such a fluttering like a lass in folly ?
The king was here , and ‘ twas mere wit in you
To follow after , making me your foil .
Mar
The king ?
La
Alb . Ay , ay , the king ! I understand
Your cry about my brother .
Mar . O !
La
Alb . Why such an “ O ! ”
As though you 'd swallow all the air i ’ the room
And kill me with vacuity .
Mar
Ah , madam !
La
Alb . You 'll not have long to wait . He 'll be here soon .
Mar
O , then you think he 's safe ?
La
Alb . I think he 's safe ? Why should he not be safe ?
Mar
Could I believe it !
La
Alb . His truest lords are with him . Albemarle
Himself is guard sufficient .
Mar
Albemarle ? He is not with your brother !
La
Alb . Brother ? Pah !
How you draw off and on , as ‘ twere a shame
To love a king !
Mar
The king ? Ah — I ——
La
Alb . You ask
If he is safe , and I say safe enough ,
Then drops the curtain of your modesty ,
And you cry of my brother . Faith , you 'll have
Me set about with this till I believe
My brother is the king of England !
Mar . O ,
I 'm wretched , wretched !
La
Alb . Patience ! He 'll be here .
True , ‘ tis most beggarly of him to lag ,
But do not doubt he 'll come .
Mar
He will not come . O , never , never , never !
La
Alb . Foolish lass ! He can not stay away from you — his wife . I might as well be out with ‘ t soon as late .
Mar
O , lady — countess — if you e'er had need
Of gentle friends ——
La
Alb . I know not what to do
With this strange piece of daintiness . Up , mistress !
How will you blush when Henry calls you wife ,
If I , in play , can throw you on your knees ?
Mar
Henry ? God pity me ! I am so racked !
La
Alb . Thou art a fool ! Up , girl , there 's some one comes .
If ‘ t be the king ! Quick now , and smooth your face .
If he should wonder at this trace of tears ,
I 'll tell him why you wept .
Mar
You could not be
So cruel !
La
Alb . Cruel ? How ? ‘ Twill please him well
To hear you wept for him .
Mar
For him ?
Enter attendant
Att
The king .
La
Alb . Now , now , be still . He comes .
Enter Henry
Hen
My duty to
My fair and honored guests . And my first suit
Is for your pardon that I come so late ;
My next is still for pardon I must haste
Unto my third , and pray the lady Margaret
For word with her alone .
La
Alb . I will withdraw ,
My lord .
Hen
To attendantsAttend the countess .
Mar
O ! dear Heaven !
Hen
Are you at prayers , sweet lady ?
Mar
Say I am ,
Can women pray too much , who need so oft
The soft protection of the holy skies ?
Hen
Have I been slack in care ? Ah , Margaret ,
Let youth excuse neglect the past may know .
In future ——
Mar
O , thou hast been all I wish !
Hen
All ? All , Margaret ? You 've been in England
Ten years or more , and understand , I think ,
Why you , a child , were sent unto our court .
Mar
My lord , when peace was made with Scotland 's king ,
I was included in the arbitrament ,
But am uncertain of the precise terms ,
Though I dare think there was no mention made
Of marriage .
Hen
There was a dowry paid
To English coffers .
Mar
Dowry ? Ah , was ‘ t not
A dainty serving of too humble pie ?
Mere specious covering for indemnity
Proud Scotland would not pay by such a name ?
Hen
May be , but ‘ twas held wise to join the kingdoms
By current of our blood .
Mar
True at that time
‘ Twas best for England to make closer ties
Wi ’ the north , but now is Scotland on her knees ,
And you have naught to fear if you should choose
To set aside my claim .
Hen
The people 's eyes
Are on you as their queen .
Mar
They will approve
As readily if you make other choice .
Hen
Then ‘ t seems we both are free to follow love
In any court we please .
Mar
In truth , my lord !
Hen
And you reject me ?
Mar
I am not so bold ——
Hen
But , lady , in the world 's mouth you will be
My cast off love , for who is there so wise
As to believe you would refuse a king ?
Mar
I care not , sir ! What is the world to me ? O , let it think as ‘ twill , if only ——
Hen
Ah ,
If only you are saved from me ? But , madam ,
I can not flip the world away as you .
It is my field of tourney where I joust
For fame and tender reputation .
I must not let men point to you and say
“ See Henry 's fool ! ” You shall be wed at once
Unto the lord most powerful in England
Who yet is free .
Mar
O , sir ——
Hen
The earl of Kent .
Mar
Your majesty , be merciful !
Hen
I am .
Mar
My knees were bending to you thankfully ,
But you have changed their purpose to a prayer
For veriest pity . The earl of Kent , my lord ?
An old , fierce man , who scorns the name of love ?
Hen
To you he will be kind . I 'll stake my crown ,
Once wed to him you 'll thank me for this day ,
And swear you 'd choose him yours from all the world .
He 's in the castle now . I 'll send him here ,
For I 'm in haste to bring the marriage on .
Wait here , sweet Margaret .
Opens doors rear , and she passes slowly through
Mar
Kill me , my lord !
Hen
Now , by these tears , you 'll live to bless me yet ,
For from my heart I swear you 're better wed
Than if you chose the king . Closes doors and calls attendant
Ho , there !
Enter attendant ] I 'll see The earl of Kent . Bid him come in . Exit attendant ] ‘ Tis cruel , But right they should be punished who forgot A king to please themselves . Enter Hubert
Hub
Your majesty !
Hen
How now , my chancellor ? Methinks this day
Should mark the high note of thy singing heart .
But thou art gloomy , as weighing still thy chance
Against the flocking French . Canst not be merry
If Henry bids thee , Hubert ?
Hub
Ah , my lord ,
I little thought to have escaped the foe .
Hen
Is that to grieve on , man ? By Heaven , I 'll think
It would have pleased you better to have sunk
My fleet and not the enemy 's . Come , come !
What think you of the fortune we 've assigned you ?
Art satisfied ?
Hub
O , ‘ tis not to be borne !
Hen
I ’ faith , thou ‘ rt plain .
Hub
O , dear my liege , I mean ——
Hen
Well , sir , I have another blessing for thee
May prove more welcome . How wouldst like a wife
Of royal blood ? I will not tell her name ,
But take my word that were my heart not bound
I 'd look her way for fetters . She is fair ,
Ay , perfect as the lily plucked to grace
A Lord 's day altar , yet is proud enough
To hold your new-dropped dignities above
The mire and brambles of the common way ;
And all this , sir , shall be your wedded wife .
Hub
My lord ——
Hen
Nay , do not thank me . Ah , at last
I 've touched the key of gratitude . Indeed ,
My Hubert , you are pale with this new joy .
I almost , fear to tell you she is there —
Within that room — and waiting your approach .
Hub
My royal lord — I beg ——
Hen
No , not a word
Of thanks .
Hub
Not thanks ! There 's something else to say !
Hen
What , sir ? Wouldst still play hang-lip at thy fortune ?
Hub
Hear me , your majesty !
Hen
Nay , I will speak .
Sir , I have done what monarchs seldom do ,
Proclaimed my general worthy of his hire ,
And paid it , too , and these sour looks from you
Are as the poisonous leaves in a fair garland
Marking it for decay . I 've yielded much
Unto your noble merit , but no more
Will yield to your proud humor !
Hub
Hear , my lord ——
Hen
No words ! There is the door . Go in and find
The lady that must be your wife , or down
Come all your brave new honors to the ground !
Opens door and forces him through . Margaret is lying on the floor , her face hidden
Hub
O , Heaven ! ‘ Tis Margaret !
Mar
O ! Leaps up , gazes at Hubert and runs to his arms
Hubert ,
Hubert !
The king closes the doors upon them
Hen
The midnight 's past . I must away to Glaia ,
And by the sunrise at her window sing .
My lords are set toward London . None shall know ,
Save Cupid 's self , how far I ride to-night . Curtain
ACT IV
SCENE 1 . Near the cottage in Greenot woods . Henry , with lute , singing . Ope , throw ope thy bower door , And come thou forth , my sweet ! ‘ Tis morn , the watch of love is o'er , And mating hearts should meet . The stars have fled and left their grace In every blossom 's lifted face , And gentle shadows fleck the light With tender memories of the night . Sweet , there 's a door to every shrine ; Wilt thou , as morning , open thine ? Hark ! now the lark has met the clouds , And rains his sheer melodious flood ; The green earth casts her mystic shrouds To meet the flaming god ! Alas , for me there is no dawn If Glaia come not with the sun .
Ope , throw ope thy bower door , And come thou forth , my sweet ! ‘ Tis morn , the watch of love is o'er , And mating hearts should meet
The stars have fled and left their grace
In every blossom 's lifted face ,
And gentle shadows fleck the light
With tender memories of the night .
Sweet , there 's a door to every shrine ;
Wilt thou , as morning , open thine ?
Hark ! now the lark has met the clouds ,
And rains his sheer melodious flood ;
The green earth casts her mystic shrouds
To meet the flaming god !
Alas , for me there is no dawn
If Glaia come not with the sun .
Enter Glaia . The king kneels as she approaches
Gla
‘ Tis you !
Hen
Leaping up
Pardoned ! Queen of this bowerland ,
Your glad eyes tell me that I have not sinned .
Gla
How cam'st thou here ? Now who plays Hubert false ?
Nay , I 'm too glad thou ‘ rt come to question so .
‘ Tis easy to forgive the treachery
That opes our gates to angels .
Hen
O , I 'm loved ?
Gla
Yes , Henry . All the morn I 've thought of you ,
And I rose early , for I love to say
Good-by to my dear stars ; they seem so wan
And loath to go away , as though they know
The fickle world is thinking of the sun ,
And all their gentle service of the night
Is quite forgot .
Hen
And what didst think of me ?
Gla
That could you come and see this beauteous wood ,
Fair with Spring 's love and morning 's kiss of grace ,
You 'd be content to live awhile with me ,
Leave war 's red step to follow living May
Passing to pour her veins ’ immortal flood
To each decaying root ; and rest by springs
Where waters run to sounds less rude than song ,
And hiding sibyls stir sweet prophecies .
Hen
The only springs I seek are in your eyes
That nourish all the desert of myself .
Drop here , O , Glaia , thy transforming dews ,
And start fair summer in this waste of me !
Gla
Poor Henry ! What dost know of me to love ?
Hen
See yon light cloud half-kirtled with faint rose ?
What do I know of it but that ‘ tis fair ?
And yet I dream ‘ twas born of flower dews
And goes to some sweet country of the sky .
So cloud-like dost thou move before my love ,
From beauty coming that I may not see ,
To beauty going that I can but dream .
O , love me , Glaia ! Give to me this hand ,
This miracle of warm , unmelting snow ,
This lily bit of thee that in my clasp
Lies like a dove in all too rude a cote —
Wee heaven-cloud to drop on monarch brows
And smooth the ridgy traces of a crown !
Rich me with this , and I 'll not fear to dare
The darkest shadow of defeat that broods
O'er sceptres and unfriended kings .
Gla
Why talk
Of crowns and kings ? This is our home , dear Henry .
For if you love me you will stay with me .
Hen
Ah , blest to be here , and from morning 's top
Review the sunny graces of the world ,
Plucking the smilingest to dearer love ,
Until the heart becomes the root and spring
Of hopes as natural and as simply sweet
As these bright children of the wedded sun
And dewy earth !
Gla
I knew you 'd stay , my brother ! You 'll live with me !
Hen
But there 's a world not this ,
O'erhYpppHeNroofed and fretted by ambition 's arch ,
Whose sun is power and whose rains are blood ,
Whose iris bow is the small golden hoop
That rims the forehead of a king ,— a world
Where trampling armies and sedition 's march
Cut off the flowers of descanting love
Ere they may sing their perfect word to man ,
And the rank weeds of envies , jealousies ,
Push up each night from day 's hot-beaten paths ——
Gla
O , do not tell me , do not think of it !
Hen
I must . There is my world , and there my life
Must grow to gracious end , if so it can .
If thou wouldst come , my living periapt ,
With virtue 's gentle legend overwrit ,
I should not fail , nor would this flower cheek ,
Pure lily cloister of a praying rose ,
E'er know the stain of one despoiling tear
Shed for me graceless . Will you come , my Glaia ?
Gla
Into that world ? No , thou shall stay with me .
Here you shall be a king , not serve one . Ah ,
The whispering winds do never counsel false ,
And senatorial trees droop not their state
To tribe and treachery . Nature 's self shall be
Your minister , the seasons your envoys
And high ambassadors , bearing from His court
The mortal olive of immortal love .
Hen
To man my life belongs . Hope not , dear Glaia ,
To bind me here ; and if you love me true ,
You will not ask me where I go or stay ,
But that your feet may stay or go with mine .
Let not a nay unsweet those tender lips
That all their life have ripened for this kiss . Kisses her
O ruby purities ! I would not give
Their chaste extravagance for fruits Iran
Stored with the honey of a thousand suns
Through the slow measure of as many years !
Gla
Do brothers talk like that ?
Hen
I think not , sweet .
Gla
But you will be my brother ?
Hen
We shall see .
Gla
And you will stay with me ? No ? Ah , I fear
All that you love in me is born of these
Wild innocences that I live among ,
And far from here , all such sweet value lost ,
I 'll be as others are in your mad world ,
Or wither mortally , even as the sprig
A moment gone so pertly trimmed this bough .
Let us stay here , my Henry . We shall be
Dear playmates ever , never growing old ,—
Or if we do ‘ twill be at such a pace
Time will grow weary chiding , leaving us
To come at will .
Hen
No , Glaia . Even now
I must be gone . I came for this — to say
I 'd come again , and bid you watch for me .
