A tear ? O , love ! One moment , then away !
Exeunt . Curtain

div.head: SCENE 2 . A street in London . Citizens , friars , priests , pass in

stage.stage: devout manner , some bearing crucifixes .

sp.speaker: First Cit
sp.p: A day , a day , O , such a day !

sp.speaker: Second Cit
sp.p: ‘ Twill make a new page in our chronicles , the like ne'er read before .

sp.speaker: Third Cit
sp.p: Nay , when Saxon Edward came back from conquered Wales ——

sp.speaker: Fourth Cit
sp.p: Ay , ‘ twas such a day of holy joy !

sp.speaker: Second Cit
sp.p: But not so general .

sp.speaker: First Cit
sp.p: And guards with arms kept order in the streets .

sp.speaker: Third Cit
sp.p: But now there 's no authority abroad save that comes from our hearts . Surely the air is charged with drug of peace , and all men breathe it .

sp.speaker: First Cit
sp.p: Where meets the council ? In the Tower chamber ?

sp.speaker: Third Cit
sp.p: Nay , at Westminster palace .

sp.speaker: Second Cit
sp.p: That 's three miles . We must push on if we would see them enter .They move off

lg.l: How meanly does it speak for this proud world
That when the devil lays his weapons by
And peace and love for one day reign o'er all ,
That it should wonder at itself , and cry
“ A miracle ! ”
In holy Edward 's time ,
The nuns of Beda joined the council in
Concerted praise , for ‘ twas their prayerful fast
Kept Heaven with the king and gave us Wales ;
And ‘ twas decreed that ever on such days
The nuns from this most blest and ancient abbey
Should with the great assembly kneel in praise .
And so they do this day . The legate , Gualo ,
Sent invitation from the king .

sp.speaker: Second Friar
sp.p: The king ? This shows most well in him .

lg.l: If we haste on ,
We 'll see the sisters passing toward the palace .

sp.speaker: Second friar
sp.p: Let 's forward then . God save so good a king !

div.stage: Exeunt . Curtain

div.head: SCENE 3 . The great hall in Westminster . Barons and prelates

stage.stage: assembled . Rich surcoats open , revealing arms . Enter Henry and the earl of Kent .

lg.l: My lords , is this the faith you keep with kings ?
Then Heaven save me from it ! Was ‘ t not your will
This day all arms should hang upon the wall ?
Yet you come here as though the trump had called
To sudden battle .
Hear , your majesty ,
The cause for which we laid upon our souls
This seeming perjury , and you 'll forgive
As Heaven , calling it no stain .
Sir , let
The movers of this saintly shift speak first .
You , Winchester ? You , Albemarle ? Canst preach
The lie away ?
My honored liege , these swords ,
Surer than bended knees , bespeak your safety .
Knowing that treachery oft defames the ranks
Of those who shine as the highpriests of God ,
I and my brother barons came thus armed ,
Thinking it better so to break our oaths
Than that false hands should break your kingly staff .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: For my protection then you do offend ?

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: For that alone , my liege , we wear this armor .

lg.l: And you , lord bishop , guardian of our person
By prayer and Heavenly counsel ,— who even in war
Should wear no sword but that of righteousness ,—
Confess you with these warlike blades thy Lord
Unable to defend his own ?
My liege ,
‘ Tis in His name , to work His equal justice ,
We bear these weapons , sacred by our cause .

div.stage: Enter Gualo

lg.l: Your majesty , the nuns of Beda 's abbey
Would enter now .

sp.speaker: Cant
sp.p: The nuns ? What do they here ?

lg.l: You know , your grace , since blessed Edward 's time
‘ T has been their privilege on days of prayer
To join their voices with the court and state .

sp.speaker: Cant
sp.p: A privilege , but never yet in practice .

lg.l: The more is England 's shame that has not seen
For so long past a day of general prayer
And utter peace . Not in our time , nor John 's ,
Nor Richard 's ‘ fore him , nay , nor greater Henry 's ,
Might Beda 's sisters claim this privilege .
Lord Cardinal , bid them in .
Nay , nay , my liege ,
This is no place for women .
Are they not
Forever foremost in both prayer and peace ?
By Heaven 's King , they 've more right here than we !

div.stage: Enter nuns , led by the abbess , who kneels before the king

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Rise , holy abbess .

lg.l: Sovereign of England ,
May Heaven 's Sovereign protect thy youth !
And as thy hand is on thy sceptre laid
Feel there the Hand invisible from whence
Thy power comes , and know thy way as His .

div.stage: Henry bows his head . The abbess and nuns pass to a station apart and kneel

lg.l: Say on , lord bishop . Let us hear how priests
May break an oath and Heaven smile upon it .
These papers , dearest liege , are warrant for us .
There is one here so steeped in guilt , the pope
Commands his sentence by our Spiritual Court ;
And knowing crime so deep makes fierce defence ,
We came thus armed .
Who of my subjects is so basely given
The pope must urge the sword of justice ‘ gainst him ?

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: He is so high in your esteem , my liege ——

lg.l: Now were he next ourself , our very love ,
Excepting one , the noble earl of Kent ,
Whom only calumny dare censure , we
Should yield him to thee .
So ? Then we did well
To wear these arms , for ‘ tis no less than Kent
Whom we accuse .
Kent ? Ha ! We 'll hear your tale
That we may laugh at it .
You 'll sooner weep ,
I fear . The princess Adelais , of France ,
Is free of the infliction that impaired
Her noble mind , and through the pope makes suit
For the recovery of a son — her child
And the great Henry 's . Gualo brings this letter ,
Beneath the pope 's own seal , to England 's primate ,
His grace of Canterbury . It is signed
By Geoffrey de Burgh , the father of your Kent ,
And written five years back to Adelais ,
In care of ‘ s Holiness , with the request
That it be given her should she recover .
The purport is — her child has lived to be
A grace to manhood , but that he himself
Approaches death , and from his worthy son ,
Hubert de Burgh , she may in proper time
Learn all a mother 's heart would know .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Well plotted !

lg.l: And here 's another paper that great Pembroke ,
Dying , laid in my hands . It bears the seal
Of Henry Second , and tells how his son
And Adelais ’ is given to the charge
Of Geoffrey de Burgh , lord keeper of the Tower
And Dover Castle .
Keep your paper , sir !
Dost think that I 'll believe these parchment tales
Of one whose stainless past the world may read ?
That precious past , sire , is the bed whereon
This deed 's embossed . All he has done that 's noble
Now serves to make this foul . Look at him now !
He has no word , but stands as one made stiff
By sin 's confrontment .
Rather like the god
Was caught ‘ twixt the burning and the frozen worlds ,
For so my too-warm love and your deep hate
Engulf him .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: Hear the end , my liege .

lg.l: Go on ,
If there 's an end .
This says that Henry 's son ,
Arrived at thirty years , shall take his place
‘ Mong English nobles as the Duke of Bedford ,
And hold in fief five castles , herein named
Rockingham , Harle , Beham and Fotheringay ,
With strongest Bedford as his ducal seat ;
But if the child should die , his great estate
Shall to the church , and in the church 's name
I call De Burgh to show the heir , or prove
That he is dead and by no hidden means .
The devil , sir , must pay you bounteous hire ,
You sweat so in his service . Naught I know
Of ghostly Bedford , or ever heard of him ,
Or that my father held a ward in charge .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: We know you innocent .

lg.l: Then let him prove
His claim to these five castles . Two he holds ,
And three were given in dowry with his sister
When she became the wife of Albemarle .
These must he yield , or show that Bedford lives ,
Else will the church by force possess its own .
Mad Winchester ! You plot too heavy here .
You know there are no stronger forts in England
Than these three castles that the countess brought me .
And you 'd command their strength in wars against
The power of the barons ! Yield these forts ?
Not while I 've breath to fight for what 's my own !
Geoffrey de Burgh received them from great Henry
For secret , valiant service , such as knights
Have rarely given kings . Talk you of force ?
My sword shall answer you . I will not yield ,
And here declare a war ! What say you , barons ?

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: Your cause is ours , and here we draw our swords !

lg.l: You hear , lord bishop . Moreover we must take
The person of the king , nor longer risk
His majesty with traitors . Come , my liege .

sp.speaker: Cant
sp.p: What ! Take the king ?

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: Ay , take the king !

lg.l: While grace
In Heaven lives , we 'll keep him from your clutch !
While we are barons and can lift a sword ,
We will defy you and protect the king !
I am a monarch , and will go or stay
As I do please . Lord barons , not with you .

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: Ah , must we force you , sir ?

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: Not from our hands !

lg.l: An you do stir , my lord of Winchester ,
We 'll wash these floors with blood !

sp.speaker: Cant
sp.p: The king is ours !

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: Swords write our title ! Strike , my friends !

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: God , no !

lg.l: Stay , Albemarle ! We do not well to waste
The life of England . If we yield the king ,
Will you give up the castles ?

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: To AlbemarleSay you will . The king once ours we 'll keep the castles , too .

lg.l: Then rest it there . Give us the king , and take
The castles .
If you can . Ay , there 'll be wars
Will make each stone of England mine . The rocks
And cliffs I 'll mark with name of Albemarle !
Think not I risk your dear and royal life .
I 'll call out troops till trees do seem to walk
And cry for God and Henry !
To your care
We yield the king .

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: Then , Henry , come with us .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Plain Henry , now thy crown is gilt

lg.l: We 'll put
No pressure on your liberty save that
We must t ’ enforce our charter rights .
De Burgh
Must to the Tower , there to await our judgment .
Lords Goly and De Vere , conduct him thither .

sp.speaker: Goly
sp.p: Come , sir . You will not move ?

lg.l: O , Margaret ,
Your love divined too well ! Now for the sword
You bade me bring , and he who first should lay
A hand upon me ——

sp.speaker: De Vere
sp.p: Come !

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: To the kingAnd you with us .

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: Hark , lamb , the wolves are at thee !

sp.speaker: Goly
sp.p: Must we move you ?

lg.l: Off with your hands , in warrior
Michael 's name !
Touch not De Burgh ! And you — lord barons — you
Who blow the gentle fires of this new peace
With wind of your hot tempers — free the king ,
And wait as fathers on his tender years !

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: I said , my lords , we should have prating here .

lg.l: The midnight vision and long hours of prayer
Give us strange powers , and we see thoughts burn
In your intent would strike their fire against
The stars of war and light disaster o'er
A shuddering world . But you ——

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: Back to your beads !

lg.l: We 'll count our heads in your fast dropping blood !
Wouldst try our swords and see if they be keen ?
And if you scorn mine in a woman 's hand ,
Here is the hand shall bear it to your woe .

div.stage: Takes sword from under her cloak and gives it to Kent . All the nuns rise , drop their cloaks and show themselves to be armed men . The abbess throws off her hood and stands revealed as Margaret

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: My guards !

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: My soldiers !

lg.l: Kent will not to Tower
While Margaret of Scotland is his wife .
Princess , the day is yours , and I , for one ,
Thank Heaven ‘ tis so .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: And I .

lg.l: Contentious lords ,
Forget one hour that ye are baron-peers ,
And churchmen clambering to the pinnacle
Topped with a cardinal 's cap . Think ye are men
Of England , whose dear duty is to her ,
And swear ye brothers as ye are her sons .
Down on your knees ! Ask pardon of your king !
O , sovereign liege , in all I said and did
My conscience led me and my God did counsel .
If ‘ tis a sin to seek the punishment
Of one whom we believe has wronged your blood ,
Then have we sinned indeed .
Wilt swear to drop
This charge ‘ gainst noble Kent , whose honest soul
Will cloak such guilt when north winds blow their frost
From bosom of the sun ?
I swear , my lord ,
That your own lips shall be the first to make
Renewal of this charge .
Rise , Winchester .
You are forgiven , but not yet may take
Your old place in our heart .
Were thoughts of men
Writ on the heart 's red walls , this sword , my liege ,
Should open mine that you might read me clear
Of all intent save truest care for thee .
And I , my king , sought but the good of England
In all too harshly crying for the rights
Of your long loyal barons .
Rise , my lords .
We hold you not attainted , but awhile
Must look with careful coldness on your love ,
Till by your lives we test this swift repentance .
O sovereign merciful , we ask no more
Than thus to prove us true .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Now let this day Be given as we intended , to His praise Whose eye doth search the closet of the dark As freely as the dayplains of the sun , And reads the minds of men where kings must trust .CurtainLORDS AND LOVERS PART II CHARACTERS OF THE PLAY HENRY III , King of England EARL OF KENT EARL OF ALBEMARLE EARL OF PEMBROKE ARCHBISHOP OF CANTERBURY BISHOP OF WINCHESTER LORD WYNNE COUNT DE ROUILLET , attending Adelais STEPHEN GODFREY , a soldier ORSON , a servant to Glaia ADELAIS , a princess of France MARGARET , wife of Kent ELEANOR , wife of Albemarle GLAIA , ward of Kent ELDRA , servant to Glaia Lords and ladies of the court , barons , prelates , guards , attendants , & c .

div.stage: TIME : 13th Century SCENE : England ACT I

div.head: SCENE 1 . Autumn in Greenot woods near Glaia 's cottage . Table ,

stage.stage: seats , mugs and ale . Enter Eldra with a plate of cakes .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Putting plate on tableIt 's the very day and hour he 'll be coming , and he 's not the man to count leaves by the roadside . He likes my cookin ’ , as I 've had proof , and he looks so cunnin ’ at me lately I could swear he was fallin ’ in love all over again . And I 'm picking up my looks , I must say . Ay , there 's nothin ’ like a soft tongue for keepin ’ a woman young . I feel ‘ most like a lassie , though he did say some words at first that made my heart sore , not knowing me after ten years away . And he 's that handsome yet ,— since he 's shaved off the beard that got so between us I did n't know my own good man that married me in Dummerlie kirk on as sweet a Sunday morn as you ever see , and the priest in a new frock from Wappington , as the housekeeper told me herself — La , I forgot my lady !

div.stage: Runs out . Stephen steps from behind a shrub

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: So , mistress , you 've known me all the time , have you ? And me playin ’ the fool courtin ’ my own wife that was ready to jump into my arms at the drop o ’ a hat ! But I 'll play you a game , my lady !

div.stage: Re-enter Eldra

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: O , Mr. Stephen !

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Ho , Madam Prune-face ! A sweet mornin ’ , now ai n't it , but a bit briskish as suits the season .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Prune-face ! By my lady 's glass , I 've not a wrinkle yet as big as the hair on a bat 's wing ! Plague take the eyes o ’ him that says it as should n't !

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Well , well , I meant no harm , but mickle it takes to pinch a bruise . I brought a message to your lady from Sir Roland ——

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Sir Roland ? He 's a lord now ——

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Ay , ‘ tween the king and Hubert they 've made him a lord .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Hubert ! You mean his grace , the earl of Kent ?

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: He 's still my friend , Meggy . The earldom is nothing between Hubert and old friends . And I 'm a-climbing too . I 've had an advancement , which I do n't mind telling you about , but I 'll have a bit o ’ your brew first and a dozen or so o ’ them cakes , seein ’ you took the trouble . I could never disappoint a woman as had put herself out for me .Sits at table

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Pouring aleIt has been a long stretch since you were this way , sir .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Eh ? Has it ? Well , I do n't wonder you think so in this sort o ’ a place . Not much goin ’ or comin ’ round here ! But time do n't hang wi ’ Stephen . There 's ridin ’ and fightin ’ an ’ the lassies to comfort ——

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: I thought you were honest . You 've bragged enough !

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: As honest as a soldier , my dear ,— and that ought to content any woman .Eldra sits at tableYes , sit if you like . I 'm not overproud , though your place is behind a man o ’ my rank when he 's at table . I know I 've eaten wi ’ you and drunk wi ’ you , but I 've had an advancement , Meggy , I 've had an advancement .Takes sip of ale and puts it downCostmary ! Well , let ‘ em as likes it drink it .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: ‘ Tis nice and balsamy . I thought you 'd like it , and saved it o ’ purpose .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Dose me wi ’ tansy and be done !

div.stage: Eldra turns her head to wipe away a tear and Stephen gulps the ale

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Bites a cake and puts it downPoh !

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Do n't you like it ?

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: If I do n't mind a lie for manners ’ sake , I do , but if I 've more respect for truth than manners , I do n't . Ai n't your hand a little out ?

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: I thought they were extra nice , sir . I 'm sure they rose like feathers .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: And may blow away for me ! But come , do n't hang your head , Meggy . You 're too old for that .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: My name is Eldra , sir .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: I know , I know , but I told you that was the name o ’ my dear lass that 's dead and gone ——

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Dead and gone ?

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: That 's what I said . If she ai n't dead , she 's where I can n't get her , which is all the same to a soldier , so I 've about made up my mind to give over lookin ’ for her . Lord , do n't cry , little chicken ! You are a soft one . Cryin ’ to think I 've lost such a jewel o ’ a lass , but I 'll tell you something to make you think better of it . There is somebody up in old Scotland that I think I 'll fetch down for the comfort o ’ Stephen — as bonny a woman as a man need want , wi ’ enough siller laid up from her old daddy to make a soldier a gentleman . Lizzie o ’ Logan ——

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Oh-h !

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: The qualms again ? Now devil take a woman as gets queasy just when a man wants to be friendly and talk things over .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: AsideLiz o ’ Logan ! My cousin as was always jealous and wanted my Stephen !

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Hey , Meggy !She runs out , leftHa , ha , ha ! Poor little woman ! I 'm a villain . I 'm twenty villains .Eldra steals back unseen and hears himTo treat my bonny sweet wife so ! The cunningest darling that ever said yes to a soldier ! I 'll make it all right when she comes back , and wo n't there be a smackin ’ o ’ lips !Eldra makes signs of joy and revenge and disappearsWhere has she gone ? Run off to cry her sweet eyes out , I 'll warrant ! I 'll go find her .

div.stage: Exit , left . Eldra and Orson come on , rear

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: O , is it true ? My faithful heart is blest at last ? My rival indeed vanquished ? And I — I am your adored one ?

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Yes , but do n't be a bigger fool than you can help .

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: Fool , ma'am ?

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: There , there , I mean do n't forget that you are a man of dignity ——

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: Ah ! Do n't trouble yourself .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: And cosset me before folks , like a bumpkin with his first lass .

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: I 'll be patient — before company . Though I should just like to show that man of blood what my rights are now . But you mean it , Eldra ? This is not another jade 's trick ?

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: ‘ Tis true — always barring that my man do n't come back to claim me .

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: The fishes keep him !Re-enter StephenAh !

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Whispers sweetly to Orson , then discovers StephenO , here he is ! Now , Orson , I know you 'll be friends wi ’ Mr. Stephen . Just to please me now . You see , sir , Orson 's been courtin ’ me many a year , and I had just about give in like a weak woman , when you came and got me all upset somehow , lookin ’ so much like my man who was drowned at sea , an ’ his own name too . I did lose my head so at times I could ‘ a ’ sworn you were my very man , but what you said about Liz o ’ Logan brought me to my right mind again , and Orson is willing to make up , and I 'm sure we can all be friends , only me and Orson wo n't be presumin ’ , an ’ shame take me to think I ever looked so high as a king 's man wi ’ an advancement — though Orson is a man of dignity now — and — sit down , Orson !Sits at table and pours ale for herself and OrsonWe take a snip together about this time every mornin ’ . Orson 's got no quarrel with the ale cost , and he does love my raisin ’ o ’ bread and cake .

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: And who does n't let him starve in a ditch ! We do n't ask you to sit , Mister Stephen . We know our place , and hope you know yours .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Ay , a king 's man must keep his head high .

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: High , my love ?

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: I mean with an advancement .

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: ‘ Tis well . You know me , Eldra .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: I hope I do , Orson .

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: And you must own , my dear , that you came to your right mind in very good time .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: I 'm reasonably thankful , Orson . I know what it is to be a soldier 's wife .

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: They lie not between linen , I warrant you .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Linen ? An they get muslin without begging it , they may thank fortune !

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: With never a silk smock for the fair .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Silk smock ? An a new one comes before the old one drops off they may say their prayers for it !

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: But we 'll be snug enough , my dear .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: That we will !

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: And winter coming on . Ah !

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: True enough .

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: A good fire .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Yes , my love .

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: A little mulled sack , if the night be wet .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Indeed , my dear ! And a hot posset for your cold , curdled with sweet wine .

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: Humph ! A little tart , I beg you , to give it spice .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Well , our tastes wo n't quarrel . I know a wife 's place .

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: By my life , you do ! O , ‘ tis a merry day ! Would I were not a man of dignity now !Pats her

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Orson !

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: I mean — O , come ! ‘ Tis a merry day ! Give us a song , mister soldier !

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: I 'll give you the devil !

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: How , sir ? You seem disturbed . Perhaps your reflections are not so happy as mine . It may be your mistress has not such an adoring and adorable eye — can not feast you with her cheeks —kisses Eldra— regale you with her lips —kisses her

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Scoundrel ! Kiss my wife ?Takes him by collar and throws him aside

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: My Stephen !

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: My Eldra !

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Running to his armsI knew it was you !

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: I knew it was you !

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Why did n't you tell me ?

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Why did n't you tell me ?

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: As a man of dignity now , I should like to ask why you did n't tell me !

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Dancing up and down stage with EldraAy , Orson , ‘ tis a merry day ! Come , come ! Here 's a good ale for all . To you , Orson !DrinksAnd let the song go ‘ round !All singHo , Autumn time , O , Autumn time , When every wind is jolly , And pip and pear drop in their prime For tooth of fun and folly ! When Hobnail 's store is ripe for raids , And grapes go to the pressing , And apple checks are like a maid 's When Jack would be a-kissing ! Ho , hips and haws for vagabonds , With russets for who 'll dare , And hazels by the meadow ponds , Brown-sweet for barefoot 's fare ! The pettychaps beflit the larch , The rocks from barn-top scold , And summer rogues are on the march For quarters ‘ gainst the cold . Ho , Autumn time , O , Autumn time ! When every wind is jolly , And pip and pear drop in their prime For tooth of fun and folly !

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Hist ! My lady is coming with her knight .

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: What knight ? Nobody should be coming here but the earl of Kent and my lord of Wynne . Come , lass , what knight ?

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: O , now it 's out , you must be as mum as a dumb man 's grave . My lady has a lover , and a sweet young knight he is , too , who rides out every week just for a peep at her . List ! You can hear them now , just over the hedge .

lg.l: And the master does n't know ! By Heaven , the man 's a villain , and
I 'm a traitor to my lord of Kent if I do n't wring his neck !

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Stephen ! Stephen !

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: Hold , sir !

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Off with you ! I 'd drag him out an ‘ twere the king himself !Leaps through the hedge and pulls the king throughGod 's mercy ! I am dead ! It is the king !

div.stage: All kneel to the king . Glaia comes through the hedge

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: The king ?

lg.l: ‘ Tis true . I am that wretched man ,
Your sovereign .
Kneel to a woman ! Nay ,
Not Stephen !

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Speak , sweet , and say that I 'm forgiven !

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: My Henry I 'll forgive , but not the king .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: No pity for the king ? O , take him , too , Fair Glaia , crown and all !RisesLook not away , Nor down , nor up , nor anywhere but here . Say thou'lt forgive , we 'll instantly to court , For there 's a spirit sits within this hour , Like silent wisdom in a lovely face , That gives me confidence . We 'll to the court ! I know thou art a maid of noble blood . For thou'rt indexed with rank 's unerring sign , And dearly limned by Nature for a queen . Weep not , my sweet , thy lover is a king , And by my soul , and these dear wildered eyes , And by the life in these blue wandering veins ,kissing her handThese azure rivers in a lily field — I 'll lift thee high as is the English throne !

div.stage: Exeunt the king and Glaia

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Now there 'll be a broil at court to please all the witches on the island .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: And ‘ twas you dropped the devil 's meat into the pot . O , woe , woe , woe ! That I should live to see my lady wed the king !

sp.speaker: Ste
sp.p: Well , worse could ‘ a ’ happened . The king might have had me hung , and it 's bad luck to be a widow twice to the same man . I 'm for the court to keep both eyes open for what sport befalls .

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Sport ? O , the poor lord of Wynne ! What will he do now ? May be ‘ tis sent on him for worshippin ’ my lady like the Holy Virgin . Sport ? O , that you should be my husband and a villain ! Up with you , Orson ! There 's work for such poor servants as we be .

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.p: Servant , ma'am ? Dost not think that this high connection of my lady 's will make me lord chamberlain to ——

sp.speaker: Eld
sp.p: Ay , thou'lt get thy right place , I hope , though it be lord footman to a donkey ! Come along with you both !

div.stage: Exeunt . Re-enter the king and Glaia

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: I can n't believe it yet , your majesty .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Nay , Henry , love . The name you gave me first . By that alone I 'll live upon your lips .

lg.l: I should be gay ,— alack , I am half sad .
A sort of music here is gone . Mayhap
I loved my brother better than the king .
Thy brother ? Call me that no more . My bride !
The sleeping angel I would kiss awake ,
For waking thou art human and can love .
Ah , Glaia , none doth know how I have dreamed ,
For kings must give up all just to be kings —
How oft at night I 've left the palace world
To find me lodging in the sweeter air
Where spirits hold their gentle pageantries ,
And meet the winds that blow from destiny
Pregnant with fortune for my famished soul ,—
While they who stood about the royal bed ,
Whose stealthful eyes held me in silken jail ,
Knew not my body lay untenanted
And they but guarded clay . And everywhere
‘ Twas thee I sought , my Glaia . When you came ,
I looked , and knew that I need dream no more .

sp.speaker: Gla
sp.p: And thou art no more sad ? I make thee happy ?

lg.l: When I am with thee ‘ tis continual Spring ,
For in my heart is such sweet jugglery
Each winter-ragged month doth put on May .
It makes me fear to be so much to thee .
O , Henry , leave me ,— leave me here a child
That never shall be woman ,— ne'er shall seek
The bitter knowledge of the human world .
lg.stage: A fawn comes to her from the wood . She fondles it
lg.l: See , brother ! I would ope no book less pure
Than these large eyes . Ah , me , was ever soul
So full of earth as mine ? I can love nothing
But woods and streams , and these unspeaking things
That reasonless may build no dream of God .
My Henry , why this fear that if I go
From this dear world I 'll come to it no more ?
Cast off the doubt — and here I trample it .
We shall come often to this home of peace .
But , Glaia , let us go . The hours run fast ,
And eve must find me at the court .
The court ?
There does my rival in my lover speak .
There speaks my enemy , for in the court
I shall find that will make these fears all plain .
Fear nothing now ! I see thou knowest how
To please me best , making me woo thee o'er
And o'er again , for naught could be more sweet !

div.stage: Exeunt . Curtain

div.head: SCENE 2 . Room in Westminster palace . The earl of Kent and

stage.stage: countess of Albemarle talking .

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: Why do you doubt ? You 've ever trusted me .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . Ay , while you were all man .

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: So am I now .

lg.l: Alb . Nay , you are one half woman , being married .
A wife 's the key may ope her husband 's heart
To all the world . She is the pick and pry
To every lock of trust , and weasels through
His secrets spite all seals . Swear , Hubert , swear
That Margaret shall not know !

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: Have I not sworn ? How many times will you demand my oath ?

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . A thousand thousand will not bring me peace !

lg.l: Ah , Eleanor , why desolate your days
With this wild fear ? ‘ Tis Heaven you 've sinned against ,
Not man . Look thou above for condemnation .
The world is harsh to virtue , not to sin .
See how the daughter of the earl of Valence ,
John 's one-time mistress , proudly holds her head ,
Nor lacks for fawning followers ? And mark
How Rosamond 's two sons have fixed their line
Fast ‘ mong our English peers . If you would dare
To bring sweet Glaia forth , I do not doubt
The court would welcome her as princess born .
Alb . But Albemarle ! He never would forgive !
Christine of Valence was not wife to him ,
Else would her mimic court be dungeon close ,
And racks , not lovers , kiss her dainty fingers .
You 've never seen his rage ! O , swear again
You 'll set securest watch on act and tongue ,
Nor let ——

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: Here is your lord with Winchester .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . O !

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: Come , I 'll satisfy you , Eleanor .

div.stage: Exeunt , right . Winchester and Albemarle enter rear

lg.l: The name of Kent erases church and state
And king . Fortune grows doting , and would make
A darling of this man .
She 'll change her love ,
Doubt not .
‘ Tis time . New favors upon him light
As birds on fruity branches . Castles and estates
Are but as feathers every wind brings in .
Dost not begin to fear him ?
You are pleasant .
I fear ? When I could lend him half my power ,
And yet o'erbear him ? In the north there are
One thousand leaders holding swords of me !

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: I 'm answered then ?

lg.l: Ay , sir . Though not from love
To Kent , nor hate to you , do I deny you .
But I 'll not stand the champion of a wanton ,
Though royal daughter of a royal sire .
The knightly Albemarles have never stooped
To lift adultery from its miry bed
And set its colors on their virtuous helm .
Now , by your leave , the half of England comes
Into the world by left hand of the priest ,
Yet fight and pray as well as you or I ,
Nor bates a jot their honor in men 's eyes .
You have my answer . When I 'm ready for ‘ t ,
I 'll tumble Kent to earth in my own fashion ,
And not by means that sets French Adelais
On virtue 's pinnacle , a star of gilt
To falsely glitter in the eye of dames
And set them wandering with their vanities
Till they forget the way to their true lords .
I 'm writing a court history , your grace .
‘ Twas John , I think , who set your countess ’ father
On fortune 's road .
Nay , ‘ twas the king before him ,
Henry the Second .
Well , my wary lord ,
I have no bruise to nurse , and meet the blow
Befalls from any point .

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: What do you say ?

lg.l: I say , my lord , I 'll strike as pleases me ,
And you keep cover as you will .

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: A bruise ? Keep cover ? Gods ! And I stood still ! The dog ! I 'll after him and take him by the throat !

div.stage: Re-enter lady Albemarle , right

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . What said our ancient enemy ?

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: Enough ! He angered me !

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . But what the cause , my lord ?

lg.l: He 'll quash the claim the church makes to my castles
If I will aid in bringing Kent to trial
On charge of Adelais , who sojourns here
To push her old appeal . I will not do ‘ t !
Alb . Thanks that you shield my brother , by whose rise
You droop .
I shield your brother ? When his name
Is Kent ? Nay , you mistake me . I refused
Because this princess was no more nor less
Than Henry Second 's mistress , and the son ,
Whose death is laid to Kent , was the vile fruit
Of wantonness . A princess ! I 'd forgive
A milkmaid false , but error in the great
Is so bestarred by its exalted place
That those beneath mistake what is so lustered
For the true sun .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . Hast seen the king , my lord ?

lg.l: I say ‘ tis guilt of such a heinous sort ,
So foully odorous and so far bestrewn ,
The sea o'errunning Britain could not wash
The island free of it !
Alb . ‘ Tis very wrong .
Alb What ! Set this princess over all your heads
As she were halo-browed , that you might pray
Her saintly patronage for your loose hopes ?

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . Indeed , it is not well .

lg.l: Well ? By my life ,
Our English dames are running mad enough ,
And must be duchesses because — look ye —
They 're wantons to a king ! Out on your kind !
“ ‘ Twas John , I think , who set your countess ’ father
On fortune 's road . ” You 've been a handsome woman —
Could foot right well on Venus ’ heels . My soul ,
There 's beauty in you yet to draw an eye
O'er the picket of defence !

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . My lord , I pray you ——

lg.l: ‘ Tis well that our young Richard has my eye ,
And trick of walk , and way of sudden speech ,
Else I 'd suspect a cuckoo in the nest ,
For all your dainty strictures and high head !

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . For Christ 's sake , Albemarle ——

lg.l: Ay , had he not
My very shoulder hitch and swelling neck
This night I 'd drag him to the eastern tower
And hurl him to the Thames !

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . My God !

lg.l: For you
I 'd pay out my estate in hire of men
To spend their lives devising drawn-out pains
That death might feed and grow upon itself !

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . Ah , sir , no need . I 'm dead now with your words .

lg.l: The king is entering . Look up , my dame .
I rage to think you could be false , and not
Because you are . Come , where 's your blood , my lady ?
Those frosted cheeks are not the royal color .
Smile and I 'll pardon you . I know you true .
But when we 're home again we 'll talk somewhat
Of those same favors granted to your father .

div.stage: Enter Pembroke , Winchester , and others . Pembroke and Winchester talk apart

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: But where is Gualo ? He is friend to Kent .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: Shipped back to Rome .

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: Well done !

lg.l: That is made sure .
And now I 'll push the claim of Adelais
With all the power pillared by the church .
Henry will never yield . He wraps the earl
So close in love ‘ twill shake the throne to part them .
There 's no path to the king not barriered
By Kent 's unceasing watch .
I 'll drop a canker
Will eat a way for us . Ah , here they come .
Arm-locked as king and king ; and eye to eye ,
Like lovers changing souls .

div.stage: Enter Henry , Kent , Lord Wynne . Lords and ladies , among whom is Margaret , enter behind them

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: To KentI fear to tell you , Hubert , even you .

lg.l: I do not fear to hear it , whate'er you do
So well becomes a throne .
You promise then
Your fullest pardon ?
Your open deeds , my lord ,
Bear such a noble front I should not fear
To clap a lusty “ ay ” to all you 've done
In secret .
Thank you , Kent . And Roland , too ,—
Our good lord Wynne — must echo you with pardon ,
For I have touched him when he felt me not ,
And shortly he must look upon his wound .
I do not fear to see it . You 've taught me , sir ,
The wounds you give me carry their own heal .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: But this is deep .

sp.speaker: Wynne
sp.p: The richer then the balm .

lg.l: Then out , poor Henry , with thy heart 's misdeed .
Listen , my lords ,— my gracious court ,— to you
I make appeal . Is any here who holds
Me in such wintry and removed regard
He would not grant my heart its choice in love ?
Your wisdom , sire , that sets the cap of age
Upon the curls of youth , gives us excuse
To bid you choose at will your royal mate .
If I speak not for all , we 'll hear dissent .
This silence warrants you to woo and speed .
That I have done , and now can show to you
This jewel of my choice that late I found
Deep hidden from the world . So fixed my love ,
I can not wait to wander through the ways
A king comes to betrothal , and shall win
Your quick assent , even now , by bringing her
To your commending eyes .

sp.speaker: A lord
sp.p: What does he mean ? Is this some princely revel ?

lg.l: It may be ,
And our part is to smile .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: To PembrokeMark you earl Kent ? He changes face .

lg.l: And his pale friend , lord Wynne ,
Turns corpse on ‘ s feet .
Ha ! Is it possible
They were not privy to this kingly move ?

div.stage: Re-enter Henry , leading Glaia

lg.l: Here , dear my lords ! Look on my choice and say
That here might come Rome 's vestals to repair
Their tapers dim . Is she not royal , friends ?
See how her eyes look bravely into yours ,
Though on her cheek a sweet timidity
Doth couch in coral . Now commend me , all !
And Hubert , earl of Kent , say whence is she ,
And what her parentage ? For all I know
Is that I found her bowered in Greenot woods .

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: My God !

lg.l: O , Hubert , muffle up the storm
Rides on your brow , and smile upon my love !

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: Believe me , sire , she can not be your wife .

lg.l: Not be my wife ? Unsay the words , dear Hubert .
You mean , perhaps , she 's humbler born than I —
The daughter of a duke — an earl — a lord —
Ay , say a knight that bravely bore his shield ,
And all the gap ‘ twixt her degree and mine
Her native graces will bridge o'er and make
Her way unto my throne .
O , king beloved ,
You must believe me ! She can not be yours !
Then , Heaven , turn foul , thou dost not shine for me !
Rise , Hubert , rise , for I must love you still ,
Though you have robbed me of the sun and stars .

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: RisesMy noblest sovereign !

lg.l: Now let me hear
Why this ne'er mated dove can not be mine ,
And I 'll attend thee patient as the dead
Do list their requiem .
Sire , I am pledged .
Such sacred oaths are warders at my lips
That angels would turn pale in Heaven to hear
Their violation .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Oaths ? We must not hear ?

lg.l: Not from my lips . It may be from another 's
In better time .
In better time ? By Heaven ,
You shall uncover here her history ,
And I myself shall say if she may be
My own or no !
Thy mercy on a man
In one hour old !

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: You are the torturer ! O , Hubert , Hubert , I am on my knees !

lg.l: Sire , give me leave to go , and take this maid ,
So long my care that I must keep her still .
Come , Glaia — child — ‘ tis Hubert takes thy hand .
My sovereign lord , I go with sorrow hence .
I would my tongue were torn from its curst root
Than speak you woe ,— but do not hope , my liege ,
Your husband hand can ever touch this maid .
The thought to ague shakes my soul !

div.stage: Exit Kent with Glaia . Margaret would follow , but is detained by lady Albemarle , who is half swooning . Winchester kneels and kisses the king 's robe

lg.l: My king ,
Thou'rt still beloved .
Ah , what canst say to one
So pinioned by distress that he must lose
His dearest friend or dearest love ?
My lord , if friendship may have leave to speak
As fits its holy bond and name ——

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: O , speak ! Say anything !

lg.l: Too long you have been wronged .
Did not Kent win by stealth the Scottish princess ,
Your promised bride ? Consorting his base blood
With royalty ?— which was his secret aim ,
And all his burning love for Margaret
But feigned and politic to gain your pity .
Again he 's at your heart ! And hopes once more
To bear himself to high success . If not ,
With face assumed and sorrowing he 'll melt
You to forgiveness .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Listen not , my liege !

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: To WinchesterIs this your comfort ?

lg.l: Sire , he slanders love
As true as God 's to men , who says my lord
Is false !
Her pride would say as much , my liege .
As for this maid ,— whom majesty might choose ,
And all the kingdom feel itself adorned ,—
She 's either heir to vast and rich estates ,
Or Kent dotes on her with such jealous love
He will not yield her even to his king .
And both these reasons , sire , I urge as one
T ’ explain his stout refusal to make known
What honesty would haste to shout aloud .
Who says that Kent , in friendship or in love ,
E'er sought his gain , doth foully lie !
This man
Is Kent 's own creature .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Ah , that 's not his sin . He loves my Glaia , and would make her his .

lg.l: Yes , sire , I love her ,— you are right so far ,—
But , sovereign lord , I would expect as soon
To pottle with an angel at an inn
As make her mine . Though Hubert spurred my suit ——

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: He favored you !

sp.speaker: Wynne
sp.p: He set no bars between us .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Ah , you could wed her — let the king go beg !

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: Away , you perked-up villain ! Out of this !

lg.l: When you come with me , sir , that I may slit
The tongue that fouls my name !
My hot-mouthed sir ,
I 'll leave his majesty to teach you better manners .
And here I do , with a ne'erhYpppHeNending lesson .
Roland de Born , so lately lord of Wynne ,
Thou'rt banished from our realms , not to return ,
Though thou shouldst live to see more years than yet
Man ever numbered his .

sp.speaker: Wynne
sp.p: Is this your will ?

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: In truth , ‘ tis nothing else !

lg.l: Then , sire , farewell .
Some men are fashioned men by circumstance —
Shaped by what wind blows on them . In their veins
The heavens croak or sing . Does the sky frown ,
They 're muddy and befouled ,— it smiles , and straight
Fair weather 's in their blood , sporting its flag
In their new countenance . Not I , my lords !
Nay , on the winds my soul shall leave its shape ,
And where I venture I am what I am ,
A knight of England , loyal to his king .

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: Death to his arrogance !

lg.l: This judgment , sire ,
Is much too modest .
Hear us now , my liege ,
For you have heard too little these months past .
My lords , I am too faint and troubled now
To understand if you be friends or foes ,
Or if the earl of Kent be false to me ;
But come , and what you choose to speak , I 'll hear .
... Glaia , art gone from me ? Ah , who would live ?
The winds of doom are sold by Lapland witches ,
Who mix the compass points and blow us foul
When we have paid our fortune to go fair .

div.stage: Exeunt Henry and lords . Lady Albemarle and Margaret are left alone

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Why do you keep me so ?

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . Where would you go ?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Where else but to my lord ?

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . You shall not go . O , stay with me ! One moment , Margaret !

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Another ? Nay , you 're better . I must go . O , Eleanor , didst hear that Winchester ? Foul murderer of honor — Hubert 's honor ! Can these be tongues of men ?... And Roland banished !

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . Canst think of him ?

lg.l: He 's Hubert 's friend . Who now
Will stand by him ?

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . You , Margaret , and I .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Yes — let me go !

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . What will you say to him ?

lg.l: Beg him not let his bitter thoughts usurp
Quite all his heart , but leave a little room
That e'er so small will make me ample heaven .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . You will not ask of Glaia ?

lg.l: Ask ? Dost think
That I must ask ?

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . He will not tell thee !

lg.l: Not ?
I am his heart . His veins run not with health
Except as I know how they course , and beat
Concordantly . Doubt not he 'll tell me all .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . He shall not tell thee !

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Madam , you are strange .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . Ay , Margaret , and strangest to myself . O , he is true ! Dear God , I know he 's true !

lg.l: Make it no question then . For by the sun ,
And heaven 's starry clock that now goes by ,
You shall not say he 's false to Margaret !
Alb . To you ? Ha ! false to you ? Dost think my thoughts
Must ever web round you ?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: GoingYou are his sister .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . What , are you gone ? Forgive me , Margaret .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Ah , you forget that I am suffering too .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . You suffer ? You ?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: You have a husband , madam .

lg.l: Alb . I have . Let me remember him . Ha , ha !
You suffer , icicle ? What do you know of pain
But as the lookers on about a pit
See one at bottom dying ? As curious eyes
Regard the writhing heretic at stake ?
Or say , as angels flying heavenward turn
To give one grudged tear unto the damned ?
That is your pain , you pure , proud Margaret !
... O , madness , seize me !
By my fears you have
No need to pray for ‘ t .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . Conscience , where dost sleep ? Let me tread by nor rouse thee .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Eleanor ?

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . Whence are those floods of fire ? O , Hubert , save me !

lg.l: Dear Eleanor , be calm . I did not think
You loved your brother so .

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Alb . What 's that you say ? Ah , yes , ‘ tis Margaret . Go to him now . Ask of this maid — then blazon all — all — all !

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Come with me , Eleanor .

lg.l: Alb . Drive home the knife
Now threats his heart !

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Come with me , come !

lg.l: Alb . ‘ Tis fit
His wife should do it !

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Come , dear Eleanor .

div.stage: Exeunt , right . Henry , Winchester , Albemarle , Pembroke , enter rear

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: We 're glad you are convinced , my lord .

lg.l: Glad , sir ?
Glad that one half my heart is mottled , foul ,
Diseased , and must be cut away , though I
Die with the cleaving ? Ay , I am convinced .
And give consent that Kent be made to answer
The charge of Adelais ?

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Be ‘ t as you please .

lg.l: ‘ Twere best to haste in this , ere all the shires
Misled in love by Kent , hear of his danger .
I have the warrant here . It lacks your seal ,
My liege .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Quickly sealing itNow it does not . Here splits my heart , And half falls with thee , Hubert .

div.stage: Winchester comforts him . Albemarle and Pembroke talk apart

lg.l: In fewest words ,
What purpose you ?
To ride at once to north ,
And through my agents stir up a rebellion
Against the king , whom we must make appear
Kent 's sole remover , for he now ‘ s become
The idol of the witless multitude ,
With whose hot sanction we may move ‘ gainst Henry
And roll his head as fast as Kent 's to hell .

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: But you must see the trial .

lg.l: So I aim .
But if I 'm blocked therein , I look to you
To keep me stationed in my feudal rights ,
And what you venture for me I 'll make good
With forty thousand men , or horse or foot .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Where is lord Wynne ? Inquire if he has gone ?

lg.l: He 'll trouble you no more , for if my servants
Be to me loyal they 've set him toward the sea .
You 're pert in my own matters . I bethought me
I would recall his sentence . He is noble ,
And I have done him wrong . Why press about me ?
Ye are devils all ! Call me the earl of Kent .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: He is not here , my lord .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Give me the warrant . Quick , sir ! I 'll have it back ! I 'll take more time !

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: ‘ Tis gone , my liege .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Gone ? Is the devil your post ?

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: We pray your pardon , sire .

lg.l: Could you not give
One little hour to old friends taking leave ,
Though one is a poor king ? Away from me !
Dear majesty , beloved above all kings ,
Let not your frown unpay again the service
Your smile even now rewarded . ‘ Tis too much ,
Howe'er we have endured , to ask our silence
While Kent doth rob thee of a fairer queen
Than ever made a court seem gaudy poor
By her rich self . Must we stand humbly back ,
That he may please his bosom with her beauty ,
And bury in his lust what forth should shine
Thine and a happy England 's constant sun ?
No doubt , my liege , we shall remove each bar
That shuts you from your love , and please ourselves
The most in pleasing you .
O , make her mine ,
And all you wish , if kings have power o'er fate .
Will come to pass . I trust you — yet — and yet —
Who can be true when Huberts are found false ?
ACT II

div.head: SCENE 1 . A room in the earl of Kent 's palace . An inner room rear ,

stage.stage: cut off by curtains . Kent alone .

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: Now , Eleanor , wilt prove thee saint , or devil ? Wilt mend this breach , or must I perish in it ? Too well I know that soul 's dark history To think it may breed light . The moment globes The years ’ full character ; a whole life 's face Peeps out in smallest deeds . Yet wonders are . And Eleanor may prove false to herself To once keep faith with Heaven .ListensGlaia ? Ay !Goes to curtains rear , parts them softly , looks within and returnsShe did not call . I 'll watch all night . ‘ Twill be No added task since there 's no sleep for me . My Margaret is safe . They dare not touch A princess of the blood . But I am down . ‘ Tis said and sung there is no greater pain Than wrenches Fortune 's nurslings when she flies . Not so . False lady of the wheel , take all ! But O , to see my king yield to the wolves Now fang-close to his heart — there is my death !Sits on a couch , his head bowed . Margaret enters , advances softly and embraces him . He looks up , returning her caressNow let the world go on , I 'll rest me here . Why should I keep my hand proud on the helm , War with the unsated surge , nor know the pause That is the spirit 's silent growing time ? Ah , Margaret , how little will content thee ? No more nor less than love and poorest me ?

lg.l: No more , my lord . Nor will aught less make full
My greedy cup . Thou wert the king 's , but now
Thou art all mine . All mine , my love ? Or is
That little “ all ” my greatest flatterer ?

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: You know my heart . Where have you been so long ?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: With Eleanor . I brought her home with me .

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: She 's here ?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Yes , Hubert . Ah , she loves you well .

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: She loves me ?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Better than you thought .

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: In sudden hopeThen ... Speak ! What has she told you ?

lg.l: Nothing . What , my lord ,
Should she have told me ?

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: DullyNothing .

lg.l: I have heard
So much of this — this nothing .
Margaret ,
Thou hast my soul . Wilt keep it true for me ?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: I keep it ? No , I doubt myself .

lg.l: Thyself ?
Then trust my trust in thee , which meets thy love
As swallows meet the waking winds of Spring
And know where life is .
Doubt or trust , I love thee !
O Hubert , let us go this night to lands
That know how to be kind and smile on lovers .
Dost hope by flying England to fly pain ,
That everywhere encircles man as fire
To shape his soul in fashion of his God ?
For love and life I beg ! Why do I say
For love and life , since there 's no life for me
Without thy love ? O , you will go with me !
Leave thy ungrateful king to wed at will ——
Leave Glaia to the king ? The thought is flame !
Mar .
Who is this maiden that you guard as she
Were the one drop of blood that in your heart
Makes living centre ? Who ?

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: After a pauseYou heard my answer .

lg.l: Ay , to the king , but not to me — thyself —
Nay more , for when thou takest away thyself ,
Though in the smallest part , so much I die ,—
And by this secret that divorces us
Am wholly slain . But tell it to me , Hubert ,
And ‘ twill become another blessed bond ,
To second union closer than the first
Re-sanctioning our souls .
lg.stage: He is silent . Her rage overcomes her
lg.l: Unseal thy lips ,
Or by the fires that flit now through my brain ,
By the ancestral wrongs within my blood
That start suspicion where there is no foe ,
I shall begin to doubt thee ! Who is she
To thee who art my husband ?
Margaret ,
Go to the maiden lying yon and look
Once more upon her vestal face , then ask
If she know aught of guilt .
lg.stage: Margaret looks silently toward the curtains

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: In subdued toneShe 's there ?

lg.l: Poor child !
I thought you 'd be her gentle , elder sister ,
And help me still her woeful flutterings .
Where 's now the proud , sure strength that made discount
Of Heaven 's arm ? O , reed-propped vanities ,
Swelling usurpful till ye seem our life ,
Ye must come down that we may find ourselves
And God .
O , take me back ! I did not know
This spirit dwelt in me . One of my race ,
A woman , long ago , stabbed through a heart
That played her false , yet she was gentle too ,
And died for what her hand had done . May be
The unquiet dead come back to live in us .
O , it was she stirred this strange passion in me .
Twas not myself . Speak to me , Hubert ! Say
‘ Twas not myself .

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: Embracing herSole angel of my love !

lg.l: You 'll take me back ? Let Time begin his count
One minute past , and leave the last one out .
O , say a word will sponge it from the day ,
Or all my future must turn back its face
And live with gazing on that minute 's point .
It was not you , my heart . But say it were ,
Should I pull down my heaven because a bird
Makes flying blot against it ? ‘ Tis the doubts
That darkly flitting show love 's constant sky
Forever radiant .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: O me ! O me ! And this is shame !

lg.l: Nay , sweet ! Weep , if you must ,
But let thy tears be rain upon the soul
Making a fair new season .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Let me die !

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: So overwrought ? Thou who hast been my strength ?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: If I were dead then you ——

lg.l: Should be as thou !
‘ Tis not thy death but Glaia 's that would be
The sad solution of these woes .
Not her ,
So fair ... and dear to us .
My gentle love !
... ‘ Twere best she died , who now must drink the cup
That makes death sweet in coming . I myself
Almost could guide the knife unto her heart
And cut off ruder visitors .
O , veil
The thought . Its nakedness has chilled my soul .

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: Ay , she is God 's , not mine . Leave her to him . And now , my life , you , too , must go to rest .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: You 'll not to bed ?

lg.l: The king may send for me .
He will not sleep , for in his face was woe
Will quiet not to slumber .
O , my love ,
How can I leave thee now ? If thou wert held
By softest sleep on pillows of content
I could no less than weep to go from thee ,
And yet these tears are all I have when thou
Art left to sad , despairing watch . I 'll stay ,
For I 've no words to part with , none to tell
How breaks my heart in going .
Nay , I must work ,
And you will call my wits to otherwheres ;
Then in the morn these eyes , undewed with sleep ,
Will show me not the light that must be mine .
Dost toy with words to me ? Not in my eyes ,
But in my heart burns thy unfailing torch ,
And if you find it dim it is thy secret
Casts shade between us , not a lack in me .

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: If I should speak then oaths were straws in fire .

lg.l: O , no , I would not have thee speak . That 's past .
‘ Tis our misfortune that we are divided
In this most pitchy hour that in itself
Were nothing if our hearts could meet and melt
In unreserved touch . In every life
There comes a watch the soul must keep alone .
The hour has struck for thine . And mine I feel
Is not so far away . Now , now I go ,
My lord . Because I help you best in going .
Our hearts would rush together , and the pain
Grows in them baffled . Dearer than life , good night .
I leave my prayers like candles set about you ,
And as they fail think of me on my knees
Renewing them from Heaven .

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: Margaret !

div.stage: Pauses , slowly takes up the light and goes off , left , leaving the room in darkness . Curtain

div.head: SCENE 2 . The same room in darkness . Margaret enters , right ,

stage.stage: carrying a taper .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: I 'll look upon her . When sleep slips the rein The soul plays in the face unguarded . Then The conscious warder holding up the mask Before the secret self bares all defence Unheedful of approach . I 'll look , and pray To find the lineaments so pure by day Still guileless fair . O , that ‘ twere yesterday — Sweet yesterday — when I knew not nor guessed The sad division ‘ tween my soul and Hubert 's ! O , knowledge , rude defiler of our dreams , How oft we 'd give thy hard , substantial store To build again with bright illusion 's eye Our happy towers on the inconstant clouds :Sees a light through curtainsShe 's up ! No ... who is there ?

div.stage: Veils her taper . Kent comes from the inner room . He carries a candle

lg.l: She does not move .
O , Eleanor , how could thy heart give blood
To one so pure that he who loves her best
Would send her back to Heaven ?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Unheard by KentEleanor ! Her child ! Her child !

lg.l: Fair Glaia , may'st thou rest ,
Not ever wake till angels call thee up .
Ay , ay , she sleeps .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: How gracious art thou , God , To bless me so ! O , wicked Eleanor ! This was the fire that maddened thee to-night . Not fear for Hubert . How couldst make his life The priceless cloak of thy own worthless shame ? But I can save him ! I will make thee speak , Unsistered woman !Draws back the curtains , leaving them open , showing the inner room and bed on which Glaia liesGlaia , now I 'll look , Nor all thy grace shall hide the lines that mark Thy cruel mother . Can this be the face That breeds such misery ? Fair heaven-case Of innocence !... My Hubert 's niece , so mine . How lily-cold in sleep ! And still ... so still . A kiss will not awake thee — one as light As my own heart . So cold ? O , cold as death !Draws back the coverletBlood ! Blood ! A dagger here ! O Heaven , That this smooth coverlet should hide so much !Stands a moment in silent horrorAnd Hubert thought she slept . “ Rest well , ” he said , “ Nor ever wake till angels call thee up . ” Nor wilt thou wake till then , poor Glaia . O , How can I call him here to look on this !Takes up the daggerStrange that the slayer left his dagger here . He in whose heart the thought of murder lives Has more of cunning in him .Drops dagger suddenlyHubert 's ! O !Staggers away from bed and holds herself up by the curtains . Buries her face for an instant , then looks up blanched and determinedI must act quickly . O , at once — at once ! One pause may be the grave of resolution .Starts toward bed , but stops“ She does not move , ” he said ... and “ ay , she sleeps , ” As though she slept eternally .Goes to bed , and takes up the daggerHis dagger . Oft has it pleased me to regard this hilt . Pearls winding like a milky way about A turquoise heaven . Even then my fate Lurked in the blade . Why do I talk , and beg A vile delay ? Pain is sole merchant here , And with each moment amplifies his profit . ... I will not pray , for prayer is softening , And I must be too stern to pity self . I was a princess . I 'll not think of that , For now I am a wife . And for my lord Must die . They 'll find me here , and say the deed Was mine . My jealous hand avenged my wrong . ... O gentle Heaven , he is not worthy this ! Nay , nor no man , and yet for every man There lives a woman who would die for him .Lifts the daggerI can not strike .Drops her armI must ... ere I go mad And leave the event to chance .

div.stage: Lifts dagger , grows faint and falls with a cry to the floor . Kent enters , left

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: Twas Margaret 's voice . My love ?Advances and sees Margaret on the floorO , life of mine !Looks toward bedGlaia ! Uncovered — bleeding — dead ! Put out My eyes ! Out ... out . What cruelty yet lives In Heaven to show me this ? O , Eleanor , Come , come and see how thy one sin has grown To widest hell ! Thy Glaia dead ... even cold ... And Margaret ... not dead ... but would she were !Bends over herYea , I could love thee then . My Margaret , Couldst do this thing ? Thy hand was ever tender , And oft thou coveredst even guilt with mercy . ... She could not do it .... Ay , she could ... she could . For her ancestral steps are marked with blood , And but to-night her eye flashed with a look That like an evil star did point to this .Knocking without , and opening of gatesMy summons from the king . Ho , Rufus ?Draws coverlet over Glaia 's formGlaia , Thou wert the bud of earth ; infinity Shall wear thy blossom and be proud .

div.stage: Enter attendant

sp.speaker: Att
sp.p: My lord ?

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: Your mistress faints . Call up her women . Haste !Exit attendant . Kent takes Margaret in his arms and bears her off , right . Re-enters , goes to curtains and draws them , concealing Glaia 's bedO , Henry , now thy heart is struck .Enter an attendantWho comes ?

lg.l: Your grace , I do not know . Strange men who give
No name , but say that they must see you .

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: Must ? Admit them .

sp.speaker: Att
sp.p: Here , your grace ?

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: Ay , here .

div.stage: Exit attendant . Kent picks up dagger from the floor ] ‘ Tis mine . I 'll wear my own . [ Hangs dagger at his belt ] Now is the earl of Kent A murderer . How feels it with you , sir ?
Enter officers and attendants

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: My lord of Kent , you are our prisoner .

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: By whose command ?

sp.speaker: Off
sp.p: The king 's .

lg.l: O , April heart ,
Dost think ‘ twill ne'er be winter ? What the crime ?
You 're charged , on pain of death , to show the son
Of Adelais , of France .
That sin is old
And faded now . I know another blots
O'er that . I 'll burn your ears with ‘ t as we go .
ACT III

div.head: SCENE 1 . A small altar room , adjoining the king 's apartment .

stage.stage: Henry bowed and kneeling . Enter Winchester and attendant .

sp.speaker: Att
sp.p: Since morning he has knelt , and sees no one . You are the first admitted .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: Dear my lord ——

lg.l: Will you , too , tell me she is dead ?

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: Alas ——

lg.l: O , not that word — the pretty mask of woe .
That never hid a tear . If she is dead ,
Weep and be dumb , or find some word that rends
The heart in uttering it .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: My lord ——

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: My lord ! You 're too polite a mourner , by my faith ! O , Glaia , Glaia , Glaia , art thou dead ? Canst thou then sleep , O , God ?

lg.l: That he does sleep
This deed is proof .
What deed ? ‘ Tis false ! She lives .
‘ Twas blessed yester morn I held her here ,
And heard her laugh and say my kisses were
Like Maythorn blossoms dropping on her hair .
And can her voice be still ? Nay , fiends themselves
Love music , and would spare to put so much
To silence . O , in her tongue the nightingale
Was dead , having no sweeter cause to live .
She could not die . A thousand thousand angels
Would rush to save her and with silvery wings
Beat back the assaulting devil .
Would I could say
She lives ! You drain my heart with every tear
You drop upon this woe . Loved majesty ,
Look up and weep no more .
Stop not my tears .
They shall pour sea-like till my body lies
An isle o'erwhelmed . My eyes could lend the skies
Another flood yet lack not moisture .... Glaia !
It was my kiss that slew thee . But for me
Thou hadst been living still . So Winter springs
To clasp his blushing Autumn love , then spends
His weary season burying her dead leaves .
Rouse you , my lord . The creature is alive
That slew her .
He is found ?— and lives — and you
Stand here to tell me ?

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: Hear my story , sire . When we arrested Kent ——

lg.l: Arrested Kent ?
You could not wait ? Well , we shall see , my lord ,
My Glaia loved him and he shall not die .
The moment he was taken he confessed
That he had slain the maid ——
What is ‘ t you say ?
Now , by my life , I thought you said that Kent —
I 'll not repeat it — ‘ twas so strange a thing —
I 'm numb since this dark news , and what I hear
By insurrection of my wits becomes
What I hear not .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: Recall yourself , my lord . Your wits are loyal , and inform you rightly . I said ‘ twas Kent ——

lg.l: Ha ! Now the devil speaks
In his own person . You 've thrust the cloven foot
Too far from ‘ neath the bishop 's gown .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: My lord ——

lg.l: Now I read back and take the hellish measure
Of all your lies !

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: Your majesty ——

lg.l: Sir , I have loved this man , and when I felt
Too weak for England 's throne , I laid my head
Upon his breast and there grew strong as he .
And you dare say ——
I do not say , my liege ,
The crime is his , but he confessed it so .
Here are the words in which he damns himself .
Drop from the world , O sun ! Make all the air
Dark as my heart , that from this hour shall know
No re-ascending star ! Leave me , my lord .
All 's as you please . Do what you will . The world
No more shall draw me forth to look upon it .
Yet I am young , and had but learned to smile .

div.stage: Enter attendant

lg.l: The earl of Pembroke begs to see my lord
Of Winchester .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: Admit him here . I 'll pray .Turns to altar . Enter Pembroke

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: What news , your grace ?

lg.l: ‘ Tis strange enough , my lord .
Kent 's wife , the princess Margaret , now swears
‘ Twas she who took the maiden 's life , and speaks
With so much care and proof of circumstance
I scarce can doubt her .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: Margaret !

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: No other . She says ‘ twas she alone , and not her husband .

lg.l: This fortune wears our colors . Give it welcome .
I feared she 'd rouse all England ,— Scotland , too ,—
In Kent 's defence . You know her blood of old .
But now her hands are bound .
Then you 've no doubt
‘ Twas she ?
I wish to have none , that 's enough
To shape my looks by .
lg.stage: Henry rises and comes toward them
lg.l: Ah , my liege , we hear
That Margaret is author of the crime
We now bewail , not Kent .
That it was either
I can not whip my senses to believe .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: She has confessed .

lg.l: Why , so did Kent . This shows
A gap in proof .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: Kent thought to shield his wife .

lg.l: Then he must love her well , and yet your tongue
Struck hard another way . Nay , it is she
Who thinks to save her lord . Poor Margaret ,
Thou hadst done better to have wed the king .
My lord , we can not doubt Kent loved this maid .
‘ Twas as apparent as the light to eyes ;
And he would pause ere put her from his arms
To bed with worms ; but this same love would be
Poor Margaret 's bitter cause to wish her dead ;
And Jealousy , we know , is page to Murder ,
Holding the candle for the hellish stroke .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: But why should Kent confess ?

lg.l: With all his sins ,
He has the grace of chivalry , and thought
By his confession to save Margaret ,
Not caring for his fate since he was doomed
For other crime .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: I 'll hear no more , my lord . A woman ... and that woman — Margaret .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: My liege ——

lg.l: No more . Here is my seal . ‘ Tis yours .
And now I beg you go . Nothing is dear
But grief , sole link ‘ tween me and love . Leave me ,
I pray .

sp.speaker: Win
sp.p: Aside , gloatingWeep , fool , my star is in my hand !

sp.speaker: Pem
sp.p: God send you comfort , sire .

div.stage: Exeunt Winchester and Pembroke

lg.l: Let none approach me .
Henry sings ]
I laid a rose upon my heart ,
Ay me !
Soon ‘ gan its beauty to depart ,
Ay , ay me !
I nursed it with desire ,
Still did its beauty go .
For O , my heart was fire ,
Cruel fire !
Ay me , I did not know ,
I did not know .
lg.stage: Enter a friar through panel door behind altar
lg.l: Art thou a shadow come to say
All men are shadows and naught living is ?
I come to give God 's help and ask for thine ,
My son and king .
‘ Tis death , sir , thus to steal
Into my presence .
So I prove my love
For thee , your highness , venturing life to reach
Thine ear 's seclusion .

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.p: What wouldst tell me , father ? I 've heard your voice before and found it honest . By that , mayhap , we 'll prove old friends . Come in .

div.stage: Exeunt

div.head: SCENE 2 . A prison corridor . Kent alone .

lg.l: Is this the end of Kent ? The block and axe
His porters to throw ope the sealed gate ?
I thought a good wife 's prayers had ushered me ,
And weeping peers had held my garments back
Until the soul disdained to hide therein .
... What value 's in this world that men will buy ‘ t
With so much groaning ? This strange human chaos
Where vice is often merit , merit vice ,
Or if they be themselves so change deserts
That wisdom is clapped to gallows , folly to thrones .
And innocence lifts up thin , fettered hands
While guilt walks angel free . Where palsy shakes
The pen from the seer 's hand , and crowing health
Bids fools to write ; where Fame forgets to blush
At Flattery 's board , and Honor , pendulous
‘ Twixt bribe and faith , dwindles inert and like
A withered finger shames the hand of state .
... Where Margarets can stripe their souls ’ pure white
With guileless blood . She , she that was a dove
To falcon turn and rend a fledgling 's breast !
It casts a doubt on Heaven , makes of faith
A leper scourged from man 's hale faculties ,
And love a monster of diseased minds !
Come , dearest Death , and mis-shaped world away !
lg.stage: Margaret is admitted , left , by a turnkey

sp.speaker: Turnkey
sp.p: You 're honest ? All your jewels , ma'am ?

lg.l: Ay , all !
They have been praised , but had no worth till now
When each one buys a minute with my lord .

div.stage: Exeunt turnkey , locking door
Margaret comes down corridor toward Kent , her hands behind her

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: Looking upWhat devil drove you here ?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Did Hubert speak ?

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: What do you want ? Why hold away your hands ? Fear not that I 'll embrace thee !

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: What art thou ?

lg.l: Nothing to thee , whatever else I am .
Away ! For Death and I have just locked hands .
One moment more and I had cozened him
Of all his pain . But you , dear , damned foe ,
Take up his weapons and re-gash my wounds .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Is this my lord ?

lg.l: Go . I command you . Go !
Eternity drops on me , and lightfoot Time
Hies like a ghost to nothing . What dost here ?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: I die .

lg.l: You die ? No fear of that . You are
Too great a lover of this life that vaunts
A bloated bubble ‘ twixt immortal shores .
If once ‘ twere true — if once I loved this world —
Thy bitter words have sucked desire to live
From all my senses . As a god I held thee ,
Now mocking gods bid me look on whilst thou
Deport'st thyself ‘ neath mortal . Sir , what plague
Hast met ? What conjuration of the skies
Disfigures thee ?
The same that made thyself
A woman . Back unto your world !
O , true
I loved this life , and held a heart not dead
To music , beauty , sweet and warm delights ,
An interest in the season-robing earth ,
An entertained eye for fortune 's chance ,
And too pretentiously I sighed to leave
The unfollowed steps of fair and flying Truth ,
And last , poor woman , shrank to change thine arms
For the cold circlet of Elysian clouds ;
But you , pervert and monstrous , work my peace ,
Unto my eyes deforming all the world
And making the unknown more dear than dream .
I monstrous ? O , thou shame ! To 've died for you
Were scarcely more than 's done each day for love ;
But I for you have heaped my name with crime ,
Crime that will damn my reputation 's snow
While lasts the world and men recount old tales !
‘ Twas for my sake you did it ! Ah , I know .
You loved me well . Would you had known me better ,
Or loved me less ! O , how couldst think my life
Would flower with happiness when sacrifice
Of one as dear to Heaven as myself
Lay burning at its root ? Nay , I must wither
Unto this world , but as I fall thy name
Grows fairer , for I have confessed ‘ twas I .
For love of me you sinned . The punishment
Is mine .

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: Confessed ? You have confessed ? No , no !

lg.l: I shall be soon forgot , but your great name
Will live , and since it must , or dark or bright ,
I would remove as much of foulness from it
As blood of mine will cleanse .
You have confessed !
O , God of truth , let man trust to thy mercy ,
Not hope to cheat thy justice ! You confessed ?
Already I was doomed , but you — you might
Have lived . Ay , and you shall !
lg.stage: Comes near her and sees that her hands are fettered
lg.l: In fetters ? You ?
By holy Heaven , though giants forged these on
I 'd strip them off !
O , let me wear them , sir !
My bond of blessedness — for I am blest
In dying for your sin !

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: That word again ? My sin ?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Forgive me , Hubert . ‘ Twas no sin . Indeed , ‘ twas none . For you were not yourself . ‘ Twas madness . Heaven must forgive it thee .

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: God help thee , Margaret ! Wouldst say I did it ?

lg.l: Not you , but heavy , secret woe that bred
A demon in your blood to strike poor Glaia ,—
And too-dear love of me which vainly hoped
To give me peace where never peace could be .
O , look not so ! At God 's own throne ‘ twill be
Forgiven thee , for surely thou wert tried
As Heaven tries its own .
Art mad at last ?
Thy crime confessed to all the world , and yet
Denied to me , the only heart that knows ?
Poor soul , her madness has been slow enough .
Come , bruised darling , with thy blood-stained hands !
Thou ‘ rt mine , my only love !
lg.stage: Embracing her . She moves from him

lg.l: ‘ Tis you that speak
Wild words . My blood-stained hands ? They 're free of blood
As the pure angel 's who writes golden down
The saintliest deeds of men !
Whate'er thy words ,
Thine eyes are true , and there 's no madness in them .
But , Margaret , I found thee by her side ——

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: ‘ Twas there I swooned ——

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.p: The dagger in thy hand ——

lg.l: Yes , in my hand , but , Hubert — hear me , Hubert !
I saw you come from Glaia 's curtained bed ,
Slow and despairing , murmuring “ She sleeps , ”
As though you said she slept to wake no more .
I entered , saw her pale , drew back the coverlet —
There ran the stream that drained her beauty 's rose —
There lay your dagger — yours . And then I thought
By dying there to save your life and name ,
But fainted , O , too soon ——
My heart , my heart !
O , had I done such deed would I have left
My dagger to confess it ? Glaia called —
Not so — I dreamed she called — and going there ,
Found her in deepest sleep — or thought I found
Her so — and touched her not lest she should stir
And know her woes again .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: It was not you ?

lg.l: That question makes your tongue a dagger 's point ,
And yet my doubt of you was deeper wrong ,
Measuring all the difference between
Man 's grosser soul and woman 's altar-lit .
O , Margaret , some serpent heart planned well
To do this deed and leave the guilt with me .
Who — who , my Hubert ? Nay , it matters not ,
Since ‘ twas not you — not you ! In two small words
My heaven is built again !
We ne'er shall know .
I 've foes enough , and one of them perhaps
So sought to cast me deeper by this crime ,
And we shall wear his foul and scarlet mark
Even unto our graves ,— for we must die .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Enough that we die sinless .

lg.l: O , my love ,
Who would have died for me !
And you , dear lord ,
Who took such shame upon you for my sake !
Death was already on me , and ‘ twas naught
To make addition to my guilt . But you ,
Your heart not pausing , leapt from safety 's shore
Into the flood . O , might I live for thee !
A blessed bondman to thy merest wish ,
From hour to hour to watch thy graces bloom
As various as Flora when she loves ,
And in each furrow of thy brow that writ
Thee mortal set a new April mocking Time !
Then when no more I could dispute his doom ,
Enter with thee a star-lit , sweet old age ,
The fane of rest , and sanctuary where
All sorrows take their ease .

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Think thou of Heaven .

lg.l: But O , how dear this life ! The immortal world
Is shrunk to shadow of a single thought ,
And this contemned earth is sudden grown
Past circumscription of the mind 's fond eye .
No-no — we must not die !
Wouldst tremble now ?
When thou hast love beside thee ? Nay , my lord ,
Be yet the man of men , whose virtue drew
My wild resisting heart into its sun .
O , must we leave it all ?— the gracious earth
Where we have loved , and heard the robins sing ,
And built our nest that song might never cease ?
Ah , I am weak , my sweet , and shine but in
The doting tear that dims a true wife 's eye .
‘ Tis not my love that paints thee radiant ,
But thy own light illumes my eyes to love ,
O , lord of mine , the kings of earth in vain
May hope to be thy shadowy parallel ,
And where we go , in any court of air
Or cloud or heaven , still must thou be the one
Excelling star .
Heart of the sun , beat here !
O , thy immortal fire will make Death warm
Ere he can make thee cold .
lg.stage: The turnkey opens door at end of corridor

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: My life , my soul !

lg.l: O , God ! Celestial marshaller of chance
To some far end of good , let me believe
Thy hand is here , and even on our heads .
Ah , kiss me , kiss me , Heaven 's Margaret .
Could I my life concentrate in one beat
I 'd dwarf it so and give it in this kiss .

div.stage: Curtain

div.head: SCENE 3 . A room in the earl of Albemarle 's palace . A friar , and

stage.stage: the king in friar 's dress , but uncowled , waiting .

lg.l: This is a fitting room for Death 's cold jest ;
So proudly hung , and filled with comfort 's chattels ,
