sp.p: I have it : The song is ready !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Looking meaningly at VasilDo n't be so sure of your first effort , my boy . Better let it get cold .

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: No , we 'll hear it . That paper looks interesting .

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: Pardon me .Folds paper and puts it into his pocket

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: I insist upon hearing it .

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: Taking paper out reluctantly‘ Tis merely a song , sir , and will hardly bear reading . I will sing it for you .Unfolds paper slowlyA Welcome to Summer , friends . ‘ Tis an old chorus , and you can help me with it .SingsCome out , come out with me To meet the summer maid ! A queen , a queen is she , Whose love is as the sea That would all lands caress , Whose loves are many as the sands , And each a sovereign is , For whom her arms enring Is royal by her kiss , Forevermore a king , a king , a king ! Come , dance , dance , dance , and welcome the summer maid ! Who has looked into her eyes is nevermore afraid ! We will gather our hearts together , we will mingle our feet on the grass , We will hold her with kisses , nor ever , nor ever let her pass !The peasants join in chorusHer free step is the dawn No darkness can waylay , Her laugh is the wild waterfall By winter never chained , Her hair the winds unreined , Her eyes unbridled sun , And all the waves are in her call That heard is never still , Her breath the clouds that hie Free as they list or will , And in her bosom find a greater sky ! Ye mothers , come , forsake Dead fire and frozen hearth ; The bones ye call your babes , awake , For in her lap she bears Sweet grain and golden ears That warming in their veins shall make The ruddy might of men ; Your daughters that now lie Blanched , broken , still , shall then Lift up rose faces and forget to die . Old Winter in his snows Is covered , covered deep , For all above him lie his slain , And not until his breath Has warmed them out of death May he arise from his cold sleep . Good-by , good-by , good-by , Old Winter dead and white , No more meet you and I , A last and long , a long and last good-night !

div.stage: As the chorus is sung the last time , Vasil dances out among the peasants , who join hands with him and all move in a ring , singing

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: I congratulate you . And now will you favor me with the copy ?

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: Seeming to hesitate‘ Tis hardly worthy ——

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: Taking itLeave that to me .Glances disappointedly at song , repeating the first lineHumph ! Yes ...Puts it into his pocketSo you are all true men enjoying yourselves ? I 've no objection . On the contrary . I 'm in the humor to join you if my lady Bright-eyeslooking at Verawill honor me .

div.stage: Vera rises , curtsies , and couples spring up , forming a dance , Orloff and Vera leading

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: At close of the danceThank you , Bright-eyes . I shall find no fairer partner at the ball , whither I must be going . And here , young man . I will leave you your song . It may be your only copy .Brings out several papers from his pocket and looks them overHere is the song , but ...Assumes sudden sternnessA serious matter . I have lost an important paper since I came into this room .Looks searchingly at their facesAn important paper on official business .All are silent , betraying no emotion . He turns his gaze to Vera , who is sitting by her grandfatherAh , my little lady , perhaps your fingers were busy in the dance . Come forward , please .

div.stage: Vera steps out , bewildered

sp.speaker: Vera
sp.p: I did not touch it .

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: Of course not . Now will you shake your scarf , please ? Yes , I will do it for you .Shakes her scarf and a paper drops to the floor . Orloff picks it upAh , found ! Good , but rather a sad affair for you , little one . Even fingers so dainty as yours must not meddle with the Czar 's papers .

sp.speaker: Vera
sp.p: I did not touch them !

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: Of course not . But you must come with me .Mutterings from the menI hear you , friends . If any of you want to come along just make it known . Our prisons are well stuffed , but we can manage to pack away all present .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: After a second of silenceThe child is innocent .

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: O , you want to go , do you ? But you happen to be the one we do n't want — yet . Anybody else ?

sp.speaker: Vera
sp.p: SobbingI did not touch it .

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: You may tell that to Petrizoff . He is always kind to beauty .

sp.speaker: Vera
sp.p: In terrorAm I going to him ?

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: He will not be far away , I imagine .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: You can not take this child . The paper was not stolen .

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: You saw it drop from her scarf .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Where you put it .

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: In a rageYour mouth will soon be shut ! If I could have had my way this morning your hide would n't hold shucks to-night !

div.stage: Noise of a carriage at door . Sophie enters in ball dress . She draws back in astonishment at sight of Orloff

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: FaintlyYou here ?

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: And you ?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: ComposedMay I speak to you , Count Orloff ?

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: At your service , your highness .

div.stage: They draw aside , left , front . The peasants talk in low tones . Guards stand by Vera

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Of course I know why you are here , but I had to simulate surprise .

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: You were very successful .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Since the exposure of this morning the people are ready to suspect me , and I must retain their confidence or my usefulness is at an end .

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: Quite .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: They heard to-day of the girl 's danger , and were planning her escape , so I , not knowing whether you would arrive in time , stopped — to ——

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Quiet their fears and assure them of her safety . Are there any prisoners besides the girl ?

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: No , but I would give something to take this insolent Shepherd . I 've only a few hours to wait though .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: A few hours ?

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: Yes — ah , you do n't know everything then !

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Dear man , I know everything but one ,— that is , how much you know . If you will go to the ball in my carriage we may find out how far we can trust each other .

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: Angel !

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Do n't ! The people — you must pretend to oppose me . They think I am interceding for the girl .

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: As if suddenly recalling somethingWhy did you save the boy this morning ?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: I will explain that too — in the carriage . We must go now . I first , so they will not know we leave together .

lg.l: I promised Petrizoff not to leave the girl till
I had her safe in prison . There have been so many escapes ——

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: With a glance at VeraShe is pretty . Good-evening then .

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: Wait — I will go with you !

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: MeltingWill you ? Then you sha'n ' t . You shall take no risks for me .

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: Risk ! I would risk anything . Ah , you can n't deprive me now .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Can you trust the guards ?

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: I will trust them !

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Very well . I will wait for you .Going , stops before AdrianI have not been able to obtain her release , but I am sure there is hope . At least I have touched Colonel Orloff 's heart . Have I not , Count ?

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: You have indeed !

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Looking steadily at AdrianAnd you will hear news of great importance before morning .To OrloffWill he not ?

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: Without doubt , your highness .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Going , again turns to AdrianThe Count will give you his word that I am to be trusted .

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: To be sure , your highness .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Good-night .Exit

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: After following Sophie 's departure with a fatuous lookCome , lady-bird , we must be moving .Starts out , the guards following with Vera . Vetrova , who has seemed quite stunned , suddenly rushes after them and beats guards with his crutch

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: Seizing him by the collar and throwing him to the floorYou old fool ! We do n't want to bother with you !

div.stage: Exeunt Orloff , guards and Vera . Vetrova , lying on floor , lifts his fist and curses

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Bending over himPetrusha !

sp.speaker: Vet
sp.p: Let me be , Adrian Lavrov ! I have held my peace all my life to die cursing at last ! I was dumb when they broke my bones under the rod . I was dumb when my son died under the lash . But Vera , my little girl — dragged to that — O God , send thy fires upon him ! Curse him — curse him — curse ——Dies . The peasants cross themselves . Some kneel before the icon , praying . Catherine gazes at Vetrova in hopeless terror . Galovkine kneels and examines the body

sp.speaker: Galovkine
sp.p: Dead .

sp.speaker: Cath
sp.p: Dead — and a curse on his lips . My Petrusha — dead — and a curse on his lips .

div.stage: Two men pick up the body and bear it off right centre , Adrian opening the door . Catherine follows with several women . The other peasants go off silently , street door , leaving only Adrian , Vasil and the revolutionists

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: As I was saying when — the Czar interrupted us — Petrizoff must die . And you will help us , Lavrov . Yes — you must ! You say yourself that our best hope lies in sympathy and sentiment ——

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Which the bomb utterly destroys .

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: Not when the Shepherd throws it . Wait ! I do not mean that literally , for thisraising his handis the consecrated hand . But your name as our leader would sanctify the deed .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Your leader ?

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: Yes . Not only for this , but for our army . Your name is a divine word in every peasant home in Russia . It is cheered by every body of workmen gathered together to-night , and in the army who would not surrender the colors of Romanov to the hero line of Donskoi ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: StartingGregorief ——

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: Wait ! They are all ready now . The peasantry , inspired by the teaching of our martyrs for the last thirty years ,— the nobility with awakened conscience ,— the workmen , one great body with suspended arms ,— the army of the Czar ready to become the army of the people ,— all await their leader — you !A pauseRussia is looking but one way — to freedom . To-day you may lead us to victory almost without blood . Let Petrizoff commit this crime in the name of liberty , and to-morrow we shall be like the scattered limbs of a dissevered body . You will not let this be , Lavrov . You will ——

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: No ! Let civilization wait another century rather than deliver her flag to the hands of murderers !

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: And where is it now if not in the hands of murderers ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: It is not in their hands , Gregorief , but in ours , that are yet clean . Do this thing , and it is you , not Petrizoff , who give the greatest blow to freedom . The world is just beginning to understand us ——

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: Yes ! Where is that understanding growing strongest ? In America . And how does the autocracy propose to meet this new influence ? By a secret commercial treaty with the United States . Give any government a pocket interest in the security of another and to the winds with sympathy ! Petrizoff has his agents there now , and the burning of Yaltowa is only a part of his scheme to chill the hearts that are warming to us . But he shall not live to do it . You will not let him live , Lavrov . My God , do n't you see that your opportunity has come ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Yes . My opportunity to point once more to where the sun shall rise .

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: The sun never rises on the blind . You would throw us back into night for another thousand years !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: What are a thousand years to the soul of man on the right path to the right thing ?

sp.speaker: Galovkine
sp.p: Plucking at GregoriefCome away . We lose time here .

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: Not until I tell this fool where he stands ! You imagine , Lavrov , that you are a friend to freedom , but a greater enemy does not tread Russian soil . Why does the government leave you at work ? Because of your power to subdue the spirit in men . It is you — such as you — who forget our shackles and fill the prisons . But thank the Powers that keep the race alive , there are still some of us who believe in manhood — in the virtues of the heart as well as the soul — in courage , honor , justice !To the othersCome up to Breshloff 's . We will finish there .

div.stage: Enter Korelenko hurriedly

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: Grasping his handKorelenko ! The word ? What is it ?

lg.l: What you wished . We needed only the consent of the Social
Democrats to Petrizoff 's death ——

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: Yes , yes !

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: And I have brought their sanction ——

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: Almost sobbingThank God !

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: If it is done under the leadership of the Shepherd of Lonz .

div.stage: Adrian staggers back against loom

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: Clutching KorelenkoTake back that infernal proviso !

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: I thought you wished it .

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: I did , when I believed the man there was human .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: He is . The most human of us all . You do n't know him . Adrian , you see that all depends upon you ——

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Waving him awayBegone — all of you !

lg.l: Come ! God gave us good right arms . We need not wait for
Lavrov 's .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: But can we do without the Social Democrats ?

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: Yes ! We have the others . Come to Breshloff 's !

div.stage: All go except Korelenko , who lingers in the door . Adrian sits exhausted on bench before loom

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Sasha ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Turning back quicklyWell ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: You have chosen ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Between my friends and my enemies ? Yes .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Between the body and the soul .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Soul ! There is none in Russia . When we get possession of our bodies we may be permitted to cultivate souls !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: If you would wait a little , Sasha . Reforms are coming . The Czar will grant a constitution ——

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: He will grant what we take , no more . And what do we gain if he gives us a constitution and keeps his army ? If he gives us schools and exiles the teachers ? If he gives us freedom and denies it to the men who have won it — our brothers in the dungeons ? No , we want our constitution , not the Czar 's — a constitution with law and justice behind it , not an army .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Is it time ? There is so much ignorance yet ——

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Ignorance ! Where is it greater than among our masters ? We suffer as much from their stupidity as their oppression . I hate the ass 's head more than the tyrant 's !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: But the poor , illiterate peasants . Are they ready ——

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Viatka and Perm answer that ! There , where they have been let alone , they have established the best governed provinces in Russia . But here , where ignorance is protected — do you know what will happen if Yaltowa is burnt ? The peasants of Karitz will be led into the town to pillage and slaughter in the name of Christ .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: In horrorKaritz ! My poor people ! I must go there at once .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: There ? It is only because you are here that Lonz will not be led into it .IronicallySince you can n't be everywhere , had n't we better devise some other means for the protection of the people ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: O , it is horrible !

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: More horrible than you dream . A good man can not know how bad the world is , for he can never get away from himself .

div.stage: Re-enter Manlief

sp.speaker: Manl
sp.p: Come , Korelenko . We shall be too late .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: He is not going .

sp.speaker: Manl
sp.p: No ? I 'll stiffen his heart . You do n't know , do you , that your little Vera has been taken to Petrizoff ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Stares in amazement , and clutches AdrianIs this a lie ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: She has been arrested .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: You let her be taken ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: I had no choice .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: There is always a choice . You could have killed her .Breaks down

sp.speaker: Manl
sp.p: Touching himCome .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Yes ! Go on ! I 'll come !

sp.speaker: Manl
sp.p: At Breshloff 's .Exit

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Savagely , starting upYou would save his life knowing that !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: What has Vera 's misfortune — yours — mine — to do with an eternal principle ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Damn your principle ! It will put us all into hell !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: The princess may be able to do something for her . She ——

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: You still believe in that spy ?Adrian is silent . Korelenko looks at himForgive me . You love her . No ! If you knew what love is you would help me !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Going to him as he reaches the doorWait . I do know . I love her even as you love Vera , and I swear to you that if she stood in Vera 's place my answer would be the same .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: AbstractedlyYou love her .Starts suddenly away

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: You will stay now , Sasha ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Now ? No . There is something to do now .

div.stage: Exit

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Light , light , O my God !

div.stage: Door opens , right centre , and a woman appears

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: Can you come to Catherine Vetrova now , sir ?

div.stage: Adrian bows his head and follows her out . Vasil , who has been sitting behind the little table rear , at times listening eagerly , at times overcome , rises and moves slowly forward , carrying his violin

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: Repeats softly“ As impersonal as the universe . ”

div.stage: Strikes two or three notes on the violin and stops , terrified . Dashes the instrument down and throws himself to the floor , sobbing ] O , Vera ! Vera ! Vera !
Curtain

div.head: SCENE 2 . The same . Vasil still lying on the floor . Adrian enters

stage.stage: right , crosses and attempts to rouse him .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: You must go to bed , my son . There is nothing for you to do .

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: RisingNothing for me to do ? Why am I in the world then ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: To be our light — our song — to find our angels for us .

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: Looking down at his violinIt is broken .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Picking it upYou will mend it .

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: And the heart too ?Goes to table , left front , and sits by it , despondent and thoughtfulWe were wrong to-day , Adrian . I was wrong . No one has a right to happiness while others are suffering because of things that are in the power of man to help . The good people who forget what is out of sight , as if misery — or duty — were a question of eyes and ears , they are the most to blame .RisesIf they would all help — just all of the good .Goes to door , rear , and stands a moment looking outThe princess dances at the ball to-night .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: My boy !

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: Coming back to AdrianBut they will not all help — not yet . Perhaps the world of peace must come before the world of love , not out of it ... as war has come before peace . The law of Moses was once the best law . His race saved itself by it . Has the day of its necessity passed , Adrian ? Are we sure ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: It has passed for the man .

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: But humanity is so far behind the man .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: GentlyThat is what made Christ .

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: And that is what killed him !

div.stage: Enter a priest , street door

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: Blessed be this house .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Welcome , father .

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: Is death here ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Yes , father .Crosses to right and opens door for priest to enterYou have many visits to make to-night .

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: Many , my son .Stops before AdrianI have a message for the Shepherd of Lonz .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Taking letterThank you , father .

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: Thank her that sent it , and God who made her heart .Passes into room , right

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: After looking over letterThe princess has danced to some purpose , my boy . Vera is free . She will be on her way to Odessa by morning .

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: Free ? The princess saved her ? My princess ! Did she write it ?Taking letterI will read it with kisses !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: It must be burnt .

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: No , let me keep it — a little while .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: We must be careful . Hush — some one is coming .

div.stage: Vasil retreats to table , rear . Enter Korelenko in great agitation

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Yaltowa is on fire ! We are one night too late ! They must have heard ——

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: On fire ? Now ?

lg.l: I waited with Gregorief at Breshloff 's , the others went on to
Yaltowa , where ——

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: You waited for Petrizoff ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: This ball was only to cover their scheme ——

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: You waited with Gregorief for Petrizoff ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: He will pass through the village about four o'clock .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: But now — O , you are saved from that thing !

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Yes . If we kill him now the fire will seem only a part of the deed . It will help them fix the lie upon us .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Too late , thank God !

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: You think of nothing but Petrizoff ! What of the people now dying in Yaltowa ? Dying because he lives ? Go see the horrors there ! The reactionists are everywhere in the streets , disguised as revolutionists , looting and murdering ! Your Karitz peasants are being turned into beasts ——

div.stage: Adrian gives a deep groan and sits overcome , by table front , left

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: It is not too late ! Our friends — Russia — freedom — yet may live if you will help us ! Your name will justify Petrizoff 's death to the world . With the loss of their chief the reactionists will be in confusion , before they can recover you can organize the great leagues into a militia ——

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: You are mad to think such power is in me .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: You do n't know your power ! You can do it — you only — and it must be done now — before the war in the East is over — before the Czar can make new promises — give us the mockery of a constitution , and fool half of us back to allegiance — before ——

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Rising , shakenIt can not rest with me . One man can not make destiny .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Yes , when that man is you — when the time is now ! Absolutism is at its ebb . Will you wait till the tide gathers and flows over us again in waves of blood ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: To himself , walkingAre there then two codes ? One for the man , one for the race ? And when they conflict , the man must yield ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Codes ! The question of a man 's right to his breath is settled outside of ethics ! O , Adrian , brother , be a man to-night and not a preacher ! Never in the history of the world has there been a revolution so ripe , so terrible , without a leader to march at its head .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Humanity has dropped the club . It will drop the gun . Even the soldiers are throwing it down . And shall I pick it up ——

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Only for a day ! Petrizoff alone stands between us and the army . Vitelkin , the next in power , is ready to join us . But he is suspected already , and must soon resign — or be poisoned . If we remove Petrizoff now thirty regiments will come to us with Vitelkin , and others will follow until the Czar is without an army . In a month — a fortnight — the revolutionists will be masters of the nation ——

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Masters of the nation !Walks away , and returns , much calmer , to KorelenkoIf it is true that only the life of Petrizoff stands between the revolutionists and triumph , he can not long be the sole barrier . He must see his folly and change his ——

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: FuriousWere he to turn angel now , he should die for his past sins !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: SadlyI see . We should unfetter the avenging lion , not loosen the dove of peace , with Petrizoff 's death .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: I did not mean that . You know it was the anger of a moment .KneelingFor the last time I beg you — in the name of all that redeems man from the beast ——

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Very paleRise , Korelenko . Heal ye first yourselves . Out of your differences , your divisions , you make your master . If for one day enmity should sleep , if for one day every lover of freedom should love his neighbor , in that day the oppressor would fall . Rise ! I will not do it .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Springing upYou will !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Will ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Yes . The princess Sophie Travinski is betrayed to Petrizoff . I hoped to prevail without telling you , and spare your heart what mine suffers .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Betrayed ?

lg.l: She has aided to-night in the escape of a prisoner taken by
Petrizoff 's order . He will know all by morning if he lives .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: This lie will not tempt me , Sasha . I can hardly believe you have uttered it .FearfullyI might have believed you .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: I am prepared for your doubt . Gregorief waits outside . He will support my wordgoing to door

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: No ! I will not see him again . It is true .Crosses uncertainly and sits on bench before loomO , is there no end to this night ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: A princess Ghedimin went to Yakutsk for a lesser offence .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Do n't — do n't speak .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: After watching him a momentIf Petrizoff dies he will never know .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: There is no time to warn her .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Then the evidence will go to Petrizoff at once .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: You would do that ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: No , but Gregorief would . He is waiting for your answer .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: My answer ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: You know how to save her .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: RisingHow ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Join us .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Sinking down againYou might be merciful now , Korelenko .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: UnbelievinglyYou will not save her ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Not that way .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: There is no other .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Then she ——

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Adrian , I can not believe you . You will save her !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: How can I now ? The struggle is over . For a heavenly motive I refused to join you ; I can not consent now for an earthly one . O , if you had not told me ! If you had pleaded a little longer —Realizes what he is saying , and looks at Korelenko with a bitter smileYou see it is impossible .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: RagingI will kill you !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Do , Sasha .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Turning from himVera ! My little girl !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Rising suddenlyO , I have not told you ——

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: What ? Quick !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Vera is free . Read this — where — Vasil , the letter !

div.stage: Vasil , who sits by the small table , silently lays the letter upon it . Korelenko crosses and snatches it up

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: As Korelenko readsYou see they will wait for you on the Petoff road until two o'clock . You must go at once . The princess has arranged for you to journey with Vera if you wish , and you must now , for to remain here means imprisonment on the Yaltowa charge .Korelenko is dumb , looking at the letterDo n't lose hope , Sasha . You can still help us in America — perhaps do more for the cause there than here — and you will have Vera ——

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: StrangelyYou must save her now , Adrian .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: She is saved . Have n't you read ? Do n't you see ?

lg.l: Not Vera , the princess . It was I who betrayed her . And it was
Vera she saved . I was so sure of you . You said ——

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: I am sorry for you , Korelenko . You have sold the angel in your service .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: No ! You did it ! You deceived me ! You swore you loved her !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: I swore the truth .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Bah ! Such love ! Prove it ! Prove it !Hurries to the little cabinet in wall , rear , unlocks it , takes out a bomb from his pocket , places it in the cabinet , locks the door and returns to Adrian with keyProve it ! I am going to Vera . Gregorief will wait at Breshloff 's . Send him this key within an hour and he will know what to do .Offers key to Adrian , who looks at him silently . Korelenko throws key to the floorThere it is ! Send it , or her fate will be on your soul , not mine !Exit

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: O , Infinite Love , why didst make us as men to try us as gods ?... And I might have saved her . Might ? ...Goes slowly to the key , stoops and picks it up . As he raises his head his glance falls on the portrait of the Saviour on wall in front of himUnto seventy times seven .He drops the key and takes a step or two toward the pictureThou too wert man !...As he gazes at the portrait Vasil comes softly forward , takes up the key , returns to table , and sits looking at the key as if fascinated . CurtainACT III

div.head: SCENE 1 . Same room . Vasil asleep on bench , rear , left . Adrian

stage.stage: watching by him .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: If I had saved him this day ... this night ! But now ... what peace can heal him ?Rises and walksLord , Lord , from out these burning days , let one , just one , go free ! As thou lovest thy world , let him be spared , let him be spared !

div.stage: Enter Sophie , street door . Adrian looks at her uncomprehendingly . She crosses to him

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Why have you come ?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: To warn you !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: The boy — do not wake him .

div.stage: Sophie crosses to left , rear , Adrian following . She looks down , at Vasil , stoops and tenderly kisses him , then moves away with Adrian . Vasil opens his eyes and looks after them

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: The last two hours have been terrible , but he rests now .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: You must take him with you .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: With me ?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: I have come from the ball .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: I see .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Orloff is a very weak man . I found out that you are to be arrested to-night .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: It has come then .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Is Korelenko going with Vera ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: I hope so . He has gone to meet her .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Then you can n't take his place . We must think of some other way — and quickly .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Not for me . It is you who must go . You are betrayed to Petrizoff .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: I hoped you would n't hear that . I am in no danger .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Between fear and reliefNo danger ?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: With a half smileBy and by you will believe that I can take care of myself .

div.stage: Enter Korelenko with Vera

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Not gone ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: You are lost .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Why did you bring her back ? You have no right to destroy her life !

sp.speaker: Vera
sp.p: I would not go . My place is with Alexander .SoftlyYou ought to understand that , princess .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: To KorelenkoShe is a child . She did not know . You should have gone with her .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Your highness , that was impossible .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: It was not ! All was prepared ——

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: To AdrianDoes she know ?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: That I am betrayed ? Yes , but the man entrusted with the evidence happened to be a devoted servant of my own —Alexander groansHe will fall ! And you — Adrian — what is the matter ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Steadying himself against the loom and clasping VeraI have thrown our lives away — mine and Vera 's — that is all .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Why could n't you go with her ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Because it was I who betrayed you . And could I accept life and love at your hands ?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: ShrinkingYou ? But why ——

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: I can not answer . Come , Vera , to your grandmother .

div.stage: Exeunt Korelenko and Vera , right , centre

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: O , why did he do it ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: I can tell you .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Then why ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Because he believed — O , Sophie , beloved , before I speak , look at me with the love in your eyes as I saw it first . I did not know it was for me then . Let me see it now while I know you are mine — mine ! Yes , yes , you love me !

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Ah , Adrian , I am afraid I love nothing else .

div.stage: Vasil covers his eyes with his arm

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: And you will kiss me once ?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Once ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: As if we were parting forever , Sophie .She embraces and kisses him . He moves away from herNow I will tell you why Alexander could not answer you , and why I can . He betrayed you believing that I could and would save you .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: And you ——

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Could , but would not .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Moving backWhat are you saying , Adrian ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: I could have saved you but I would not . Is n't it clear ?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Moving back till she stands in dim lightNo — I do n't ——

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: I would not consent to Petrizoff 's death .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Lifting her headO !Regarding him steadilyYou refused your consent when you knew that his death would save me ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Lowering his eyesI did .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: He , a murderer , whose death has been justly due a thousand times , and I , innocent , the woman you say you love ——

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Bowing his head , not meeting her lookI have told you the truth .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: And that is why we part forever ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: That is why .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Because I could not forgive you ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: No . I should want more than forgiveness . I should want you to understand .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: That you were right ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: And I could n't understand ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Still hopelessly , not looking at herNo .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Coming nearerAnd we part forever ?He makes no answer . She comes nearerForever ?He is still silent . She comes near enough to turn his face to hersForever , Adrian ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Sophie !Takes her in his arms

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: O , do you think I will ever leave you now ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: You do understand !

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: SmilingThat I can never be in your way ? You will always sacrifice me first ? Yes , I knew that all the time , but you did n't .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: And it makes no difference ?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: How can it when I love you ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: I wonder if God understands women .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: O , some of them . The rest He made to puzzle over when eternity hangs on His hands .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Kissing herHeaven-heart !

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Releasing herselfThat must wait . We have n't a minute ——

div.stage: They hear steps outside , and stand waiting . Orloff and two guards enter

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: It is my turn to be surprised , your highness . I suppose you are here to assure this prisoner of safety .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: What prisoner ?

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: Adrian Lavrov .

div.stage: Guards put fetters on Adrian 's wrists

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: For what crime am I arrested ?

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: To guardsKeep him here until I return .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: For what crime ?

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: For crime sufficient .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: I insist upon knowing .

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: You will know soon enough — in the next world . They say everything is known there .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: He is ashamed to tell you . You are arrested as chief instigator in the burning of Yaltowa .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Is it possible ?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: More than possible . It is so . That is the crime you will die for unless you are rescued by a rising of the people .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: That must not be !

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: Do n't worry . We are giving your friends enough to think about .

div.stage: Sophie has gradually neared the door . Orloff steps before her

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: Pardon me , your highness . You invited me into your carriage a few hours ago . I beg to return the courtesy .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Let me pass !

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: You will leave here only under my escort .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: I know where I shall die then .

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: You have cost me one prisoner .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: What proof have you ?

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: None — yet . But I know it .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: O wonderful sagacity !

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: And I shall lay my reasons before Petrizoff .

lg.l: I suppose you believe , too , that I would rescue the Shepherd of
Lonz ?

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: I shall at least not lose sight of him until he is in prison .Sophie turns her back upon OrloffYou must come with me or stay here under guard . I do n't promise you as pleasant a journey as you gave me , for I shall not be at so much trouble to please . I shall not even ask you to let me repeat the little kiss ——

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Sir !

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: On your hand , which you so kindly permitted .Sophie again attempts to pass himWill your highness take my arm to the carriage ? We have only a short distance to drive before meeting Petrizoff .Looking at his watchHe ought to be almost here .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: I will stay here .

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: In shackles ?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Holding out her armsYes .

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: Stay then . But I will not bind you .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: No , I might not forgive you that if it turns out that you have made a fool 's mistake .

lg.l: There is no mistake , as you will learn after I have seen
Petrizoff .
No conversation between prisoners .
Let me assure you that these guards can be trusted .

div.stage: Adrian sits in the large chair , a guard stationed on each side of him . Sophie sits on low stool before him , and lays her head upon his knees

sp.speaker: A guard
sp.p: AnxiouslyIt is not permitted to communicate ——

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Then do n't , sir !

div.stage: Silence for a moment , then the noise of horses approaching

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Ah — Petrizoff !

div.stage: Vasil rises cautiously . The guards have their backs to him and the door . He stands on the bench , unlocks cabinet , takes out the bomb , puts it under his blouse , and goes softly out

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Sophie — Sophie — you do not regret ——

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: No , no ! Do n't , Adrian ! Forget all but love — love — love ! This is the last — the last ——

div.stage: Sound of trampling without , shrieks and noises . They start and listen . Korelenko runs through the room from right and out at street door . Vera comes on after him . Adrian and Sophie rise and look questioningly at each other . The guards lift their weapons . Adrian looks toward bench and sees that Vasil is gone

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Vasil !To VeraIs he in there ?

sp.speaker: Vera
sp.p: No , Adrian .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: He has gone out . He will be hurt .Looks suddenly at cabinet , which is openWho has been here ? Gregorief ?Stares at cabinet . Sophie 's gaze follows his . He turns to her , speaking slowlyThere was a bomb in that cabinet . Could it be possible — that ——

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: GentlyI am afraid it is true .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Never ! Not him !

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Adrian ! Beloved !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Not heeding herVasil ! Vasil !Staggers to seat by table , front , left . Guards keep by him . Enter Korelenko followed by Gregorief and others

sp.speaker: Vera
sp.p: Running to KorelenkoVasil — where is he ?

div.stage: Korelenko is silent

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Is he hurt ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: The boy — or ——

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: The boy .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Not hurt , but taken .

div.stage: Adrian throws his fettered arms upon the table and lays his face upon them

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Is Petrizoff dead ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Only a wound . This night belongs to hell . O , if it could have been as we planned !

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: No one is killed ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: No one but Orloff .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Orloff dead !Under her breathThen I am safe .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Gods , if only it had been Petrizoff ! His escape is unbelievable .Turning to AdrianWhat says the preacher now ?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Do n't ! See his fetters ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Ah ! When ——

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: Crossing to AdrianFortunate man ! Now he may develop his soul !

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: How can you ?

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: How could he , madam ? How could he ? Do you know what he has done ? He has killed every man that died in Yaltowa to-night — he has slaughtered every child — he has outraged every woman ! What else ? Freedom offered him her hand and he struck her to earth ! He has scattered her forces — he has strengthened her oppressor — and the rivers of blood that must now drench Russia shall flow from his door ! But — ha ! ha ! he has saved his soul !

div.stage: Enter Irtenieff , attended

sp.speaker: Irtenieff
sp.p: I want the prisoner , Adrian Lavrov .No one answers . He sees Adrian and crosses to himWhat is your crime ?Adrian does not raise his head

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: None .

sp.speaker: Irten
sp.p: You are arrested for the burning of Yaltowa ? All prisoners taken on that charge are free by the order of Petrizoff .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Take off his chains !

div.stage: At a sign from Irtenieff guards unfetter Adrian , who does not seem to know what they are doing

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Such an order from Petrizoff ? What does it mean ?

sp.speaker: Irten
sp.p: It means that he is frightened into saying his prayers for a day or two .

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Adrian , my dear one , look up !

sp.speaker: Irten
sp.p: To KorelenkoAnd if you 've a particular regard , as I 've heard , for the little beauty there , you 'd better get her out of Russia before his scare rubs off .

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: Thank you , sir .

div.stage: Exeunt Irtenieff , men , and guards left by Orloff . Dawn has been gradually breaking , showing through door and window , rear . Sophie continues to talk softly to Adrian and finally he raises his head

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: They will bury the sunshine of the world — shut up his golden years in darkness ——

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: We will free him , Adrian . We will live to set him free .

div.stage: Zarkoff , and Vasil guarded , appear at door

sp.speaker: Zarkoff
sp.p: Stepping inNow show your accomplices .Vasil stands on the threshold , silent , looking eagerly at the faces in the roomYou swore you would tell who helped you if we brought you here .

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: I will .

sp.speaker: Zar
sp.p: Pointing to GregoriefIs he one ?

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: Let me take my time . You would n't hurry on your way to Schlusselburg , would you ? I must speak to my friends first . Adrian — father , brother , master — the songs have all come back . When I only looked on , doing nothing to help , the music stopped , but now ——

sp.speaker: Zar
sp.p: Too many words , sir !

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: Now I am doing my part , I have a right to my song . They will take me to ——

sp.speaker: Zar
sp.p: Stop that !

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: And under the stormy waters my heart will be singing ——

sp.speaker: Zar
sp.p: Say your good-bys , and be done !

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: Put your ear to my violin , and you will hear ——

sp.speaker: Zar
sp.p: Come !

lg.l: You must yield something too , Adrian . Step back to the law of
Moses for vantage if you can leap to Christ with the world in your arms .

sp.speaker: Zar
sp.p: You have broken your oath !

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: I have not . I will tell you .

sp.speaker: Zar
sp.p: Speak then . Who are your confederates ?

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: There is but one .

sp.speaker: Zar
sp.p: Who ? Where is he ?

sp.speaker: Vasil
sp.p: He is here — in this room — he is in every prison in Russia — he is in every heart that knows the meaning of love — but if you want to arrest himstepping back into the sunlight and pointing upwardyou must go up there , for he is God .

sp.speaker: Zar
sp.p: That for your blasphemy !Strikes Vasil on the mouth with his swordOff with him !

div.stage: Guards take Vasil off . Zarkoff follows . Silence broken by a groan from Adrian

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Beloved , beloved , he shall be free ! The whole world shall help us !

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: May we knock down the prisons now , Lavrov ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: O God , in all thy ages can this be justified ?

sp.speaker: Kore
sp.p: You can justify it in a moment . Adrian Lavrov , this is your call to war . If you respond , his life is well lost .

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: War ?Staggers upYes . And I will use the strongest of earthly weapons , the arms of peace . The powers that upbuild are as invincible as the universe . By them it stands . Only by their toleration do the forces of destruction live . Toleration ? Only by the support of the powers of peace do the powers that destroy exist . Is not the army of the Czar fed by us , clothed by us , paid by us ? And if we refuse to give , must it not beg of us ? If he who works not shall not eat , what is the doom of the destroyer ? The sower shall not sow for him , the reaper shall not reap for him , the builder shall not build for him , the physician shall not heal him , the scholar shall not teach him , the lawyer shall not plead for him , no trade shall supply him , no craft shall assist him , no art shall amuse him . The mills shall be silent , the wheels shall not turn , the wires shall be dumb , until he cries out “ Peace , thou art master : let me be so much as thy servant ! ”

sp.speaker: A revolutionist
sp.p: Right ! This , too , is war !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: Yes . The new war of a new day . Not in madness hurling bombs , but giving our pity as we take our right .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: And who will pay your soldiers of peace ? Must not their women and children eat ?

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: The money we now pay to our brothers to strike us shall put bread in our mouths .

sp.speaker: A revolutionist
sp.p: Keep the taxes !

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: You join us at last !

sp.speaker: Adr
sp.p: No . We join each other ... under the only unconquerable power . Gather an army and go forth with guns , and you may be laid in the dust . But the gathered forces of peace are as the fingers on God 's hand , one with His strength , one with His will . Friends , friends , we have been searching earth for the weapon already in our grasp . The woman at the loom , the mujik in the field , the workman on the housetop , the man at the wire , the throttle , the wheel , hold it in their hands . To know its might — to use it together — that is all . Together ! O , they must see it — as I do now ! I will gather my disciples , we will knock at every door and preach the gospel of united peace until all our unions are one union , all our bodies one body , with one breath , one heart , one head . In barin and peasant , mechanic and noble , Christian and Jew , Finn , Pole , Czech , Serb , Georgian , Tatar , must be born as in one man the conscious strength of peace . And to its deliverance I give my life , my soul !Sits down . Sophie leans over himYes ... he shall be free .

sp.speaker: Greg
sp.p: Who has been searching Vasil 's violin , comes forward with a paper in his handThey shall all be free ! We will make no terms , we will accept no constitution , till every dungeon door be open , till we hold in our arms the brothers who have made freedom no longer a dream of the night but a song of the morning ! To them we owe the liberty that is dawning , and shall we tread the earth they give us while they perish beneath it ? Hear our latest martyr — the youngest of us all . Hear the “ Voice of Schlusselburg ! ”ReadsWe are deep , we are deep Beneath your swift feet That pass and yet pass With unfaltering beat ; But life has no sound That can deaden our moans , And no measure of ground Can bury our bones , Can bury our bones . We have given ye all But our lingering breath ,— The light from our eyes , The prayer at our death . The wine of the days , Drink it up , drink it up ! But our hearts , as the grape , We pressed for the cup , We pressed for the cup . Through the measureless sun Your seasons shall sway . Pluck the fruit as your own , Ye have nothing to pay ; For your summers of bloom Are the summers we 've lost , And we in our tomb , We pay the red cost , We pay the red cost . Your youths shall be wed And the maids shall be fair , But the tears we have shed Are the pearls they shall wear ; Your bride ye shall seek As never we could , But the rose on her cheek , It is dyed with our blood , It is dyed with our blood . The lips of your child Shall be warm on your own , But ‘ tis cold , it is cold , Where our babes lie alone . The hand of your friend In yours ye shall take , But look ye !— the scar Ours wear for his sake , Ours wear for his sake . The feast shall be spread And the world shall be there , But set at the head Our invisible chair . Ay , the banquet is ours , For our dishes make room ! Each baked by the fires Of a smouldering home , Of a smouldering home . We are deep , we are deep Beneath your swift feet That pass and yet pass With unfaltering beat ; But life has no sound That can deaden our moans , And no measure of ground Can bury our bones , Can bury our bones .CurtainTHE SIEGE A DRAMA IN FIVE ACTS CHARACTERS OF THE PLAY DIONYSIUS , the Younger , tyrant of Syracuse DION , a Syracusan noble ARISTOCLES , the Athenian friend of Dion OCRASTES , a young lord , attached to Dion HERACLIDES , admiral of Syracuse PHILLISTUS , an ambitious courtier CALLORUS , ÆGISTHUS , friends of Heraclides SPEUSIPPUS , from Athens , friend of Aristocles PANTHUS , captain of Dion 's Grecian guards DOMENES , captain of the tyrant 's guards TIMOLEON , ASCANDER , lords of Syracuse GYLIPPUS , MENODES , DRACON , citizens BRENTIO , slave to Dion TICHUS , slave to Aristocles ARATEA , wife of Dion NAURESTA , a noble lady THEANO , daughter of Nauresta METHONE , woman to Nauresta Soldiers , citizens , messengers , dancers , & c .

sp.speaker: SCENE : Syracuse , Sicily TIME : 356 B
sp.p: C .

div.head: ACT I
SCENE 1 . A pavilion in vineyard near Dion 's house . Enter Dion and

stage.stage: Aristocles , followed by Brentio and Tichus .

lg.l: That Dionysius bends the neck of pomp
To do you honor , shows an eye yet false
To your true merit .
But ‘ tis better , Dion ,
Than to have found his frowning archers planted
Point to our landing ship .
He 'd not have dared
To greet you so , but this vain , strutting show
Wrongs you no less .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Himself far more .

lg.l: Ay , friend .
The mines of earth into one coffer poured
Would not enrich a spendthrift or insure
Him linen for a shroud . If you can not
Prevail with him — If ? Nay , you will . All ifs
Lie down before your wooing argument .
I knew his father when the years had stripped
His agued soul , and his untutored age
Looked from a crabbed eye upon the world .
For him I would not have a second time
Foregone Athenian groves , but youth that keeps
An open door to Wisdom as to Folly ,
May even of Virtue make at last a guest .
My hope is born again , now you are here .
When I have seen pick-thank philosophers
At ear of Dionysius , seeding his mind —
Wherein my toil had set fair Ceres ’ garden —
With foul and flaunting weeds to overrun
My country , I have been tempted to forego
The idle reaping , uplay the soil itself ,
And with some few and trusted followers
Rouse a new Spring to breed us gracious harvest .
But he who strikes at heritage gives riot
Fair leave to play above his trampled grave ,
And rather than usurp a wrong with right ,
You bend your strength to make the wrong a virtue .
Ay , so the young tyrant has my knee , but thus
To keep my mind at bow and flexure proves
My patience ‘ fore the gods . Welcome the day
When I may honor Truth in honoring
The head of rule in my belov � d city !
But now no more of state austerities ;
I would be glad one hour and nurse the joy
Of seeing thee . Thou'st brought me half my heart
That kept with thee in Athens .
Well ?
My lord ,
The mistress comes .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: In happy season .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Mistress ?

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: My wife .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Art married , Dion ?

lg.l: Since you sailed ;
To Aratea , Dionysius ’ sister ,
But as unlike him as the eternal sky
To moody ocean .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Married ? That the word ?

lg.l: Fast bound , indeed , to one who will not break
Our souls ’ knit circle . She is Virtue 's servant ,
And wears her fairest flower , beauty .

sp.speaker: Tich
sp.p: Aside , as Dion looks off left to see if Aratea approachesHa ! A beauty ! I will warrant it . There be Some ugly wives i ’ the world but no man married ‘ em .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: To BrentioCome , sir . What entertainment is provided ?

div.stage: Dion talks aside with slave

lg.l: So goes my friend . He who was happiest lost
In the vast solitude of a noble book ,
Or Truth 's deep-pathed discourse . A wife . Is this
My journey 's end ? That little haven whence
No harbored sail dares sea ? Port of delay ,
And pocket of emprise , whose shallows oft
Have sunk the mightiest hope of greatest states !

div.stage: Enter a servant

sp.speaker: Ser
sp.p: To DionMy lord , the captain of the harbor waits .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: To AristoclesOne moment , friend .Exit , right

lg.l: That lordly soul a-dream
In woman 's arms ! That heaven-cleaving mind
At fireside tattle with a gossip dame !
Now comes the sunward ranging eagle down
To sit by nest , a tame prudential spouse .
Where sped the proud ambassador of morn
On wings that clipped the burning orient ,
Hovers the cautious mate at pains to find
A youngling 's breakfast .

div.stage: Re-enter Dion

lg.l: Come , my friend . You 're skilled
In harbor matters , and I need your word .

div.stage: Exeunt Dion and Aristocles , right

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: Is your wise man married ?

sp.speaker: Tich
sp.p: That 's a fool 's question .

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: True , but — Peace ! Yonder comes the mistress . I must be off . “ Entertainment , ” quoth my lord . Which means a gentle sally of honest nymphs , and a sort of mild , virtuous music at hide-and-seek in the vineyard . You must to court if you would know how wenches can trip in Sicily . Come , brother stranger . I 'll take care o ’ your enjoyments . You shall see us with both eyes , I promise you .

div.stage: Exeunt Brentio and Tichus . Enter , left , Aratea , Theano , Nauresta , Ocrastes and Phillistus

lg.l: I 'm not convinced , Phillistus . Who may search
The wreckage ‘ neath a smile , or count the tears
Deep in a stoic eye ? Let us believe
Aristocles is not in nature cold
As his philosophy .
I 'll freeze my sword
A winter night , then warm his heart by ‘ t. Cold !

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: You 've seen him ?

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: At the landing .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Now we hear ! What is this marvel like ?

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: A frozen god . Apollo cast in snow .

lg.l: Sicilian suns
Are warm .
He 's proof ‘ gainst sun . Why , he doth cool
His liver with his blood ,— hath not a stir
Of whetted sense , be ‘ t anger , love or pain ,
To prick him mortal .
He is young to be
So true a sage .
They come . Prepare , O eyes ,
To wonder !

div.stage: Re-enter Dion and Aristocles

lg.l: Welcome , noble Athenian .
Your fame has oft made voyage to our shore ,
And we rejoice that now you follow it .
Please know my friends .

lg.stage: To Aratea , as Aristocles greets the others
lg.l: Why is Phillistus here ?
Are we so poor , my dame , the enemy
Must sauce our feast ? Nay , nay !
I hope , my lord ,
My brother 's subjects are not enemies .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Who has stood apart , approaches AristoclesWelcome to Sicily , although your breath is somewhat frosty for our warmer pleasures .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: As Dion frownsThe frost that draws the poison , saves the flower , you mean , my good Phillistus .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: A fair interpreter !

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Ay , when we know not our meaning , let a woman find it .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Which she will do the more readily if we mean nothing .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: True , her wit is generous . She 'll always bait a hook that angles painfully .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Though she , good soul , must hang herself upon it .

div.stage: Theano and Ocrastes move aside , bantering . Aratea turns to Phillistus and Nauresta

lg.l: Ocrastes is a youth full dear to me .
Orphaned at birth , I 've bred him from a babe .
He is of bravest heart , and must leap high
Although he fall o'er heaven .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: And the maid ?

lg.l: The daughter of my brother some years dead .
Her bloom might make e'en priestly blood forget
To pace with vows , but she is true , and kneels
To wisdom 's star . Hast yet no eye for woman ?

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: For all things fair . That is my staff ‘ gainst age . We 're young so long as we love beauty .

div.stage: Aratea moves to Dion and Aristocles , leaving Nauresta and Phillistus together

lg.l: See
This feathered snuggery ?

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: A vine-lark 's nest .

lg.l: Touch ‘ t not . We 'll lose a song by you . ‘ Tis strange
These dare-wings build about our heads , when they
So fear us .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Farther . Birds are not my study .

div.stage: They move aside

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: Frowning again , my lord ?

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: And reason for it . I like not yonder pairing .

div.stage: Looks at Theano and Ocrastes

lg.l: Would that your plans
Might leave them happy !
False ? I 'll not believe it
Of thee , Nauresta . I 've given thee confidence
As open as the ungated dawn ; unlocked
My secrets ; fixed within your breast , as in
My own , my darling purpose !
‘ Twas my counsel
In Aratea 's ear that brought you hither .
And why these dark reproaches where I hoped
To see the color of your gratitude ?
What 's done , though ne'er so well , but makes a way
For what 's to do , Nauresta .
Ah , my lord ,
I know not how to please you .
Learn . To me
Be wax , and adamant to all touch else .
Mad Dionysius is in revels lost ;
Dion is far too stern for common love ;
Between the two my hope makes fair ascent
Above the clouds of state . ‘ Tis I must reign .
Then we , my queen , must see our daughter wed
To some strong noble who will prop our power .
Ocrastes ’ love is bound inseverably
To Dion . Keep him from Theano , sweet .
Look on them now . See how she bends to him ?

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: Nay , she is modest , sir .

lg.l: But mark ! He speaks ,
And crimson runs her cheek , as though his voice
Did paint it magically , which bids him fair ,
For know you not that love on blushes feeds
As plundering bees on roses ? He is sure !
‘ Twill task you hard to ward from port who bears
So bold a sail .

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: But I will do it . Ay !

lg.l: Again you are all mine !
lg.stage: Nauresta moves to Theano and Ocrastes
lg.l: Thus do I woo
The mother , with the daughter in my eye .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: To AristoclesAh , yes , I know you 'll cast fond sighs toward Athens , And in the night look through the dark to her — A myrtle-crown � d bride without her lord — But yet our land , too poor in Ceres ’ smile To outwoo Acad � me , may show some charm To ease your banishment .

lg.l: O , ‘ tis an isle
That ‘ neath the eye of Zeus might bloom nor blush
Save at his praise ; yet holds within itself
Treasure that ornaments its cruder worth
As gems make eyes in stone ,— a friend whose hand
Leads Virtue 's own , and woman 's beauty crowned
By starry mind as I ne'er hoped to see
Till at the port of the immortal world
My eyes should meet my dreams .
What now ? So soon ,
Aristocles ?

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: My lord ?

lg.l: I knew she 'd find
The gate to your forgiveness .
My tongue creaks
Amid this piping .
True , she 's fair enough
For praise , but I 'm a plain prose lover , friend ,
Nor , like a doting osier o'er a brook ,
Pore on her features , wasting oil of time
That should burn high in task of gods and state .
I 'll cast a pebble in this summer pool .
Sir , you will find our Dionysius worthy ,
The proud descendant of a prouder sire ,
Upholding well his shining heritage .
Worthy I hope he is , but even kings ,
My lord , may wrap them in humility ,
Nor boast descent , when demigods of earth
But bastards are in heaven .
Ay , some of us
Should curvet not so high , bethinking of
Our audience in the clouds ; for this brave world
Is but a theatre whereto the gods
For pastime look , and whoso makes most show
Of plumes careering and proud-lifting stride
Is but the greatest anticker of all
To their high eyes . A little music , friends .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: And in good time ! A sermon then a song .Enter dancers , the two in advance bearing urns which they place on a small altar , singingBring cedar dark , And ruby-wood , Bring honeyed-bark , The Naiad 's food , Till altar flame And incense rise In friendship 's name To seek the skies .Chorus by maidens bearing wreaths of olive and laurelMyrtle leave on Venus ’ tree , Nor the Bacchic ivy see ; Olive bring , and laurel bough . And may hours that gather now Of his years fair token be !

div.stage: They bow before Aristocles and continue dancing

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Watching ArateaThe sun has made a shrine of her bright hair Where eyes would worship , but her fairer face Lures their devotion ere they gaze one prayer .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Crossing to AristoclesAristocles , I swear yon dancer 's foot , Curving the air , marks beauty of more worth Than all the fantasies of dream you write On heavens conjectural .

lg.l: It suits you well
To treat the theme deific with bold tongue .
No thought so high but you would trick it out
In shrugging sophistry !
Farewell . The court
Has always welcome for me .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Farewell , my lord . And Ceres send you grace !

lg.l: Beware , proud Dion !
The topmost limb makes an uneasy seat .
Who perches there must take account of winds ,
Lest dignity go forfeit to surprise .
By Jaso , sir , your cause is fallen sick ,
Nor Athens emptying all her wits may heal it !

div.stage: Exit

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: My lord , a little patience ——

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Patience , madam ! Would words were meat for swords ! I 'd had his crop !

div.stage: Enter a royal messenger

lg.l: Most noble Dion , greeting from the king .
He begs you 'll bring the Athenian sage to banquet ,
And see some shows within the royal gardens .
More revels ! More ? This cracks the very glass
Of our fair prospect , wherein we saw him sit
With listening ear to wisdom .
No !

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: My lord ——

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Say to the tyrant I 'll not feast with him .

div.stage: Exit messenger

lg.l: May I be bold to say this is not well ?
I fear , my lord , your stern , imperious port
Is much against you in our easeful city .
If on occasion you would smooth your brow
To patient lenience you in time would win
All hearts to wear the livery of your purpose ,
That now shows cold and sober for their mood .
Not so ! The bending tree ne'er kissed the clouds .
I will not stoop ! What ? Flaunt his sport before
A sage 's eye , who comes at his own suit
To teach him truth ?
Yet we must not forget
Discourteous truth is hated ; vehemence ,
The whip of argument , but frights conviction .
Pardon so stale a word .
But ‘ tis so true !
The winding zephyr , not the hurrying gale ,
Finds out the hidden rose . My brother 's heart
Has yet a grain of good , which gentleness
May find and touch to life .
It was the slight ,
The unseemly slight to you , Aristocles ,
So chafed me .
Think but of our charge , my friend ,
Fair Syracuse .
So , so ! I say no more .
Your wisdom be to me Athene 's shield
Whereby I 'll see to strike this head of wrong
Nor be devoured . Come , we will walk abroad .
But not to court .
My wishes wait on thee .
May Fortune dress thee for a second self
Till eyes mistaking seek thy face for hers .
Nay , let her wed thee , and like loving wife
Give all her portion , then empty-handed pluck
New grace from heaven to adorn thee still .

div.stage: Exeunt Dion and Aristocles

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: Now , Aratea , the song of praise ! Which of the gods is he most like ?

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Like none of them . Jove is long-bearded , Neptune has forgot to walk , Mercury is boyish , Apollo like a woman , and Mars so heavy-footed he would stumble mocking the grace of Aristocles !

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: ‘ Tis plain a curious eye will never take you to Olympus , since you 've seen the Athenian .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: I own I have a sudden comfort from this gentle sage .

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: You know my Dion has one only fault .

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: O , all but perfect man !

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: He is so true that he is stern as truth .

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: That 's truth indeed !

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: So just that he is harsh as Justice ’ self .

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: Another truth !

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: So good that ——

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: What ! More of this singular fault ?

lg.l: This Athens ’ tongue , so sweetly mediate ,
Will lead the people 's love unto my lord ,
Who now upholds the state in thankless sort .
They honor and admire , but keep their hearts
For those who woo them ! Ah , I blame them not .
Dion need borrow no Athenian tongue
To speak for him .
You 'll hear no voice denies
Him perfect praise .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Who would deny it ?

lg.l: None ,
Ocrastes , none . How like a gem unpriced
His rich simplicity doth shine amid
The purpled show of lords ! It is as though
The sovereign alkahest , weary of law ,
Had given the scorn � d pebble leave to glow
The fairest eye of all the pearl � d shore .
They 'll sing us deaf , Nauresta , on this theme .
But come .
Come , madam , come ! We must prepare
Some good-wife pleasure for my lord 's return .

div.stage: Exeunt Aratea and Nauresta , left

lg.l: My love ! At last ! O goddess Patience , how
Thou muffledst me ! Time crept on thousand legs
And each one crippled .
Ay , so slow the hour
Moved to this golden now I thought each moment
Turned back to seek some loss and spent itself
A second time .
Now all the world 's at morn .
How young we are , Theano ! O , ‘ tis true
Life is at tick of dawn when love begins .
I 'm older then than you , for I ‘ gan love
The day you won the laurel from proud Carthage .
In the wild race how like a shooting star
You made a heaven of earth 's grosser air !
And ‘ twas that day I heard old warriors say
Your lance would dare prick ope the clouds till Mars
Looked forth to combat . Ah , I scarce believe
Our island 's easy lap did bear you , and thank
The gods that wealth , whose poison-pampered tooth
Likes best the marrow-sweet of youth , has left
You still a man .
Truth weeps when lovers talk ,
But where is sound more sweet ? All that I am
I owe to Dion . Give to him the praise ,
If praise is due , and you would please me best .
Thy approbation is my glass of merit ,
And there alone am I array � d fair ,
Yet for his sake , not yours , I love lord Dion .
‘ Tis wonder 's hour in wonder 's day he should
So fit his life , despite the careless time ,
To please the gods .
When shall we tell him , love ,
Of this new joy of ours ?

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: My mother first .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Didst note her frown ? What has so changed her , sweet ?

lg.l: I find her troubled late , as she would soothe
Her breast above some panting mystery .
She must disclose the cause , and show if ‘ t has
An honest face . I 'll have no mincing doubts
And ghostly secrets peering on our love .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: She is our gentle mother . Wait , my heart !

lg.l: Phillistus is too often at her ear .
Have guard against him . In his smoothest words
He 'll subtly seat a devil to confound you .
‘ Tis pity . Eloquence is the flute o ’ the soul ,
Which virtue alone should play , for good or bad
It has immortal consequence .
He was
My father 's friend , and well may be my mother 's .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Ah , but he coos too near her widowed nest .

lg.l: Ocrastes ! Can you dare ? My noble mother !
Whose sorrows sit like shadows in her eye ?
Whose loyal breast asks no embrace less chill
Than the cold tomb where my dear father lies ?

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: ‘ Twas but a word .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Unsay it , O , unsay it !

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Ay , by our island 's god , ‘ twas never spoken !

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: I 've scarce a breath , Ocrastes .

lg.l: And that breath
This kiss must drink . You will forgive ? Speak not .
These clinging lips have told me . A kiss , Theano ,
Unseals all secrets but to be their grave .
Then we know all , and all we know 's forgot .
‘ Tis saying true , a kiss is worth the world ,
When , having it , there 's no world but a kiss .

div.stage: Re-enter Nauresta and Aratea , left

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: Crossing to TheanoStill here , my daughter ?

div.stage: Enter Brentio , right

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: O , mistress , the master is coming with Dionysius . Since he would not take the Athenian to court , the court is coming hither .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Here ? ‘ Tis a strange declension of his pride .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: I fear ‘ tis cover for a thrust ‘ gainst Dion .

lg.l: No ! Virtue such as his is heavened above
The reach of sceptres .
But he was too bold
In his refusal to attend the feast .
They come ! And Dionysius ’ brow is like
A new , unclouded sun . No eyes for us !

div.stage: Enter Dionysius , Aristocles , Dion , and lords

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: To AristoclesSpeak on , nor cease t ’ enchant my rous � d ear , Although thy words , like honey from the isle Where Ate fell , are something mixed with bitter . But give me not to virtue suddenly , Lest she disdain the greening , unripe fruit , And from her sun I do forever fall .

lg.l: Heed then his counsel , Dionysius .
A ruler is the state 's bountificer ,—
High warden at the gates of happy good ,—
And when he turns unto himself the stream
That should make fair his country , he is damned
As oft a robber as his subjects count .
Each man he meets may claim his golden coat !

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: What 's your rough meaning , sir ?

lg.l: ‘ Tis this , my lord .
Here is a land born in a dream of Nature ,
And given to man to please her waking eyes
Until she thinks that yet she dreams . His task
To build the adorning temple , turn groves retired
To happy shades where wisdom meets with youth ,
And with triumphant art set statued thought
To gleam abroad from every favored spot
Till e'en the flattered gods be tempted here
In marble fair to wait on mortal eyes ,
And genius roam in generation free ,
Breathing the constant good of mind aspiring ,
Till not a clod , be it or earth or human ,
But knows a smile to make itself more fair .
How should it grieve thee then to see the pomp
Of one , sole , only man heave with the weight
Of all the state , and wear in barren pride
The fertile beauty of his golden isle ?
Divine Athenian , if I be that man ,
Be thou the master of my realm till I
Have learned what ‘ tis to be one . Teach me here
My first new duty .
Check debauching riot
That sluices now the palace ! Cease these feasts
That fume to heaven like Hecate 's brewing-vats !
Nay , sir , those scowls unwrite your waterish vow .
Our Dion means , my lord , that virtue wanes
As revels wax ; and yet an hour of rest
The gods allow us . I myself have trained
Young figures for the dance that wreathes with grace
The needful , idle hour .

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: You leave us music ?

lg.l: Ay , ‘ tis the angel ‘ tween the sense and soul ,
A hand on each , that one may feel the touch
Of purest heaven mid rosy revelling ,
The other catch sweet trembles of a wave
That shake her calm till white cheek meets the rose .

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: And feasting , sir ?

lg.l: Nay , there 's the soul 's expense
For what o'erdims her fair , majestic visions ;
But fruits of sheltered vales grow lush for man ,
And awny grasses droop with sugared grains ,
And wine , tempered to reason 's flow , oft lights
The questing mind .
Enough ! No groaning board
That shifts its burden to the spirit ! No revel
To pleasure Pleasure ! Naught but what is meet
For fair philosophy 's relaxive hour !
Adrastus , see ‘ tis done . Go instantly !
Dion , you 're for the harbor ?
Dion With your leave .

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: Which we must grant . Your business is our own .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: With you , my lord ?

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Most welcome son . Adieu .

div.stage: Exeunt Dion and Ocrastes

lg.l: Brother , ‘ tis long since you have visited me .
I hold a magnet now in our new friend
Will draw you to my house .

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: Nay , I must rob you . The palace is his home .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: O , not to-day !

lg.l: I 'll yield to-day , but not an hour beyond
To-morrow 's sun . Adieu , Aristocles .
Give me thy love ; I 'll give thee Syracuse .

div.stage: Exeunt Dionysius and lords

lg.l: We have some statues in the garden , sir ,
May please an eye from Athens . Will you come ?

div.stage: Exeunt Aratea and Aristocles

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Mother , why look so darkly on Ocrastes ?

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: Darkly , my daughter ?

lg.l: Has he not a soul
As truly virtuous as his face is fair ?

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: True , but he 's not for you . Believe it .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Ah !

lg.l: Nor grieve my heart with pleading to know more .
Some day I 'll speak , but now my bosom 's locked
With key not in my hands .
Mother , I pray
You 'll give no more a flattered , willing ear
To lord Phillistus ’ tongue .

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: I do not know . I am disturbed by him . I scarce can tell you how .

lg.l: To call him friend
But proves my loyalty to the loved dead .
I do not doubt my mother ! No , no , no !
But him I fear . His eye speaks muddily ,
And echoes not his words .

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: No more of this ! You prattle , child . Say that he loves me ——

lg.l: Ah ,
Not that !
Yet were he villain , is not love
The soul 's sweet cleanser and redeeming incense ?
The serpent and the bee make food and venom
Of the same flower 's sweetness ; so fair minds
In love enlarge with merit , while villainy ,
Sucking such sweet , swells rank and poisonous .

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: No more , my daughter !

div.stage: Enter courtiers , right

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: Good-day , my lords ! You are early from the play . Did it not please you ?

sp.speaker: First courtier
sp.p: Tame , tame . I 'd not have left my couch at the bath for such . And Dracon 's tongue was middle of a pretty tale .

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: But the banquet — why stayed you not for that ?

sp.speaker: Second courtier
sp.p: Have you not heard ? The seven evil winds have struck the feast , and left but fruit and wine . My wife 's as good a cook . Can serve a plate of figs !

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: What 's this ?

sp.speaker: First courtier
sp.p: As we say . Our delectable gardens are smit with sudden prudent frost . The mullein and the plantain shortly will grow where we have plucked luxuriance ’ rose .

div.stage: Enter Aratea and Aristocles

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: What do you mean , my lord ?

sp.speaker: First courtier
sp.p: Looking at AristoclesThe wind is all too near that wrought this havoc .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Nay , have no fear for Dion . You wrong this hour of promise . Your brother yields us much .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Indeed too much ! These sudden born desires are to be feared in him . Ah , here 's Ocrastes .

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: He 's much disturbed . I know that brow .

div.stage: Re-enter Ocrastes , right

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Ocrastes ?

lg.l: Now heavens shake for what mine eyes have seen !
I followed Dion to the southern shore
Where the new pinnace floats beneath the castle ,
And there Domenes held him in close talk ,
When suddenly ere wink could question it ,
The soldiers had him bound within a boat
Outrowing to the pinnace , which took him up
And bent to sea like an embodied wind .
But that a score of traitor arms enforced me
The waves had kept me not on hated land !
Surprise so stormed him Dion scarce could call
“ Revenge me not , but seek to calm the city ! ”
Then from the pinnace a relenting boat
Brought this short writing . ‘ Tis for Aratea .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Read — read — Ocrastes — I — I can not see .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: ReadsAristocles will be thy comfort . Bid him not forget Syracuse to think of me . Now that the thorny counsellor is plucked from court , he can do much with Dionysius . Ocrastes will be to thee a brother of more love than ever was the tyrant . Sweet , farewell . ‘ Tis from thine eyes I 'm banished , not thy heart .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: O Dion , Dion ! My unhappy lord !

lg.l: Abate thy grief , dear lady . Affliction is
The night of man where stars his lustrous soul
That in a happy sun would pale unseen .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: My brother ! ‘ Tis his treacherous hand ! O , me ! Now heaven and earth be naught , I care not !

div.stage: Exeunt Aratea , Nauresta , Theano and attendants

sp.speaker: A courtier
sp.p: Come ! There 's more to this .

sp.speaker: Another
sp.p: Ay , friends , let 's to the streets .

div.stage: Courtiers hurry away . Ocrastes and Aristocles alone

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: I 'll rouse the populace !

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: No , you will calm it .

lg.l: Sir , I was knit in heat and tempered mortal !
Your natal star was cold when you were born ,
Dead in the heavens , had long forgot its fire ,
And could not give one twinkle 's warmth to you !
I 've blood , and know my friends !
Dost think that sorrow
Lives only in hot brows ? No angers be
That rage not on the tongue ?

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: O , you can feel ?

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Here sweep the tides that prove it .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Yet so calm ?

lg.l: Who keeps his heart astir with his own woe
Has never room for others . Let us put
Our paltry love aside and seek the good
Of all the city , not of one because
He is our friend . Think not a man may leave
Life 's reefed and breakered straits behind and reach
Philosophy 's still-waved almighty sea
With selfish sorrow 's mottled pilot eye .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: And you 've a mortal pulse ? Can love and die ?

lg.l: I am as you , Ocrastes ,— heart and limb ,—
But I have given my kingdom to my soul ,
And throned secure above the body 's chance
Rock not with its misfortune .
Who can keep
Such sovereign state , my lord ? Art never torn
Or shaken ?
What hap of winds , think you , may shake
The monarch towers of the soul ?
Forgive me ,
Aristocles . Thou sun immovable !
How like Hyperion fixed in calm you shine ,
And riot 's faction in my blood grows still
With looking on thee . I 'll to court and strive
