With sober measure to effect repeal
Of Dion 's banishment . And failing that ,
I yet may save for him his untouched wealth .
Is it not lonely on the serene height ,
My lord ?
The gods are sometimes there .
The gods ?
Vain words on vainer tongue . O , man , man , man !
Weak child of limit and unwinged desire ,
Coping with deity in daring bout ,
And drowned at last within a woman 's tear !
... Hyperion fixed in calm . Ay , true it is
That in the heaven of my sphering mind
I 've reached the pause solstitial . And would fain
Take comet course on new , unbidden track
Than traverse o'er the stale appointed route .
Ay , break the orbit 's fond and placid round ,
And swim a wonder to the staring suns !
The end is death ,— and yet a comet 's death .
The rushing wings are round me , bear me up ,
And drive me like a meteor charging doom ,
When Aratea veils me with her eyes .

div.stage: Enter Tichus

sp.speaker: Tich
sp.p: Aside , noting Aristocles ’ groanHo , for ill that 's past and ill that is to come , philosophy has ever a saw , but in a present pinch speaks not for groaning !... My lord , the lady Aratea asks for word with you .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: HesitatingTell her ... I come .

div.stage: Curtain

div.head: ACT II
SCENE 1 . An outer court , Dioniysius ’ palace . Two entrances to

stage.stage: palace on the right . Columns rear . Sea and sky seen between them . Behind columns a street . At left a garden . Speusippus and lords pass from street toward garden .

lg.l: Dion , my lords , has gathered friends in Athens ,
And waits your invitation to set sail
With power for your relief . Six circled moons
Have risen from the sea since he was banished
And you are dumb as you were staring yet
Upon the marvel of his taking off .

sp.speaker: First lord
sp.p: What is his life with you ?

lg.l: He walks a mark
For Athens ’ eye ,— a breathing virtue , sir ,
Making the good in other men stand still
To gaze at what in him is better .
This
Is his true color .
True ? By Pallas , sir ,
Apollo purges not more ardently
The earth of humors than he iniquity
From man and state ! Divinity has made
His heart her brooding place to bring forth deeds
So like her own complexion that men read
The book of Heaven in them and grow wise
Without the aid of schools .

sp.speaker: First lord
sp.p: We know our loss .

sp.speaker: Third lord
sp.p: The tyrant sends him his great revenues .

lg.l: Which Dion casts like sweet and general rain
On parching poverty . His charity
Is a perpetual summer where bruised merit
Lifteth in flower .

sp.speaker: Second lord
sp.p: So was it here .

lg.l: And you
Could have him home had you some brave Greek blood
At heart . Please you , I 've heard a shepherdess
Combed wool on Dardan plain when Troy was burning
Methinks Sicilian sires bred from that dame .

sp.speaker: First lord
sp.p: By Zeus , this is bold rating .

lg.l: ‘ Tis our due .
‘ Twixt caution 's pause and the delay of shame
Lies but one step , and Syracuse is on it .
Courage grows agued and hunches at the hearth
Forefearing enterprise .

sp.speaker: Speu
sp.p: Can you be still ?

sp.speaker: Third lord
sp.p: No more , my lord . Here 's Dionysius .

div.stage: They move into garden as Dionysius enters from street with Aristocles and other lords , and turns toward palace

sp.speaker: First lord
sp.p: He 's well attended .

lg.l: Ay , let tattered vice
Step out o ’ door and contemnation hoots
It home again , while silken viciousness
May march as ‘ t will ‘ tween meek uncovered polls ,
With Flattery 's footmen running neck and neck
To open any gate .

sp.speaker: First lord
sp.p: True ! true !

sp.speaker: Speu
sp.p: Talk ! talk ! A sword 's the tongue for me !

sp.speaker: Third lord
sp.p: The tyrant speaks . Hark , friends !

lg.l: Aristocles , excepting thee
No man alive might teach me hate myself .
Say what thou wilt , I 'll love thee !

sp.speaker: Third lord
sp.p: Fair enough .

lg.l: Fair in the flower , but no fruit , my lord .
The fragrance sickens . A sound wholesome deed
Were pungent sniffing !
Sir , upon the soil
Of this fair courtesy I 'd lodge a seed
Might bloom with Dion 's pardon .
Pardon Dion !
By Delos ’ horned altar , no ! My tongue
Compound my own destruction ?
Sir , your tongue
Is bound to you , but I could wish it had
A wiser master .
Roast me in the bull
Of Phalaris , if I be such a fool !
Thou know'st that he conspired against me !

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Nay ——

lg.l: With honey breath you steal into my heart
But to betray it !
I pray your leave to sail
From Sicily . Greece hath a place for me
Above insult .

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: Go when you will . To-day ! Our admiral shall bear you .To HeraclidesHear you , sir ? Choose out your ship . Aristocles , farewell . Talk not of me i ’ the Acad � me .

lg.l: My lord ,
The gods take care we 've no such dearth of matter .
Farewell .

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: As Aristocles turns to goDost mean it ? Nay ! Spoil not my jest . Canst take offence from one who loveth thee ? In truth wouldst go ?

lg.l: The winds that fan me hence
Will be as welcome as the breeze that lifts
The sail of calm-bound mariners that long
Have in mid-ocean rocked and dreamed of food .

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: No , no , my friend ! Thou shalt not go from me ! Dost call thyself philosopher , and take First chance to fly thy duty here ? Hear you , Lord admiral . Watch every gate nor let This bold man pass . Sink the Sicilian fleet Ere you do spare a ship for hire or pity To grant him sail and beggar me of friends , For all my friends are corporate now in him .To AristoclesTalk not of parting while you have my love . Cold yet ? Go seek my sister . She will bring Your high look to sweet friendship 's level . Go . Yours is the only tongue can draw her from Her tearful reticence . Tell her the stars Will find me with her . I have news too new For pale indifference . ‘ Twill rouse her wrath Or pleasure .Speusippus and companions pass from garden to street and off leftHa , what Greekish stranger there ?

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Speusippus , sir .

lg.l: Methought his acid look
Had turned my purple cloak a pauperish yellow .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Aristocles best knows him . An Athenian .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Who is slowly going into palace by smaller entrance , front , turnsAnd worthy of his birth . He is my friend , And brings me Dion 's love .

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: That name again ! ... Well , thou ‘ rt my soul .

div.stage: Aristocles goes into palace . Dionysius turns to larger entrance rear

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Detaining HeraclidesA word with you , my lord .

div.stage: Dionysius and attendants enter palace

sp.speaker: Her
sp.p: What 's urgent , friend ?

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Marked you Speusippus ?

sp.speaker: Her
sp.p: Ay .

lg.l: He comes to stir a war in Dion 's name .
Already there 's a rumbling ‘ mong the people
That warns us to be swift .

sp.speaker: Her
sp.p: My fears have caught it .

lg.l: The tyrant 's mood is ripe . See how he loves
And hates Aristocles ? This is the hour
To move him to the Athenian 's death .
You 're right .
When friendship oars ‘ tween choler and regard ,
A crafty hand may steer which wish � d way
Sets wind of secret business , and he
That rides be none the wiser .
The Athenian
Removed , then Dionysius is our own .
Well have short need of him . The tyrant 's guards
Are envious of the Greek to murder 's pitch ,
Because he counsels Dionysius
To cast them off and rule by love alone .
The captain stands our friend , his sword aloft
To fall as turns the hair .
The guards must do ‘ t .
The people hold them privileged in humors ,
And say not yea or nay to them . But does
Callorus join us ?

sp.speaker: Her
sp.p: He yet hesitates .

lg.l: Then cease your suasion and to his easy state
Clap screws will cramp . Pain is the orator
Can clinch his case and drive the question home .

sp.speaker: Her
sp.p: You 'll to � gisthus ?

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Ay , though we 've a difference . A trifle that his vanity may stand on .

lg.l: Make your excuse , but study how you do it .
Faults oft are none till clapped conspicuous
With an apology .
I 've learned of you .
None has a tongue more apt to come at love
‘ Neath what ill cover hides it . Dionysius
I leave to you . My name use as ‘ twere yours .
My sum of wisdom is to know your own
And trust you wholly .

sp.speaker: Her
sp.p: That you may , Phillistus . My fame rests on this move .Exit

lg.l: Your fame , good sir ,
Has naught to do with what I close intend .
By Victory 's wings , I 'll reach the top of power ,
Or from her golden ball knock Fortune 's foot
And steer her course myself ! Now to Nauresta .

div.stage: Goes into palace , front entrance . Brentio , Tichus and Methone enter merrily from garden . Brentio carries a large harp . They sit on benches left

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: These are merry days since Dionysius brought us to the palace . I would weep for my poor banished master , for they say a far country makes a weary foot , but there 's so much laughing matter here — the singing and the rhyming , and the pretty wenches tripping your eyes up at every corner , that my tears are no more out than I 've good reason to whip them in again .

sp.speaker: Meth
sp.p: O Venus ! There 's no laughing here save of your dreaming . Dost see how the courtiers scowl ? They say the scholars and philosophers leave them no dancing room in the palace ; the halls are full of sand for the pleasure of the students that come to draw those foolish figures — plates , they call em ——

sp.speaker: Tich
sp.p: Geometry .

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: That 's your master 's doing . Thank the wise man for that !

sp.speaker: Meth
sp.p: It suits our mistresses well enough . They blink at a smile as an owlet at the sun . Troth , I 've seen them weep so much that I feel wrapped in a fog with the vapor of their tears .

sp.speaker: Tich
sp.p: But let us be merry . No more sad airs , my sweet Methone .

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: AsideI like not this sugary possessive .... Play , my own sweetest Methone , and I 'll sing you a song out of head .

sp.speaker: Meth
sp.p: Pray you , sing it not out of feet too , for a limping line is past carrying .

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: ‘ Tis a song of you and will go fast enough , I warrant .

sp.speaker: Meth
sp.p: ScornfullyOf me ?

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: Nay , of your jewels !

sp.speaker: Meth
sp.p: An you mock me , I 'll ——

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: Touching his lipsYour rubiespointing to his eyes, your diamondsgrinning to show teeth, your pearls .

sp.speaker: Tich
sp.p: You may sing that song when diamonds wink tears , rubies pucker for kisses , and pearls bite figs i ’ the morning .

lg.l: Well , I 've a better one .
Her voice is like the birds that wive
When blossoms swing in April trees ,
And from her bosom 's honey hive
Sighs come and go like bees .
Her smile ——

sp.speaker: Meth
sp.p: Nay , I 'm no farm-house sweet for loutish Corydon ! How would you sing me , master Tichus , were I in Athens where every maid is fair ?

sp.speaker: Tich
sp.p: With more truth and less boast .

lg.l: Your song , sir .
Heigh-ho , my star of love
Has left its heaven high ,
And all the beauteous court above ,
To dwell in fair Methone 's eye .
And now , alas , unlucky bliss ,
It finds a home so bright
That all its beauty buried is
Within that fairer , cruel light .
No more , no more it shines for me
But as she gives it leave !
O , bid thy stars , sweet maid , agree ——

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: Ho , if heaven had no stars save those left by lovers after fitting up their mistress ’ eyes , Erebus would stumble for want of candles !

sp.speaker: Meth
sp.p: Jumping upGo ! I hear my mistress !

div.stage: Tichus walks leisurely into garden , Brentio following

sp.speaker: Meth
sp.p: Brentio , take the harp !

div.stage: Brentio returns and picks up harp

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: So ! I 'm an excellent dromedary , if I can n't flute it like Apollo .

sp.speaker: Meth
sp.p: Run , snail !

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: Not I , by Vulcan 's limp !

div.stage: Theano appears at smaller entrance of palace

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Methone ?

div.stage: Brentio runs into garden

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Coming outYou here , Methone ? Attend the lady Nauresta . I fear your pleasure and your duty lie Too far apart .Exit Methone , rightOcrastes , come ! My love ! Fair clos � d flowers that wait the royal dawn Ere they will sport with beauty 's open face Are as my heart that caseth up its joy To wait thy voice .The day darkens to dusk . Theano looks into the garden , suddenly eagerHe 's coming ! No , he stops To talk with Brentio . How close they whisper ! What is ‘ t he gives the slave ? For shame , bold eyes , To spy upon a lord so true ! What was ‘ t Phillistus said ? No matter . It was false .

div.stage: She moves aside as Brentio crosses to palace

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: Jingling coinsO sweet , sweet gold ! Art mine — all mine — my love ? And will I do it ? Ay ! I 'd sell my soul To such a brave paymaster .

div.stage: Enters palace

lg.stage: Coming on right , not seeing Theano
lg.l: Vile , too vile !
Let me not think of it .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Ocrastes ?

lg.l: Ah ,
My never-setting star !

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: But you are troubled . Hast news ?

lg.l: Rumors , my girl . They 're in the air
Like floating poisons . O that Syracuse
Had one man in ‘ t !

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Look in my eyes and see him .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: One sword in one right hand !

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Here , in my eyes .

lg.l: I see a dallying , damn � d temporizer ,
Who stops to count the threatening dragon 's teeth
Ere reaving him of head .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: My love , what is it ?

lg.l: Still Dion lingers , playing the game of wits
In idle Athens , while scandal eats his name ——

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Ocrastes !

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Yes , I said it .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Ah , you mean ——

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: I mean ——

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Aristocles .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: O , Dion , Dion !

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Speusippus says he comes .

lg.l: Too late he comes
That should be here already .
Dear my love ,
He is not young as you , and years are cautious .
While age makes ready to resent affront
The blows of youth are given and forgot .
Ah , my Theano , I 've but one place of peace —
Nay , I 've not that — your pity-housing bosom .
Though � olus ’ thirty sons made centre round me ,
There should I rest as on a summer cloud
Rose-covered by the toil of flying doves
To keep off heaven 's tears . And you deny it !

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: My own !

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: You do not love me !

lg.l: Hear him not ,
O patient Heaven !

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Come to me , Theano .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Not while my mother lives to suffer for it .

lg.l: My love , as nature runs , she must die first .
Forgive my rudest tongue — but will you then —
When so she goes — bring all this heart to me ?
I 'm tortured lest her bitter will against me
Should reach back from the tomb .
Ah , my beloved ,
The wounds we give the dead must fall unfelt .
Then why should senseless graves wound life ? Ay , then —
Unhappy happy then — I 'll be all yours .

div.stage: Enter Methone , right

sp.speaker: Meth
sp.p: Mistress Theano , your mother is strangely ill . I pray you , come .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: O me , my fatal word !

lg.l: Nay , ‘ twas our watchful star moved me to urge it .
Let me go with you , love , and strive once more
To win the picket of her bluff regard .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Not now . Wait here until I come again .Exit Theano

lg.l: The silken bud that holds a treasured world
Uncaskets nothing in the hour of bloom ,
But fans the air with its own waste of leaves .
Even so my hope , that with the swelling year
Pressed to a summer crown , unfolds on naught
And prodigal of self to naught is come .

div.stage: Goes into garden . Stars appear in the sky visible beyond columns , rear . Servants come out of the palace and set lights about the court . Enter Aratea and Aristocles from palace , front . They cross to rear and sit between two of the columns

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Aristocles — my Dion 's friend and mine — rest upon your soul and feel encirqued By silent potence , like the quietude Of heaven when gods are still ,— when prayers come not , And enters no desire . So strange — this peace . My infant eyes oped on a shaking isle , And I was cradled in my father 's wars . O soon , too soon , I knew woe 's touch of death ! But these are living days — days to be wreathed With memory 's stars , and circled new each morn With pearls iridian from regretful eyes That they — such days — can pass .

lg.l: Eternity
Looked once upon the world , where lingers yet
Some brightness of her eye that we call Time .
Can aught so fleet hold value of thy tear ?
Thou who hast the immortal heritage ?
I can not say . Your mind in heaven sleeps ,
And by the day you but recall your dreams ;
While I , my lord , couch not so gloriously ,
And from the earth must speak .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: O , not from earth ——

div.stage: Re-enter Ocrastes

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: To OcrastesWill you not sit with us ?

lg.l: Nay , I 'll rest here .
lg.stage: Lies down on one of the long seats
lg.l: I know you talk of Dion , and one who loves him
Brings no intrusive ear ,— or if it is ,
‘ Tis deaf with weariness .
He 's tempest-racked
Between his love and friend . Ay , me , the world !

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: I 'll leave you now . No more of my poor thoughts . You 're wearied with long listening .Rises

lg.l: O , sir ,
Your thoughts are flowers and your words their fragrance ;
I do not hear but breathe them . Pray you , stay !

div.stage: He slowly resumes his seat . She looks silently at the sky . He writes on tablet

lg.l: Aristocles , thou wilt be god of gods
When thou ‘ rt among those stars ; but now , O friend ,
Come nearer earth . Be mortal for my sake .
I 'm fearful when you 're gone , or when your soul
Keeps court so far above me .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: I 'll read to you .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: What you have written there ?

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: No — no — ‘ tis nothing .

lg.l: Ah , do not read to-night . I am so lonely
That even with a book I would not share thee ,
Though it should tempt with the most wondrous hap
Of bard or lover caught in liquid line .
You 've travelled much ; tell me an Egypt tale .
I 'm weary of nymphs , and piping shepherd songs ,
And the ever-wrangling gods of blue Olympus .
Then hear the tale of Isis as ‘ tis told
By the prophet-cradling Nile when Lotus buds
Upbreathing blow new seasons of old dreams .
Not e'en our Venus , dove-led , invisible ,
More softly moves to Paphos wood than she
O'er sleeping earth . Her wings lead on the light ,
And when she lifts them dawn awakes .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Fair Isis !

lg.l: She seeks her brother , self-created , slain
By his own pride , for he was God of All .
Her tears , like weeping music , sweeten earth ,
Nor rests she till she finds him .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Sister Isis !

lg.l: And then — none knows how hid in solitude
She suckles death with life till he new rises
The God of All , too great for pride , too just
For death ; the sire of Beauty , breathing Life
Through Love ,— soul of the nurturing sun —
The mother-breast of fields — the parent thrill
Of birds , of trees , of flowers — of all that makes
Most sweet the fair world 's mortal pageantry ,—
Yea of the eternal , vital glow that throbs
Within humanity 's deep-rubied heart .
So runs the myth , dear Aratea .
Ah !
How runs the rubric of thy thought that sets
The symbol plain ? Read that to me , I pray thee .
The lonely mind may not uprafter stars ,
And vain , adventurous man who of himself
Createth Heaven must see it fall . Then doth
The woman spirit , girdle of the worlds ,
Above the ruins cry ,— his mate forgot
Who from his flesh by love 's divinity
Calls forth the beauteous eternities
To star the globe of life .
Which is to say ,
As simple people speak in Sicily ,
A man must wed !
Ocrastes , talk not so !
Like stars that may not range below the zenith ,
His meaning keeps the orbit of high thought ,
And will not dwell in gross and simple words .
Ho , mistress Dion , you too would like to spin
Your cobwebs round the moon !
Get you to Athens ,
While you may say to Dion she is true !
O , ay , I know what you would say , my lord .
You would not love Aurora though she dropped
Her morning mantle at your feet and blushed
Herself revestured . No ! But Aratea !
She has a human heart ,— eyes that can fill
With tears ,— soft hands that love the thing they touch ,—
A body that might be the ivory cup
Delight doth use to dip and measure out
The rose-flood of her pleasure . Go , I say !
Take to the sea , and leave no track my sword
May follow .
Sir , forgive his madness ! Ah ,
He is distracted by these wrongs to Dion .
I have not told you , friend , that Dionysius
To-day seized all possessions of my lord ,
And stopped all moneys to him . In this deed
Ocrastes reads the preface to new woes ,
Which shakes his mind 's security and gives
A living color to his fantasies .
lg.stage: Aristocles stands gazing out , not showing his face
lg.l: But Heaven and I know your white soul , my lord ——

div.stage: Enter Callorus , from palace , larger entrance , with guards

lg.l: Your pardon , worthy sage and fairest lady .
I come from Dionysius , whose care
Has bared a plot against Aristocles ,
Whom he for safety bids repair at once
To the castle fort , where he must rest to-night
In sure protection of the royal guards .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: The guards ? The royal guards ?

lg.l: You will make haste ,
My lord ? Before the people move against you .
Hearing that Dion has set sail with troops
To level Syracuse , they think ‘ tis by
Your aid and counsel . Pray you , lose no time .
I 'll go with you , Callorus . Not from fear ,
But to keep riot down that else might shake
The city 's peace .
Farewell .

div.stage: Exeunt Aristocles , Callorus and guards , by street

lg.l: Farewell ? I could not speak .
The tyrant 's guards ! They hate Aristocles .
My fears have now a shape and short will show
Their foulest face . I must take means at once
To learn the truth . My careful Dionysius ,
I will be vigilant too .
lg.stage: Turns to go in . Picks up a bit of paper
lg.l: ‘ Tis what he wrote
And said ‘ twas nothing . O ,— a pretty rhyme !
Thine eyes are on the stars , my Star !
Would I might be
That heaven far
With thousand eyes on thee !
He is a poet . Ay , ‘ tis but a rhyme .
And yet — ‘ tis very pretty — I will keep it .

div.stage: Re-enter Ocrastes from garden . He approaches Aratea as if he would speak , but she hurries into palace , entrance front , without seeing him . He retires in gloom as Dionysius and a train of lords come out of palace , large entrance , rear

lg.l: Come , friends ! Now is the sweetest garden hour ,
When day 's dust-foul � d trail is passed , and night
Has not yet donned her moist and heavy cloak .
Here let us wait the lords . We 've summoned all
Of golden purse and of right noble line .
Now that we 've stopped all revenues to Dion ,
And this night give our sister to a husband
Of our own choosing ——

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Dionysius !

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: Ha ! You , Ocrastes ? Know to whom you speak !

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: My lord , you would not dare ——

lg.l: Not dare ? That word
Is strange to me . Will some good scholar here
Tell me its meaning ?

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Pardon , mighty lord . I sought to warn you that the wife of Dion ——

lg.l: Your blood moves hotly off in Dion 's cause ,
And warning from our chief suspected foe ——

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: This arm has fought your battles , sir !

lg.l: Ay , so .
Would we might rank your famous valiancy
Once more with us , but while we doubt your heart
You are our enemy .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: What proof , my lord ——

lg.l: We 'll find it soon enough . Till then have care ,
And dainty walk ‘ tween wolf and precipice !

div.stage: Dionysius and lords go into garden

lg.l: No cry this wrong would give the sea new tongue ,
And mend the winds with utterance ! But now
No time for sighs and groans . The tyrant 's brow
Is hung with murder 's cloud . I must be quick
Or lose the breath ties me to upper earth .
Action must take the vantage now of thought ,
And reason follow after .

div.stage: Re-enter Theano , from palace

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: I was long . ... She 's better now , and quiet .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Better ? Who ?

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Who ?— O ! My mother .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Fie , does she yet live ?

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: O gentle gods !

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: All women now should die .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Ocrastes !

lg.l: Do not stare . Thine eyes are not
The only home of agony . Farewell !
Farewell ? No , no !
You 'll tell me first ! What is it ?
Will you not trust me ?

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: ‘ Tis thy trust I want .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Thou hast it .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Swear ‘ tis mine .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: My lover !

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Swear ! Thy trust ! Thy perfect trust !

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: ‘ Tis thine . I swear it .

lg.l: Though fiends of doubt hail thee on every side ,
Venting their slander from the mouth of winds .
Yet wilt thou trust me ?

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Ay , my lord , I will !

div.stage: Lords begin to enter from the garden

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Once more to-night I 'll see thee . Go !

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: My love !

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Go , go !

div.stage: Theano goes into palace . Dionysius comes from garden . Ocrastes moves aside and stands in shadow

lg.l: ‘ Tis time our sister should be told
Our happy purpose .

sp.speaker: A lord
sp.p: She is here .

div.stage: Aratea re-enters , and hastens across to Dionysius

lg.l: My brother ,
I came to seek you . Lord Aristocles ——
Ay , troubles press upon us , dearest sister ,
And much is trembling in adventure 's hand .
Now do we need your husband 's strength to meet
Ill fortune 's tide .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Then you have sent for Dion ? O , you forgive !

lg.l: Speak not that traitor 's name !
He is the foe ‘ gainst whom I must go forth .
You are to wed a lord whose might shall be
My own . To-night ! Dost hear ?

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Ay , Dionysius .

lg.l: And art not pleased ? No thanks that I provide
For your forsaken state ? Now , now ! One word .
Stand not so fixed , as I had ordered you
To instant death .
You make me marble , sir .
Unloose my soul 's locked torture with the key
Of one retracting word , or I must seek
In kinder stone my sole relief from pain .
O , say it is not so ! This is a jest
Will make you weep when you ——
Jesting to fools !
Not thron � d skies can change what we 've determined .
This rebel brow shocks my fond heart that toils
In your ungracious service . Come , my friends .
All to the council hall ! With me , my sister .
O , brother , not one moment to look back
And say farewell to Heaven ? Not one to gaze
Into the darkness ere I plunge to hell ?
And let the hour ‘ tween my intent and deed
Lay meddling finger on my purpose ? Nay ,
You know me better , madam . On my lords !
Delay 's the whetstone sharpens best the blades
Of enemies .
Go , sir ! I am myself .
I will not move . If you will tear me hence ,
And drag your father 's daughter at your feet ,
Then you may take me to the council hall .

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: Your pleasure , sister . Here we 'll hold our court . Go , Clitus , to the steps and turn all hither .

lg.l: Art thou my brother , Dionysius ? Nay !
We are of different mothers . Now I know
We are of different fathers , too .

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: You dare ! Silence thy slanderous tongue !

lg.l: I say thou ‘ rt not
My royal father 's son !

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: His sword is mine !

div.stage: Seizes her in a rage , threatening her with his weapon ; then slowly releases her and she sinks to bench by pillar of the colonnade . Lords assemble , some talking excitedly but in undertone , others cool and scoffing . Speusippus and friends enter , taking inconspicuous place . Ocrastes keeps in shade , motionless and unnoticed .

sp.speaker: A lord
sp.p: Ha , Calisthenes , you need not come to bite at this bait . ‘ Tis a dainty morsel and only goldfish are allowed to nibble . An old lord . I mislike this marriage . ‘ Twill bring us woe , let it reach Dion 's ears .

sp.speaker: Another
sp.p: Ay , wars beyond our guess will come of it .

sp.speaker: Young lord
sp.p: The admiral against � gisthus ! Second young lord . Heraclides ? He is much wived already . Third young lord . The easier to take another . Second young lord . � gisthus bids most fair . I take you .

lg.l: My friends , would that I had for each of you
So fair a sister , and were not thus forced
To choose among you . Who is first to speak ?

sp.speaker: Her
sp.p: I pray this gift , my lord .

lg.l: Brave admiral ,
You would stand high , perhaps the highest with us ,
Were't not that old wives make new enemies .

sp.speaker: Icetes
sp.p: I 'm free to give my undivided heart .

lg.l: But , good Icetes , age is creeping on you .
We want a fighting arm as well as heart .
Who else ? No voice ? Must we then hawk her up ?
Look on her , gentlemen ! Even tears may not
Disfigure her . This fit of sorrow past
You 'll see her smile again , those wondrous smiles
You 've longed in secret to make all your own .
A week , a day , will put some spirit in her .
To you , my lords of Syracuse ! Think not
To wed the wife of Dion as she stands .
You 'll pluck no rose in me . This face I 'll sere
With constant travelling tears , till Beauty here
Shall search in vain for memory of herself .
My wealth I 'll fling upon the air to birds
And beggars . Ay , my palace shall take wings !
My costly robes I 'll cast into the street
That common women may adorn themselves .
I am no princess . I refuse the name
Of aught that makes me sister to that wretch .
Go seek some linen washer by a brook
And find a wealthier and a prouder wife .

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: Spoke I not truth , my lords ? You see how fast Her spirit grows . Hear her sweet names for me ? Now we 'll have bidders plenty . Thanks , my sister . She 'll sing , my lords , when once she 's neatly caged . � gisthus . I beg ——

sp.speaker: Callorus
sp.p: My lord ——

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: ‘ Tis fit you both should speak At once , for both alike sit in my favor . � gisthus ’ lands are broad , but you , Callorus , Have proved a mightier leader in the field , And all in all you do deserve alike . There 's none may rank above you .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Stepping outOne , my lord . � g . There 's none !

sp.speaker: Callo
sp.p: Let him come forth !

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: Who , sir ? His name .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Ocrastes .

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: You ? � g . Ha , ha !

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Why not , my lord ?

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: You 're Dion 's heart . You cast him off ?

lg.l: You ask
For proof ? I take his wife . Were I to warm
My fingers in his blood , I 'd have more hope
That he would rise and bless me than to keep
His love while she lies on my bosom .
Ara . O !

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: I challenge any here to match my claim . This is the sword , my lord , that held the city Against the Tarentines when these brave nobles Trembled behind their fast shut doors . � g . ‘ Tis false !

lg.l: All know ‘ tis true . Since boasting now 's a virtue ,
I 'll do it well . Who wore the laurel wreath
That saved all Sicily a spreading blush
The day the Carthaginian youths were sent
Defeated home ? You ask for wealth ? My vineyards
Run to the wilderness . My corn now greens
On � tna 's slope and yellows by the Gela .
My father 's coffers are unopened yet ,
And ships are sailing here will fill my own .
My slaves might meet an army , and I 'll put
A sword in every hand for Syracuse .
In rank I bow to none . The blood of Pollis ,
First king of Syracuse , runs yet in me ,
And even Dionysius ’ royal self
Yields to my line the birthright courtesy .
Enough . Now Dion 's cause falls down . Enough !
Come to our heart , Ocrastes ! There 's not one
We 'd rather win to us .
O , Dion , now all
Forsake thee but calamity , that like
A covetous ill wife hangs on thy fortune !

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: By Pluto , no more fear ! Our throne is safe !

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: My lord ——

sp.speaker: Diony
sp.p: Nay , brother !

lg.l: Pray be warned by one
Who knows too well your need . Not all the troops
Of broadest Sicily may keep you safe
When Dion comes from Greece . Men swarm to him
As he were golden Saturn giving off
New fortunes with each breath . Send me with speed
To Italy . There I have friends shall be
Your own , and pour a fleet into your harbor
Will turn lord Dion pale when next his eye
Scans Syracusan waters .
Italy ?
We 'll think of it . You 're the true warrior stuff ,
Planning campaigns with the same breath you win
A royal bride . We like you better for it ,
But she may like you less . Give her a word .
O , fairest woman that ever made the earth
More sweet and beauteous to live upon ,
You 'll find in me a true and gentle lord .
These tears I 'll teach to run a smiling race
And in a happy death forget their birth .

div.stage: Attempts to embrace her

lg.l: Open the prisons , call some convict forth ,
And I will wed him , but not you ! These lords
Have hated Dion , have not lived upon
His constant kindness . You have drunk his love
Like flowing wine , and lived by it !
Rail on ,
If railing pleases you . In aftertime
You 'll love the better for it .
Right ! Give her leave ,
And she will stroke you where she meant to strike .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: You love Theano !

lg.l: Ah ,— I did , perhaps ,
A thousand years ago . All now 's forgot
But that thou mayst be mine .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: O , false ——

lg.l: O true !
What was scarce fair to unpossessing eyes ,
Perfection is when gods have made it ours .
Thou wilt forgive me that I loved thee not
While thou wert Dion 's , for my eyes were sealed
By loyalty to him . But this divorce
That frees thee gives me sight . I see , and love .
And by that love still dost thou grow more fair .
For is not love a second , truer eye ,
Finding out beauty where the first could not ?
No more ! We 'll plead hereafter . ‘ Tis an hour
To win , not woo . Swords must be burnished , sails
Must meet the wind !
Are you Ocrastes ? No !
O , no ! He is the son of Dion 's love ,
And you would wed his wife . He was a poor
Forsaken babe , his mighty heritage
Plunder for any thief . ‘ Twas Dion then
Became his father , gave him life and wealth ,
And that sweet breeding that till now did show
So fair in him . Ocrastes owes him all ——
Ay , all ! E'en wisdom . He would call me fool
Stayed I from market when thy richest self
Courts any passing bid . Since he must lose ——
Nay , every touch will be a three-fold shame
Robbing a husband , benefactor , friend .
My eyes will mirror those reproachful days
When Dion 's care was fond about us both .
His kisses guard my lips . His praise of you
Will block your words in my assaulted ears .
You know me not . My words shall be love 's fire
Burning the track of Dion 's pale discourse .
My kisses on your lips hold festal war
With his till they , poor ghosts , shall flee . And dews
Of happiness shall wash all pictures out
From your fair eyes but my enthron � d own
Which hourly I 'll new-set in their fair glass !
I called you brother !... O , my lords , I beg —
Some one of you — to take me for — your — wife .

div.stage: Faints . Ocrastes supports her . Curtain .

div.head: ACT III
SCENE 1 . A chamber in the palace . Nauresta on bed asleep .

stage.stage: Phillistus watching .

lg.l: This poison 's swift . Here is her cup . Why palter ?
A drop will do it .
‘ Tis when we sleep the touch
Of life is gentlest . Even affliction 's kiss
Falls like a rose upon the sense-shut lid .
Then he most miserable is as the happy ,
And who so happy that is not then more blest ?
And since that death is sleep 's eternal sum ,
Why should I pause , nor grant this precious good ?
O , I could moralize me to a god
Who holds the cup of bliss for lip beloved .
Nauresta , drink , and in this little drop
Sip everlasting ease .
‘ Tis done . I 've reached
From mortal shores and opened Hades ’ gate .
Ay , with the gesture of a hand have hooked
Eternity .

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: WakingPhillistus , you ?

lg.l: ‘ Tis I ,
Beloved Nauresta .

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: Flowers ! You have brought them ?

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Can I forget you love them ?

lg.l: Ah , my friends !
They wear no frown to dash down hearts ; nor chide
When ears are sick for quickening praise ; but yield
Their royal payment for each passing care ;
No vagrant dew gives them its moistening heart
But they must pay it thrice in perfumed beauty ,
And bury it as never king shall lie .
O human faces , might ye turn to flowers ,
How many broken hearts would live again !
This is a covert chiding of my faults ,
So deep repented , love . I 'll make thee happy .
My gentle daughter — she that I could call
A sister to this rose — her mute complaints
Cry like dumb , wounded birds to my sore heart ,
And I pass by nor help . For what , Phillistus ?
That you may wear a crown in Syracuse .
A crown that is the golden nest of cares ,
Brooded by every dismal wing may hatch
An enemy to peace .
And when didst grow
So wise , Nauresta ?
Midnight hours teach well .
Some sleepless nights would help you too , I think .
Wise ? Ay , and not too late ! I 'll be no more
Your shield while you make thrust at brave Ocrastes .
I 'll give him my Theano .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Does he know ?

lg.l: Not yet . I weakly thought to pay old love
The grace of first confession .
Thanks for that .
This sudden turning of a heart long loyal
Has left me numb . You know how dear my purpose
That she should wed a lord of my own faction .
Give me an hour , but one , before you speak .
You break the bough that held my care-built nest ,
And old wings go not blithely after straw .
They 've learned to wait , and who would count an hour
Before the long day of unbroken love ?
... I 'm weary now , Phillistus .
Rest thee , sweet .
Ah , not too soon I spiced her cup . The way
Grows perilous , and I must mount with care
To my high seat , lest I should rise to fall ;
For though the path to crowns be long and slant ,
There 's no way down but by a precipice .

div.stage: Enter Theano bearing an urn which she places on table by cup

lg.l: You 're faithful , sir .
Her brow is calm again .
Now were I ill ‘ twould quickly make me well
To have so fair a face above my bed .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Hear , my lord , you 'd die ere mine should be there !

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Surely ‘ tis no offence to call you fair .

lg.l: Beauty lives not upon your commendation ,
Nor with your silence dies . Spare me , my lord ,
The cymbal clap of words that add no jot
To fairness .
Pardon me , dear girl . I was
Your father 's friend ——

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: I strive not to forget it .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: And could I have your love ——

lg.l: All that is good
In you I love . Now thou'st the measure , sir ,
For my affection . Is it small enough ?

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: By heaven , you do not mince it !

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: WakingIs that my daughter ?

lg.l: See , mother , I have brought this drink for you .
lg.stage: Pours beverage into cup and offers to Nauresta
lg.l: There 's health in ‘ t. Is there not , Phillistus ?
Ay ,
Health and long life .

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: There 's virtue in the cup . Even now I 'm better .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Now ?

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: O , I could rise !

div.stage: Sits up

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: No , dear . Be patient yet .

lg.l: Nay , I 'll be up !
Pray call Methone , love , to dress me .... Ah ,
Whence comes this lighter heart ? How good to have it !
I feel like a new-pardoned prisoner
Tasting the air . Smile , sweet ! Those lily lids
Shall droop no more with woe I lay upon them .
Now , now , Methone , make me young again .
O , not that robe ! Tis for a grandame that .
My sky-gray mantle with its falling softness
Broidered like sunset clouds !

div.stage: Exit Methone

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: I beg you , sweet ——

lg.l: Wilt smooth my hair ? Nay , let it be as ‘ tis .
This way . Ah — now —
O ! Help me ! Help ;
Let go , ye furies !

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Mother !

sp.speaker: Meth
sp.p: EnteringMistress ! mistress !

sp.speaker: Nau
sp.p: ‘ Tis poison ! poison ! I am murdered . O ! My daughter — tell her — tell her — ah — Ocrastes ——Dies

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Have mercy , Heaven ! O , Phillistus , help her !

div.stage: Faints . Phillistus holds her

lg.l: Go call your comrades here .
Even now you 're mine .
Ocrastes ! Ha ! Her last word was his name .
I 'll turn this crook of fortune to account ,
And make a god of accident .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: RevivingO ! O ! Misfortune makes my heart her sanctuary . So many woes take shelter there .

lg.l: One woe
You have escaped . Ocrastes ’ wicked love .
O villainous ! I dare not think of it !
That he would poison one so dear to you ——
Man , man , care for your soul ! There is no stain
So black as when the gall of calumny
Breaks on the snow of virtue ! You must rate
Your precious life at naught . Ocrastes , sir ,
Will have your slanderous heart for this !
He may ,
If ‘ tis your wish . You heard her cry his name
As though she saw her murderer .
She cried —
Ah , yes — I heard — What did she mean ?

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: The truth .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Make me not mad !— He 's never entered here .

lg.l: Why should he when a little gold will buy
A hand for any deed ?
The gold — the gold
He gave to Brentio ! Dear Juno , help !
My mind strays from me .
Hast not found him changed ?
Full of quick passions — contradictions — words
Of broken point ? Seen shadows on his face
As though his mind were brooding darker matter
Than could be kept within ‘ t ? Bethink thee well ,
For memory 's eye reflective oft repeals
The confirmation of the grosser sight ,
And what so pleased the entertain � d sense
Shows in her studied glass a fearful front .
O , stop thy tongue of death ! My promise to him —
So strangely asked — so strangely given ! O !——

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Thy mother 's word ——

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: O , let me die , die , die !

lg.l: My girl , all things that be may be endured .
Death does not come for this or that affliction ,
But when ‘ tis time to knock . Up , sweet Theano !
By fortune 's rudder , wheel and horn of bounty ,
You shall rise fair above this foul mischance !

div.stage: Re-enter Methone

sp.speaker: Meth
sp.p: My lady , lord Ocrastes begs to see you .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: No , no ! Not now .

lg.l: Ay , see him now , Theano .
Show him the burden of this bed , nor let
The damn � d simulation of his eye
Deceive you . Bravely tell him to his face
None better knows the gate she came by death .
You lie !... And yet I can not see him now .
Though he is innocent , my wicked promise
Burns like accusing fire by this dear form .

sp.speaker: Meth
sp.p: Mistress , he comes !

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: I 'll leave you with him . Courage !

div.stage: Phillistus retreats to curtains , left . Enter Ocrastes

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: You dare come here ?

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: I dare ?

lg.l: O , see , Ocrastes ,
What lieth here ! The shell of what even now
Was she who gave me birth .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Not dead ? Ah , love !

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Call me not love ! Not here — and now . O , go !

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Theano !

lg.l: Touch me not ! My doubt will make
Your hand a thing of fire !
Dear heart , fend off
This sea of woe or ‘ twill sweep reason with it .
I could be wild with strange things that I know ,
And came to tell you of , but for your sake
I 'm calm .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Dost know , sir , she was poisoned ?

lg.l: Poisoned ?
Forgive me , love . Be mad now as thou wilt ,
Still thy distraction will be stinted measure
For grief so dark . Poisoned ! O , who ——

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Who ? Who ? That is the question thrusts me like a sword . All loved her — all . She had no enemy .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: CalmlyYou spoke of doubt . What did you mean , Theano ?

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Leave me , Ocrastes ! Go !

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Phillistus ——

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: No ! He loved her well . That was his touch of Heaven . O , who had cause but ——

lg.l: Do not say it . I go .
Not deity descending from the skies
To make our peace could now unite us . Ay ,
Thou ‘ rt dead to me as that cold body .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Oh-h !Swoons

lg.l: And in that bosom did I come to set
A purpose I 'd not whisper now to death
Lest his dumb lips should tattle . Alone — alone ,
To grapple in the dark the beast of chance !
... Affection on my track shall ache to death ,
Friendship in blood lie mute , and love I 'll tear
From its high heaven to plunge like Ate 's coals
On Pluto 's fire !
Sweet girl , he 's gone .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: RisingWhere is he ?

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: He 'll trouble thee no more .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Heat me the irons ! This tongue shall be burnt out that dared accuse him !

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: She 's mad indeed !

lg.l: Nay , sir , the cloud of pitch
That blinded me is gone .
Touch her not yet .
Methone , hasten Brentio to find
The noblest lord in Syracuse .

sp.speaker: Meth
sp.p: Who , mistress ?

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Who but Ocrastes ? Go !

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Approaching herTheano ——

lg.l: Sir .
We have no need of you . I pray you , go .
He will forgive , then I will die with thee !
Nay , by the gods , should you so die , my maid ,
Then Sicil ’ will have groaning cause ‘ gainst one
Who robs her country to make rich her grave .
Immortal Beauty must herself go wronged
Should you so break her living mould in you ,
And drain her veins to your fair body trusted
For warm and deathless passage .
Are you man
Or monster that you foul this hour with thought
So gross ?
A man — no more , no less — who loves
Your mother 's daughter . Hate me as you will ,
I here adopt your grief ,— with oath and tear
Take it to love as my own child of woe ,
And swear you faith to death .
The gods , my lord .
Record not oaths of men till they 've received
The confirmation of an act . I 'll wait
Their seal on yours .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: This night ——

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Sir , will you go ? Stay not to rouse Ocrastes ’ rage .

lg.l: You think
He 'll come ?

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: I 've sent for him .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: You 're proudly sure . Will coo your loves by this forbidding bed ?

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Ay , for her hovering shade knows now the truth .

div.stage: Enter Heraclides

lg.l: Pardon , my lord , that I have sought you out .
The hour like an unbridled courser needs
Strong hands upon it . Ah ,— death here ?
There lies
Delay 's excuse ,— and yet ‘ tis none , for woe
Whose feast is but a heart should lift no head
Beside the large calamity that makes
A morsel of a state . How goes our matter ?
Aristocles is locked within the castle ,
In care of Dionysius ’ guards .
Ah , then
He 's safe .
As safe as we could wish , my lord .
And I 've yet fresher news . Ocrastes joins us ,
With wealth and courage like an Atlas back
To bear our venture .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: He revolts from Dion ? Ocrastes ?

sp.speaker: Her
sp.p: He , my lord .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: What works this change ?

sp.speaker: Her
sp.p: A lady 's morning cheek and golden hair . He now is wed to absent Dion 's wife .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: What say you , sir ?

lg.l: The lords were in debate
Of who should have her , when out comes Ocrastes ,
And cries his claim with such o'erhYpppHeNriding proof
That Dionysius claps a quick assent
And all the court confirm him sullenly .
Ocrastes goes to Italy for troops
To meet the force which Dion brings from Greece ——
But this new marriage ! Tell us more . Belike
I 've missed some sport .

sp.speaker: Her
sp.p: Sport ? Ha ! It was a scene .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: But went the lady to him willingly ?

lg.l: O , she was modest , played chameleon
And chang � d color rhythmically , as though
A music of sweet shades sat on her cheek ,
Then coyly swooned , but her reviving eye ,
Methinks , looked kindly on his youthful beauty .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Watching TheanoAnd the young lord ? Did not his countenance Play hers a blushing match ?

lg.l: Ay , shame and will
Mapped out his face between ‘ em , but short met
In love 's red constancy .
The . O ! O !
Once more
The lady fainted , but ‘ twas in his arms .
Ha , ha !

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: And yet I live !

lg.l: How long , my lord ,
Since this bold comedy ?
‘ Tis now two hours
Behind us .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: To TheanoAh , before he came to you ! What shameless shame !

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: He loved me ! How — O , why ?

lg.l: Nay , ask not why . As well essay to trace
The legend that the soft and curling foam
Writes on the shaken wave as fix love 's path
With steady eye or his vagaries mark .
Farewell an hour . I 'll come again to-night
To serve your grief . You 'll learn at last to trust me ,
And in my heart seek comfort .

div.stage: Exeunt Phillistus and Heraclides

lg.l: Oh , oh , oh !
He does not love her . Would he did ! I then
Might honor him that dared dishonor truth
For love 's almighty sake ,— but ‘ twas to save
His life . Ah , me , his life that sav � d thus
Abates all value and becomes as clay .

sp.speaker: Meth
sp.p: Sweet mistress !

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: O , O me !

lg.l: Stay this hot flood .
Tears bring no lover back . Ay , not though maids
Should weep until their cheeks were but a mead
For two salt brooks to play .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: O , leave me !

sp.speaker: Meth
sp.p: Nay ——

lg.l: Leave me , I say ! Away !
O death ! O life !—
Which wears the darker face ? Here is my choice .

div.stage: Falls by Nauresta 's body
Curtain

div.head: SCENE 2 . A bare room in the castle fort . Aristocles alone .

lg.l: They said a bed would be provided me ,
But nothing 's here . And nothing 's all he needs ,
Who holds himself a soul stripped of the world
And its necessities .
That fellow took
My cloak . Good luck to him . Philosophy ,
Thou art the only sail no wind may drive
Into misfortune 's port . How still the world !
The silence like a great Accuser stares ,
Full of dumb curses looking from large eyes .

div.stage: Rises and walks

... I will not see her more . O , quickly come , Ye stoic angels wont to wait on me , And with the cords of resolution stout Bind ye my purpose to the throne of Zeus That it may shake but with Olympus ’ self ! ... Will she not think me harsh to leave her so ? She who is made of all earth 's gentle things — The scent of morn , the first green on the bough , The valley dews where infant blossoms drink , The going light with rose heart yearning back ,— Yet brave , and like a new Hippolita Might wear the belt of Mars . O , flower of heaven , Yet wrapped in soft and strange delirium Of odors once Elysian ! Naught to me , Who will not see her more . Now is she dead , And I know but a grave . I 'll sleep ... sleep ... sleep .
Lies still . Enter Aratea . She is veiled , and her unbound hair falls about her form

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Drawing inner bolt to doorI scarce could bribe the guard to let me pass !Looks about room and sees AristoclesAsleep ?Crosses to him . UnveilsRise , friend !

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: StartingMy dream .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Aristocles !

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: RisingYou ? you ?

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: I , friend .

lg.l: ‘ Tis you — and yet ‘ tis not .
A stranger soul , disordered and unknown ,
Looks from your eyes .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: My brother 's false to thee . This castle 's murder 's trap , and you are caught in ‘ t !

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: I 've had some thought ‘ twas so . I die to-night ?

lg.l: No , no ! dear Heaven ! See !
This inner room .
It has a hidden stairway to the sea
Where waits a boat will bear you to a sail
New-spread for Greece , with crew that know the wave
As though begot of mermaids .
No ! To make
Presumptuous end of life is an offence
To Heaven , but gracious gods may offer death
For honorable choice — as they do now —
And here I choose it .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Thy choice then must be mine . My hope was you would fly and hasten Dion To my deliverance . For I am sold . The cords of bondage cut in very flesh . But ask not now of this . This letter here Will tell my lord what I have spared you . Go , Or I 've no hope , and then — by this bright blade —showing a daggerI die .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Ah , what you will ! Command me .

lg.l: Come !
Into this chamber !
lg.stage: Exeunt , and in a moment re-enter
lg.l: O , the door new-sealed !
Apollo help us now !... Did you not see
The narrow window in that chamber ?
Ay ,
The stars looked on us as we passed , as though
They smiled to see how man would measure time
With periods clept death .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: FearfullyIf you — could leap ——

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: I will .

lg.l: Tis not far down — but O , the rocks
Jut up like monsters . No ! You shall not do it .
‘ Twere death with treble pain .
Then I 'll die here .
To go from your fair presence to the gods
Is hardly change .
‘ Twould change the world that lost thee .
Then would this isle uncrown herself of joy ,
And palsying shake beauty from her lap .
The flowers would die in pain , and every leaf
Fast wither , fade and fall , as those that moan
O'er Thracian Phyllis ’ grave . I will not stay
Without my friend . Ah no , ‘ twould not be life .
The longest days are breaths , quick-drawn and short ,
The longest life a day to be forgot .
Thou soon wouldst come .
I could not find the way .
‘ Tis with your eyes , not mine , I catch the light
Unalterable upon immortal brows
And keep my course .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Nay , thou'st no need of guide . Shine out , bright soul , and dim thy troubling stars .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Turns aside , weepingYou do not know !

lg.l: Be true unto the calm
Of Heaven in you set . Who trust to aught
That 's of their souls externe but give themselves
As feathers to the wind .
My lord , this night ,
By Dionysius ’ force , my hand was given
In marriage to Ocrastes . Dost thou hear ?
Ocrastes sails this hour for Italy .
Ere he returns ——
Thou'st whirled away my soul !
O stroke of Dis ! O faithless Heaven ! He ?
Not he ! Such mid-hell treachery is out
Of mortal meaning !

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: He is mad , I think . He loves me not .

lg.l: I 'd sport a madman too !
Wear lunacy as doth a king his purple ,
If that would draw a goddess from the skies
To quiet in my arms ! Did it not strain
Forbearance to the snap that Dion — whose wisdom
Humbles the mouth of Zeus — whose justice is
The boast of shades when Rhadamanthus blunders —
Should wear the chiefest pearl to mortals cast —
Sweet Beauty 's sole extravagance — as ‘ twere
A something to be stained with human love
And gods not question it ? Who then could see
It made the common booty of a thief ,
Nor break the cable of a mind controlled
And lose the shore of reason ? Who ?
Be calm
If thou wouldst help me .
Pity , weep , weep , weep !
O , from thy woeful heaven cast a dew
As universal as the East when she
To every herb throws pearls !

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Leaping upThe guards ! They come ! But I go with thee , sir . ‘ Tis not farewell .

lg.l: Not you . I die because Elysian mates
Now summon me . No need excuses there
The guest intrusive . Stay thee for thy call ,
Nor but to save an hour of painful breath
Cut ever off the never ending day
We two shall walk the clouds too happy e'en
To love . Give me that hope , and dying now
I live . Deny it , and ‘ tis you , not swords ,
That wound . They slay poor flesh , that gauzy breath
Sole guards from wormy ravage . You would strike
My never-healing soul ! Those steps of doom ——

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Hark ! Ah — they pass ! Dear gods , is there no way ?

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: The window .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: No !

lg.l: I 'll make the leap and live
To set you free !
No , no ! The rocks would gash
More cruelly than swords . Wait — O ! Blest Heaven !
Thou ‘ rt saved ! Wait here !

div.stage: Runs into inner room

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Go , spirit beautiful ! Her hair enrobes her like a parted cloud That opes to show us Heaven .... Give now my flesh To swords , ye gods , but save me from the death That has no end !...Re-enter Aratea , shorn of her locks , which she lays at Aristocles ’ feet . Her veil is draped about her , concealing her lossO ! Maimed , my goddess ?

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: See ? I knew you 'd say me nay . But now ‘ tis done .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Those locks of Venus ’ gold .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: The dagger served .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Too well !

lg.l: Not so . Now , now a rope to bridge
Eternity for thee ! More strands ! Lend me
Your lightnings , blessed skies , to weave this chain !

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Your flying fingers need them not .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: More , more ! A thousand hairs , they say , will hold a man .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Ay , one will do it .

lg.l: Merry , my lord ? Why not ?
Apollo , smile upon us ! I know we dream .
See how I make this fast ? It is your life
I lengthen .
O , ‘ tis bought too preciously !
lg.stage: Takes up a lock and kisses it
lg.l: What waste of sun and gold !
Nay , when you 're safe ,
I 'll cast it to fair Venus on the sea ,
A votive offering . Look now ! ‘ Tis done .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: So soon ?

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: And you must go .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Art sure ‘ tis done ?

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Afraid , my lord ?

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Afraid !

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: You see ‘ tis finished .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Ay , ‘ tis .

lg.l: The window — come ! We 'll make this fast —
And then — farewell !

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Till I return with Dion .

lg.l: Return ? No , no , my lord ! O , come no more
To this cursed land . Be happy in thy Athens .
And Plenty bless thee as thou wert her child ,
Swelling thy measure till prosperity
Hang on thy look like fruit invisible
Dropping to whom thou wilt .
And you — and you —
My heart is dumb . What gods wish for themselves
Become a human fortune and befall thee !

div.stage: Exeunt . Guards approach and beat door . Re-enter Aratea

lg.l: Strike , dogs ! Some say Apollo fathered him .
O , god of melody , guard thou the life
That beats a perfect song !

div.stage: Door falls and Domenes enters with guards

sp.speaker: Dom
sp.p: What ! Who is this ?

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: A princess , sir .

sp.speaker: Dom
sp.p: Where is the prisoner ?

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: He 's gone .

sp.speaker: Dom
sp.p: Gone ! How ? Where ?

lg.l: Did not Zeus himself
Steal Ganymede ? Why not Aristocles ?

div.stage: Curtain

div.head: ACT IV

stage.stage: SCENE : The grove of Ceres on the right , a temple partly visible . The island of Ortygia in rear , separated from mainland by a very narrow channel with wall on the Ortygian side running off stage left , to channel bridge where the ensuing conflict is supposed to centre . The island extends down to the Lesser Harbor , centre rear , which widens to a sea-glimpse at right . On the island shore in the farthest distance is outlined the temple of Artemis . Part of the Ortygian castle is shown on an island , left , the lower part concealed by channel wall .

At extreme left , front , the entrance to Phillistus ’ dwelling is seen . Between dwelling and channel a road leads toward the bridge . At front of stage a road runs left toward the Greater Harbor , and right toward Epipolai , the outermost portion of the city .

On the right , toward rear , terraces lead up to the heights of Achridina . Various statues are seen , the largest being a Victory at entrance to grove . Off the stage , left front , over Greater Harbor , the sun is setting , throwing gradually softening tints and increasing shadows .

Troops of soldiers , laughing and talking with citizens in holiday costume , come up the road from the Greater Harbor and pass off toward Epipolai . Speusippus , Ascander , and Timoleon , enter from grove and stand near the Victory . At right front enter young men arrayed for banqueting , bearing wreaths , torches , etc . They turn to rear and pass up terraces toward Achridina , singing .

O , pleasure is the wing of Time , Care his limping , leaden foot ! Too late , too late , for laugh and rhyme When old Winter 's at the root Of desire , And no fire Can thaw the frost where we lie mute .
Then come all and feast ye now ! Come catch Love , the pretty rover ! Not a maiden bind her brow With a rose unkissed by lover ! As a flower Is Cupid 's hour , And where he flies none can discover .

div.stage: Exeunt toward the heights of Achridina

lg.l: So turns our war into a holiday .
Here Dion lands , and swift the tyrant flies
With all his boasted guard into the castle ,
While Syracuse throws open gate and arms
To welcome her besieger .
By Artemis !
Didst see him marching in ?— Calippus on
One side , Aristocles on t'other — their corselets white
Fair shining in the sun , and each with locks
Bright garlanded ?— close treading them the guards —
The hundred Grecian guards that watch by Dion ,
Then all his men in battle order placed ?
But when his trumpeter blew from the gate ,
And all the people upward looked in silence
While he declared them subjects but of Heaven ,
No wonder that each eye turned fount and flowed .
Then ‘ twas the wet cheek marked the noble heart ,
And the unwatered eye was shame .
And now
His soldiers rove throughout the city , while
The people lean from walls like branching trees
And shake a crop of blessings .
Kisses too !
E'en in the streets the women set their tables ,
And from their wreath � d urns pour Cretan wine
For Dion 's men .

sp.speaker: Tim
sp.p: What says my lord Speusippus ? The only sour-face in all Syracuse .

lg.l: And cause enough . A pretty soldier , sir ,
Who 'd choose to march with flowers in his hand
Like smirking virgin on Diana 's day !
I thought the tyrant would show tooth of war
And not turn tail and kennel .

sp.speaker: Tim
sp.p: StartingWhat noise is that ? It cuts the air unlike a feasting cry .

lg.l: By Mars , I pray our swords will yet have airing ,
And good fresh drink too !

sp.speaker: Tim
sp.p: Here 's a man , Ascander . He courts dame Trouble as she were his wench .

lg.l: Tut , tut , my friends , I 've but a soldier 's relish
For an honest fight . What 's there to fear ? Besides ,
I have a trick to dodge misfortune 's blows .

sp.speaker: Tim
sp.p: What 's that , Speusippus ?

lg.l: Why , if breaks my cup ,
I think what now an it had been my vase
From Phelas ’ shop ? I break my vase , and straight
I cry ho ! ho ! now had my house been burnt
That were a woe ! But burns my house indeed ,
I think of wife and child who perished not ;
When dies my wife or son , I thank the gods
That Death crept all so near and touched not me .
And when his certain hour to clutch me comes
I 'll think of famines , plagues , of earthquakes , floods ,
And nations swept away . And still I 'll cure
Such broad affliction with the thought of how
The Universe itself is but a shell
To crackle when it please the hand that made it .
So , friends , I mend each woe with its own cloth
Till all looks well again .
Ay , but the patch
Is greater than the garment .

div.stage: Enter Calippus , hurrying

sp.speaker: Speu
sp.p: Ho , Calippus !

lg.l: Hail , friends ! But stay me not . I run to join
The general without the city gates .

sp.speaker: Asc
sp.p: What ? Dion ?

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.p: Ay !

sp.speaker: Tim
sp.p: Without the gates ?

lg.l: ‘ Tis so .
Phillistus and the admiral have seized
Excitement 's topping hour to turn all hearts
With fear 's mad eloquence ,— saying that Dion
Comes to avenge his wrongs and set up rule
More cruel than Dionysius dared . And so
This gay and garlanded humanity
Troop to these traitors , while lord Dion camps
Without the city .
Gods ! Did he go mildly ?
By Erebus ’ black daughter , I 'd have turned
And beat them to subjection . Not a blow ?
He came to lift their yoke , not add another ,
And struck to heart with their ingratitude
Gave them their choice , nor made warlike retort
Beyond to warn them , with his finger lifted
To yonder frowning castle , that the tyrant
Was bayed , not conquered .

sp.speaker: Tim
sp.p: Conquered ? No ! The city never knew a woe till now .

lg.l: Ay , Syracuse should with one general bray
Cry ass to Heaven . O , mullets of Abdera ,
Would ye be kings , come reign in Sicily !
Phillistus has no force to meet the foe
Will belch from that black fort .

sp.speaker: Speu
sp.p: Haste , friends , to Dion !

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.p: You 'll go ?

sp.speaker: Speu
sp.p: What else ? There 'll be some good play yet . Bray , Syracuse , thou populated ass !

div.stage: Exeunt . The sunlight fades into twilight , and the full moon rises , right , rear , where the Lesser Harbor widens to the sea . Theano comes out of Phillistus ’ house and places fresh verbenas on the entrance altar . An Amazon follows her

lg.l: Though gods forget me I 'll remember them .
Stand back ! I 'll not be dogged !
lg.stage: The Amazon advances , folds her arms and takes station near Theano , who turns wearily from her and looks out upon the scene
lg.l: Well for this earth
That Beauty keeps her court for gods not men ,
Nor clouds for mortal mourning ! O , fair city ,
And fairer night , how strange and cold your smile
Upon my heart !... The slave is gone . That means
Phillistus comes .

div.stage: Phillistus enters opposite and stands in shadow , gazing at Theano

lg.l: I 've little hope to cheat her more . Her eyes
Are at the windows of my heart and read
Each dark recess . Well , let love go if ‘ t must .
The joys of hate are no less deep ,— and she
Is mine !
Theano ? I am here .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: I see .

lg.l: My day of days has come ! One kiss to crown it .
Art still unkind ? Ah , sweet , where is the smile
Should dress thee in a fairer light than gilds
The crystal Thetis when Hyperion woos ?
What ! not a kiss .
This statue 's sculptured lips
Are warmer , sir .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: To me !

lg.l: Though on your brow
Yon Victory should drop her high-held wreath
You 'd be no more nor less than now . Who wears
The unseen chaplet given of spirit hands
To him whose soul is virtue , needeth not
Ambition 's leafy handful that oft makes
The mortal brow vaunt as it grew the trees
Of all Olympus .
What a welcome here
For Sicily 's new king ! Know , my Theano ,
That Dionysius is to castle beaten ,
And treacherous Dion from the city thrust ,
While Heraclides with me shares the power
Soon to be mine alone , for his fall , too ,
Already is assured .
Then thou hast topped
The very summit of thy bold desire .
True ! Aspiration now , lit like a lark
On Fortune 's steeple , sings above all hazard .
My loved Theano , thou ‘ rt queen of Syracuse ;
We 'll sleep to-night like happy royalty
In honor 's bed .
The stone of Sisyphus
Will gather moss ere that may be , Phillistus .
You gave the safety of your stable house
To my bewildered grief . ‘ Twas noble , sir ,
Though mine was woe would make a lion sheathe
His hungry claws and pass on softest foot .
But not for gold or throne will I be yours .
Not for all sapphires that have kissed in crowns ,
All rubies that in deepest caves make day ,
Would I be wife to you , or take your hand
Though to be plucked into Elysium !

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: So ? By the fires of Dis , I 'll end this play ! Dost think me your poor slave to sweat for naught ? An ass to bear your pack for chaff and straw ?

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: My lord ?

lg.l: Did I risk all to play the nurse
Unto your tedious grief for a false lover ?
All Syracuse knows you his fool , and yet
You 'd play Penelope , and hope to sit
With tears of twenty years upon your cheeks !
O stare and wonder , gasp , and sir ! and ho !
Weep if you will , and pray your baby prayers .
I 've done with ah 's and oh 's and niceties !

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: O now this monster shows its head !

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Go in !... Wilt have me call the slave ?

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Beware , Phillistus !

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Of what , or whom ?

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Of Heaven , sir !

lg.l: Ha ! ha !
What powers there owe not their reign to man ?
The mind at holiday makes gods for sport
And gives them us for masters . When I 'm crowned
I 'll banish all these idle , meddling wits ,
These boggy brains that spring with toadstool thrones
Decked with a deity .
And yet the gods
Now hear thee !
Say they do , love rules ‘ mong gods
As men . Doubt not they 'll wink at my warm suit .
O , thy black soul will be the scorn of devils
When hell has claimed thee !
Know me blacker still !
Since hate must be the bond between our hearts ,
I 'll burn this into thine — thy father 's death
Was by my hand made sure , that I might woo
Your foolish mother , who drank in turn my cup .
Yet shall I wear the blossom of your love
Fair on my bosom , and the fruit shall grow
To propagate my house . So silent , madam ?
Is not this news ? You would not coo for me ;
May I not hear you rave ?
Who , who could speak ?
Now swirling harpies pluck away my soul ,
And leave me here a shell that yet can breathe !

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Ah , you shall breathe and live for me — for me !

lg.l: O lust , whose sovereign heel treads life
As destiny had given bond and stamp for ‘ t !
Ay , my desire would charter hell for breath
And blow her fires to desolate the world
Ere lose thee now !

div.stage: Enter a messenger from the bridge road

sp.speaker: Mess
sp.p: Sir , Heraclides begs your instant aid ! The castled enemy have darted forth ——

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: How ? Where ?

lg.l: Behind the wall — across the bridge !
Like adder 's tongue they 've struck the sleeping city .
Now Heraclides calls for men to guard
The channel crossing .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Say I 'll join him there . At once ! Away !

div.stage: Exit messenger

lg.l: Ragunda ! Amazon !
lg.stage: Ragunda comes out of Phillistus ’ house
lg.l: Take in your charge , and keep a closer watch .
Your life , as hers , is short or long .
In , madam !
Here dies my faith . O chance-made world , upheaved
By Demiurgus turning in his sleep !

div.stage: Goes in with Ragunda . Enter second messenger

sp.speaker: Mess
sp.p: O , sir ——

lg.l: Pray put your periods after news ,
Not ‘ fore .
My lord , the tyrant 's guards have made
A second murderous sally from the castle ,
And with great brands of flame have fired the city !
Now Dionysius , knowing he must forego
The tyranny , would utterly destroy us ,
And wipe from earthly chronicle the name
Of Syracuse !
I 'll come ... when I have turned
A bolt within .

div.stage: Enter third messenger

sp.speaker: Third mess
sp.p: Where is Phillistus ?

sp.speaker: Second mess
sp.p: Pointing to houseThere .

lg.l: The people rage against him , and have sent
Again to Dion , praying his return .

div.stage: Re-enter Phillistus

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Dion ! He 'll come . Then farewell crown and life ! Where , men ?

lg.l: The fight is hardest where the wall
Runs to the channel .

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: On ! That is the place .

div.stage: Exeunt toward bridge . The sky darkens , clouding the moon . On the road from the Greater Harbor enter men , women , and children , who run about confusedly in the darkness

sp.speaker: First voice
sp.p: Where is the lord Phillistus ?

sp.speaker: Second voice
sp.p: Heraclides is wounded .

sp.speaker: Third voice
sp.p: Dogs ! They brought this hell on us !

sp.speaker: Voices shrieking
sp.p: The guards ! The guards !

div.stage: Soldiers of Dionysius rush on , road left , front , carrying brands which they cast about . They seize the people and put all to the sword

sp.speaker: Soldiers
sp.p: To Achridina ! To the heights ! Burn all !

div.stage: Exeunt , right , rear , scattering brands , one of which lights the temple of Ceres seen through the trees , left . Enter citizens , left , front . They carry arms . Burning brands reveal the dead

lg.l: See , friends ! Here lie our pictures as we 'll be
A moment hence .

sp.speaker: Second cit
sp.p: No hope now but in Dion !

sp.speaker: Third cit
sp.p: As Dracon entersDracon !

lg.l: All lost — all lost . Put up your swords .
The Carthaginian fleet lies in the bay ,
And by the sea-gate to the castle fort
Empties her men into the tyrant 's hand !

sp.speaker: Second cit
sp.p: O Syracuse !

lg.l: And next upon this news
Phillistus and the admiral desert us ,
Flying to Dionysius .

sp.speaker: Voices
sp.p: Traitors ! dogs !

sp.speaker: Dracon
sp.p: And now though Dion should forgive our baseness ——

sp.speaker: Voices
sp.p: He will ! he will !

lg.l: His force and ours united
Can not make stand against the strengthened foe .

sp.speaker: Voices
sp.p: O woeful night ! O bloody , bloody night !

lg.l: Now sword and fire will make such havoc ‘ mong us
There 'll not be breath enough in all the city
To say good-morrow to the sun .

div.stage: Cheers without , right , front . Enter a warrior at the head of troops . He wears helmet and carries shield

lg.l: Shame , shame !
O , Syracusans , shame ! If ye be men ,
Let battle take the garb of order , and death
Array itself in decency ! I 've brought
A band of noble Leontines to strike
With who shall prove no coward ! Lift your swords
Till Victory sees them shining through the night
And knows which way to bend her doubtful wings !
On , on , my men ! On , Syracusans , on !

div.stage: All go off left , cheering . Enter Gylippus , right , rear , wounded

sp.speaker: Gylippus
sp.p: I 'll drop me here till flame or steel o'erhYpppHeNtake me .Falls down

sp.speaker: Menodes
sp.p: EnteringGylippus ? Wounded ?

sp.speaker: Gy
sp.p: Deep enough . No matter . Wounds are Bellona 's favors . Do you bleed ?

sp.speaker: Men
sp.p: I lose an arm . ‘ Twas a warm kiss that took it .

lg.l: Hast seen the stranger and his Leontines ?
He goes through fire as ‘ twere a pastime loved ,
Shaking the burning timbers from his back
As they were flies .
Thrice has he formed
The citizens for charge , though night and flame
War on confusion 's side .
Ocrastes comes
With ships that treble all sent out from Carthage .
Then Dion to the rescue speedily ,
Or Syracuse is ashes !
Dion ! He 's here !
Now Mercy cloister close , and stern Revenge ,
Long patient , take the sword !

sp.speaker: Men
sp.p: Ho , who are these ?

div.stage: Enter the warrior in combat with Phillistus , left , rear

sp.speaker: Gy
sp.p: The stranger with Phillistus ! Here 's my blow !

div.stage: Attempts to rise

sp.speaker: Men
sp.p: No need ! He falls !

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: DownYour mercy !

lg.l: Take it — death !
Thou single confine of all men 's corruption ,
Die — die — and poison ghosts in hell !

div.stage: Flames issue from Phillistus ’ house . Servants rush out , shrieking

lg.stage: Half rising and looking at the flames
lg.l: My house
In flames ! Thanks , gods , for this ! Proud mistress , burn
Behind your bars , and to your black remains
Be your Ocrastes welcome !

sp.speaker: Warrior
sp.p: Aid me , Heaven !

div.stage: Rushes into house

lg.l: That voice — O traitor ! He will save her ! Ay
He 'll tread through hell nor burn his feet !
I die now as they kiss ! Ocrastes — O !
The rest I 'll tell to gaunt and gibbering shades .

div.stage: Dies

Curtain falls and rises upon the same scene in ruins , several hours later . Wrecks smoulder in foreground , In rear the flames from Achridina throw light on the untouched castle and island . Noise of battle comes from left . Enter from bridge road Dion , Panthus , Calippus , Aristocles , Speusippus , and others

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Thanks for my life . ‘ Twas bravely rescued , friends .

lg.l: My lord , you do us wrong so to expose the arm
That props our hope .
Nay , not with me , Calippus ,
The battle rests , but with the unknown warrior
Gods lend our fainting cause . Where'er he strikes
The gash � d enemy look on their wounds
And turn like death-met fear to seek a cover .
Ay ! Once he fell , but rose with such new might
He seemed like Mars who , tripped on Trojan field ,
Uprising threw his shoulders ‘ gainst the clouds
And darkened heaven .
By Zeus , he 'd dare to hale
Rhamnusia from her wing � d car and turn
Her gryphons to the winds !

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Back to his aid !

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: Your wound , my lord .

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.p: Give valor space to breathe . There 'll be brave puffing ere the wall is down . The channel banks it close , but we may breach it .

lg.l: It must be done , and must , sir , captains may
In war .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Then to it ! We waste breath .

lg.l: Stay , sir !
We go — not you — for when our general bleeds
Each man afield bleeds with him . See , your wound !
By Thaumas ’ claw-foot maids , ‘ tis past a scratch !

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: I feel not this — but O , fair Syracuse ! Rock in thy fiery cradle till the sea Gets up to weep , and bending gods pour down Remorseful tears to drown the reddening shame That blushes o'er the moon and writes the name Of hell upon the stars !A sudden burst of noise and flame from the heights of AchridinaArt gone , my city ?... Ah , fallen Dionysius , must thou Lose all , then cast thy soul to swell the loss ? It is thy kingly reputation burns , With all that thou mightst own in fair Elysium !

div.stage: Shouting , left

sp.speaker: Speu
sp.p: The wall ! the wall ! They charge !

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: The stranger leads ! Ho , come , Speusippus !

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: On ! on , on , my friends !

div.stage: Exeunt , left . The flames from Achridina die down . Semi-darkness . Men enter and creep about the blackened ruins . Soft light in the East

sp.speaker: First man
sp.p: Now Ceres mend our bones ! Will ‘ t e'er be light ?

sp.speaker: Second man
sp.p: Ay , yonder winks the dawn .

lg.l: This blindfold war
Is Horror past familiar — her leper cheek
Bowsing both cheeks like mistress privileged .
Gods keep us ! Many a man has died this night
Upon his dear friend 's sword . The treacherous torch
And threatening glare of flames too oft betrayed
The panic-glaz � d eye .

div.stage: Domenes rushes on from left . Speusippus following

sp.speaker: First man
sp.p: Domenes ?

lg.l: Ay ,
The captain of the tyrant 's guards . The Greek
Is on him !

sp.speaker: Third man
sp.p: Down !

sp.speaker: Dom
sp.p: Spare me ! I 'll give you news !

lg.l: Live while your tongue wags . Speak ! What of the fleet
From Italy ?
All lost but one poor sail
That brings the desperate news . The tyrant mad
With this is bound for flight with what is left
Of Carthage .

sp.speaker: Speu
sp.p: Ah , Ocrastes dead ?

sp.speaker: Dom
sp.p: Drowned , sir .

sp.speaker: Speu
sp.p: And Dion 's wife ?

sp.speaker: Dom
sp.p: She 's in the castle — safe .

sp.speaker: Speu
sp.p: And flies with Dionysius ? Speak , man !

sp.speaker: Dom
sp.p: She begs to stay , but he may force her off .

sp.speaker: Speu
sp.p: Then we must stop this play and take the castle ! Drag off ! You 're past all harm .Going off , leftNow one charge more !Exit

div.stage: Light breaks over Lesser Harbor

sp.speaker: Voices
sp.p: Light ! light !

lg.l: O blessed Zeus ! And yet I fear
The babe-eyed Dawn will sicken with what 's here
And creep back into night .
No , day comes on ,—
The red-capped nurse that in her bosom hides
The cherub Dawn , while her broad smile
Goes round the world .

sp.speaker: Third man
sp.p: A smile on this ?

lg.l: Ay , ay ,
Her stomach 's for all sights , and ulcerous earth
She 'll kiss as close as fountain-laughing vales .
By Ares ’ bloody dame , here 's work enough
To keep the gods a year from holiday !

div.stage: Shouts without , left . Enter citizens and soldiers in joyful confusion

sp.speaker: Voices
sp.p: ‘ Tis down ! The wall is down ! The castle 's taken !

sp.speaker: A voice
sp.p: The tyrant has fled by sea !

sp.speaker: Another
sp.p: And none too soon !

sp.speaker: Another
sp.p: He 'd pay his head else !

sp.speaker: Cries without
sp.p: Dion ! Dion ! Dion !

div.stage: Enter Dion with friends and citizens

lg.l: Shout not my name , for ‘ twas the noble stranger
