Who won this night . Seek him , Calippus ,— beg
His presence here with brow unhelmeted ,
That we may look where valor hath her home .

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.p: He 's gone , my lord .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Gone ?

lg.l: Vanished , as the sea
Had lapped him up .
More like the gods have stooped
To draw him home again .

div.stage: Looks about at the desolation and groans

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.p: Your wound , my lord ?

lg.l: No , no . I weep for dying Syracuse .
Now is her glory like a weary star
Withdrawn from fortune 's heaven . O fairest city ,
Whose beauty drew the feet of farthest kings ,
And set a value in the poorest eye
To be a storied heritage to sons
When sires who saw had passed ! Even thou hast won
From cold oblivion but an ashen cloak !
‘ Tis tyranny lies here , not Syracuse .
Ay , from these mourn � d ashes , friend , will spring
A brighter glory than they bury now ,
And this night 's woe bear fruitage of a peace
When Time shall hang as thick with happy hours
As Flora 's breast with buds .
By Hector 's spur ,
It pricks to think this valor-breasted night ,
Bristling with action 's pikes toward charging death ,
Should e'er beg life of tolerant memory ,
Thankful for so much breath as may endow
A musty adage in the mouth of peace ,
Or shepherd song piped by an idle rill
To meek-eared violets in noonday shade !
O ! O ! my lady Fame must have her nap .
Soft , Mars , put on thy slippers !

div.stage: Enter soldiers dragging Heraclides

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Who is this ?

sp.speaker: First soldier
sp.p: My lord , a prisoner .

lg.l: ‘ Tis Heraclides ,
My lord .

sp.speaker: Voices
sp.p: Death ! Death to Dion 's enemy !

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: What ? Heraclides ?

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: Ay !Drawing his swordThe blow is mine !

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Put up your sword , brave Panthus . Nay , put up !

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: Dropping weapon‘ Twere better used , sir .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Heraclides , speak . What would you say ? Do you repent this night ?

lg.l: All men , my lord , repent the step that brings
Their cloud-high foreheads to earth . I lie so low
That Fortune 's sun-bent eye will find no more
My sunken ruin ,— and but one comfort left ,
I can descend no further .

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: Ay , to hell !

sp.speaker: Her
sp.p: Ambition knows no hell but failure . Strike ! You put me out of torture , not send me to it .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Life only dreams her hells till death 's be found .

lg.l: ‘ Tis easy thus to speak from victory 's height
Whence all looks fair ,— so fair misfortune seems
Sole lie o ’ the world . We bite truth with the dust ,
My lord .

sp.speaker: Voices
sp.p: His sentence ! Death ! The traitor ! Death !

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Peace , friends .

sp.speaker: Voices
sp.p: Death ! Seize him ! Kill him !

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.p: Dion speaks !

sp.speaker: Voices
sp.p: Hear Dion !

lg.l: Not alone in martial venture
Do victors win their bays . Let each of us ,
Trampling on anger and contending malice
That from our natures thrust out serpent heads ,
Forgive this captive foe , and crown our brows
With wreaths of victory outshining all
That shake from war-decked temples . Hear , my lord .
By the power I hold in the true hearts and minds
Of noble Syracusans , I forgive thee .

sp.speaker: Voices
sp.p: No , no !

lg.l: My lord , he warned . He has a tongue
Would flatter Zeus from heaven , and common minds
He calls as flies to honey .
Nay , his sweet
Is wormwood now . Because this foolish man
Has walked in sin , shall I too blemish virtue ?

sp.speaker: Voices
sp.p: Revenge ! Revenge !

lg.l: Who offers injury ,
And who revenges it , ply the same thread
Of Nature 's scarlet . Heraclides , go .
Thou'rt free .
I do not kneel to you — a man —
But to the god that houses in your shape .
O noble Dion , what deed may speak my thanks
Too great for tongue ?
Arise , go forth , and where
You once betrayed a thousand hearts lead one
To safety .

div.stage: Exit Heraclides , rabble following

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.p: To SpeusippusSir , what think you ?

lg.l: ‘ Tis gross error .
He 'll breathe a life into the stones o ’ the street
Ere lack for followers .

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.p: Come , let us see .

div.stage: Exeunt Calippus and Speusippus , others following

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: To his Grecian guardsGo nurse your wounds , brave friends . I need no more Your arms , but ever need your love . You with them , Panthus . You know my wishes .

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: Ay , my lord .

div.stage: Exeunt Panthus and guards . Aristocles remains with Dion

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: My friend !They embraceNo tears ! We 'll water joy hereafter . Now there is much to do . Wilt seek Calippus for me And make him governor of the castle ?

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Ay .Exit

lg.l: Now red revolt with opened veins lies low
Fast paling to her death ; and silence deep
As takes the mother 's ear who waits the step
Of her dead soldier son , creeps o'er the world .
And to my lonely eye the universe
Shrinks to a monument writ with one grief .
Ocrastes , couldst , when locked within my love —
Ay , bedded in the core — to vermin turn
And gnaw the heart thou breathedst in ?... O youth ,
Among life 's strangely flowering hopes thou art
The blossom of deceit ! When we have watched
Thy tender green peer up — thy opening buds
That wrap their silken promise round our fears —
And spent our prayers like nurturing rains upon thee
That thou mayst bloom above our pride and hang
The rose or spring upon our frosty age ,
How dost thou droop , till o'er thy cankered wreck
We dew thy fall with tears !... O beauteous bud ,
What deadly aconite cast its foul shade
Upon thy blowing grace ? My son , my son ,
I am no warrior when I think of thee ,
Else would my sword be out . A father 's eye
Is turned upon thy sin , and all the wrong
Thou didst to me half righted with a tear ...
... The sun comes flaming from the sea as though
Another Syracuse burnt on the waves ...
Why stand I here ? The castle doors are open ,
And therein waits the fairest face of earth
To shine for me To shine ? O human sun ,
Unlike thy skyey peer , thy light is dimmed
With what thou'st looked upon . Thy beams have drunk
Pollution deep that now detested falls
Upon my soul .

div.stage: Re-enter Aristocles

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: All 's well , my lord .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: All 's well ? That 's strange news for my heart . Wilt go with me ?

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Whither , my lord ?

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Into yon castle .... Come .

div.stage: Exeunt . Curtain

div.head: ACT V

stage.stage: SCENE : A room in the castle . Brentio alone .

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: By Hector , we 've had a night of it . I must stop now and count my fingers and toes , for I 'm sure there 's some of me missing . First , my gold !Counts goldAll here . But poor mistress Theano that I promised to carry through fire and flood for this same sweet gold was burnt up last night . Well , my lord Ocrastes is dead too , so I 'll not be called to account . Had it been flood now I might have kept my promise , but fire — I never could abide a singed beard .Enter TichusHo , Tichus ! These are wars , sir ! These are wars ! Have you killed your man this night ?

sp.speaker: Tich
sp.p: A score , I hope .

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: Well , I 've naught to say . Let deeds talk . A bragging tongue is Fame 's best grave-digger , though it wag i ’ the mouth of Hercules . But I spared some , I 'll say that . They cried so for mercy , poor fellows ! Not a man of ‘ em was ready to die , by his own count .

sp.speaker: Tich
sp.p: If you wait for that you 'll die swearing blood is green for all you 'll even draw of it . When the gods promised that no man should die till he was ready old Charon sold his boat .

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: There 's a stick-penny for you . What was his bargain ?

sp.speaker: Tich
sp.p: A feather bed , that he might sleep off idleness .

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: Ah , but you should have seen me when a villain pitted at me with three pikes . A murderous three-handed deformity , by the truth o ’ my eyes he was !

sp.speaker: Tich
sp.p: Then you shook your sword , I warrant !

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: No , bless me , I shook my feet .

sp.speaker: Tich
sp.p: Man , you did n't run ?

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: No , I flew . I wore Mercury 's feathers , I tell you .

sp.speaker: Tich
sp.p: Shame , Brentio ! A coward 's leg will never overtake Fame .

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: Ay , but when a man must leap the grave to catch her , let take her who will ! I 'm done . Have you been through the castle ?

sp.speaker: Tich
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: Come then . There are sights to be seen . Mostly in the cellars , where every soldier gets a bottle for his song .SingsWho will not be merry then let him go drown , Let him go drown , In as rosy a bumper as ever went down , As ever went down , And he 'll bob up , he 'll bob up , by Bacchus , he will , As hail a good fellow as ever wet gill ! Here are our masters ! I 'm gone . A hero may drink , but work — never !Exit

sp.speaker: Tich
sp.p: There 's more trouble ahead than the claw o ’ my wit can scratch . Ocrastes ’ death makes one less in the pother , but I 've eyes in my head , and there 's no doubt my master is in love with the lady Aratea , and one lover can make more trouble than a score of extra husbands . Well , well , when thy cares bewilder thee take time and wine for thy counsellors . So let it work out .Exit . Aristocles and Dion appear in hall partly visible through wide open doors , rear . Aristocles enters and comes front . Dion remains without , gazing down , moody and meditative

lg.l: Deep , deep , my thoughts , dive to some bed of death
In my wide-regioned self , nor come again
Like sea-return � d corpse , with livid grin
And foul , accreted horror , to beg anew
For burial .
lg.stage: Dion comes in and walks slowly across to Aristocles
lg.l: You 'll see her now ?

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: See whom ?

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Your wife .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: My wife ? Have I a wife ?

lg.l: She waits
Your summons by Diana 's altar .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Ah ! So near ?

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Theano waits with her .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: My niece ? She 's safe ?

lg.l: By miracle . The unknown knight
Bore her from out Phillistus ’ burning house .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Still swells our debt to him .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: You 'll see her now ?

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: See whom , my friend ?

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Your wife , sir ,— Aratea .

lg.l: When you repeat the name I half believe
I have a wife . Your voice was ever true ,
Nor fed me with the rifled husks of speech .
... Was she not fair ?

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: My lord ?

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: How fair , think you ?

lg.l: Who , sir , could say ? Such beauty scorns all words
And writes itself but in the wondering eye .
You shift . You shift . Your tongue is beauty 's pencil .
Did heaven lack a goddess you might limn
A fairer than a Venus for the place .
Speak on . Tell me her sum to the last doit .
The balance of a hair — a smile unborn —
I 'd not strike off .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: ColdlyYou know her worth , my lord .

lg.l: Nay , the appraising eye when fixed too near
The thing it loves distorts the sweet proportion .
You can adjust your gaze , take stand to bring
Her beauty to perfection 's single-point .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: What matter ? All is yours .

lg.l: Ah , if ‘ twere mine
I 'd care not , happy then to know ‘ twas mine .
But when we 've lost we 're moved to question , sir ,
Else are we crippled twice in our estate ,
Once in the loss , again to know it not .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Strange speech , my lord . I hardly know your tongue .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: You can not understand , for you 've no wife . No more have I . But once .... Yes , yes , I 'll see her . Wilt bring her here ?

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: I bring her ? Here ? To you ?

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: If ‘ tis too sad a service ——

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Nay , I go .Exit

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: I am forgot in his great pity of her .

div.stage: Enter Calippus

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.p: Lord Dion , Heraclides begs to see you .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Is he alone ?

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.p: � gisthus comes with him .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Bid them into the banquet hall .

lg.l: My lord ,
You will not see them ?
Ay , there 's naught to fear .
Tell them I 'll join them soon .
Now riven heart ,
Close firm as mountain bulwark that beats off
The Thracian wind .

div.stage: Enter Aristocles with Theano and Aratea

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: To TheanoGood welcome , niece .

div.stage: He embraces Theano , and looks silently at Aratea

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: FalteringlyMy lord ——

lg.l: Your friend , your lover — ay , your slave ,— but not
Your lord , sweet Aratea .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: O ! Condemned !

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Not that — but ——

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Then you 'll hear me ?

lg.l: No ! Your voice
Renews in me the battle that I thought
Was fought to end .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: But I could say , my lord ——

lg.l: Ay , you could say what would revoke the sun ,
Turn back into his heart his golden spears ,
And from the sapphire battlements make pour
Surpris � d night ! How easy then to shake
The scarce-sworn vow from my unfended breast
To melt like snowflake caught in lap of June !

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: O , sir ——

lg.l: You 've that in you defeats resolve ,
And casts in broil the mind 's high chancery .
I will not hear a word ! ‘ Tis my defence ,
Not cruelty . All honor shall be thine
Apart from me .
What honor may be mine
Apart from thee ?

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Nay , question not my justice !

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: You think me vile , my lord ?

lg.l: Mayhap I do !
Were there no poisons left in Sicily ?
No rank , night-sweating herbs whose bane might work
Proud honor 's choice ? Were daggers grown too blunt
To pierce fair flesh ? What , not a rope — nor cord ?
No garters — strips of silken robes ——
O , spare
To accuse a soul who erred that she might still
Be true to Heaven .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: True ? By Pallas ! True ?

lg.l: Sir , she obeyed the gods who bid us wait
And work on earth our destiny .
The gods
Sometimes write in our fates that to seek death
Is what will solely please them .
Must I see
The sun of justice in you set ?
Ah , friend ,
Do you not see ‘ tis my desire that cries
To keep her still ? ‘ Tis passion weighing doubts ,
Hoping to find them light as rising vapors .
Though she had struck at life within her heart ,
Swart Atropos had dropped her shears for pity ,
Nor helped so fair a woe to death . Yet you ——
O , she is pure , but not to me ! ‘ Tis stamped
Upon my soul that she is dark to me
Though fair to Heaven !
Hear her , sir . She took
No vows . Her lips were dumb ——
O , vows ! You speak
Of words ?

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: But ——

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Silence , niece !

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Receive her , sir .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Never , my friend ! What can you know of this ?

lg.l: I know she is Pandora without taint !
The secret pattern lost in mourning heaven
When rapt Hephaistos shaped the perfect clay
By Pallas ’ breath made vital ! Sir , receive her !
Let me implore it by our years of love .
Thou'rt dear to me as man may be to man ,
But wert thou dear as god may be to god ,
I could not grant thy wish .
Then she is mine !
And , could I snatch a tear from Dian 's cheek
When bowed at secret altar she renews
Her vestal sanctity , ‘ twould not be less
Unspotted to my love ! O , Aratea ,
Wilt come ? My wife ? Say not thou lov'st , but cling
Unto my breast as trusting bud to bough ,
Or but uplook with eyes whose shaken sea
Is calmed in mine .
Ye powers that rule my being ,
Stop every conscious note but wonder !
Ah ,
I 've heard it said Apollo loved my mother ,
And I could wish it true , that god-descended
I might embrace thyself , who surely art
Of high Olympus born — whose mortal part
Wears beauty as the night her stars .
Behold
Me desolate , ye gods ! Is this my friend ?
Nay , thou hast given friendship such a blow
She dies from earth , nor in eternal groves
May she be healed .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Not mine , but yours , the blow .

lg.l: Ocrastes struck me , and I rose again .
My wife was taken , and I lived to sigh .
But you — O , now the quick of life is seized
With mortal ill. Now shakes my earth to centre ,
And on me falling bow her peak � d tops .
Even here and now I die . All fellowship
Forego with gallant breath , and lay me down
Like forest trunk that pours its wasting heart
From every lopp � d limb .
Go from me , girl .
My wounded senses shrink away from life
Till gentlest touches are as brands of pain .
Dumb be my lips . I 'll speak no more on earth .
Keep you that word ! Thy silence is my speech !
Know , Dion , though the knowing now is naught ,
Ocrastes left me ere his marriage vow
Was cold in air , nor took one bridal kiss .
Nor have these eyes beheld him since that hour ,
Nor will the eye of mortal see him more .
The sea now holds him to her buried heart .
Some shelly couch washed with a Nereid 's tears
Is his last bed .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: And you untouched ... untouched .

lg.l: I grieve you did not know me better , sir .
You too , my lord Aristocles . Those cords —
Those daggers — poisons — had been quickly found ——
Untouched ! No bridal kiss ! My blindness goes .
But Heaven , in pity , shut me dark again ,
For I have wronged Ocrastes — who is dead .
How could your woman heart not know the truth —
That he thus saved you from a baser touch
To be restored all perfect , pure to me ?
And he is dead . Give me your pity , gods !
Now we will mourn , Theano . Here , my daughter .
Our griefs let marry in our kissing tears .
But there 's a brightness yet in this dark woe .
Once more , my love , my wife , you are all mine .
What mean you now ?
To guard my own . For you
The pearl of opportunity is lost .
Briareus ’ hands could not now snatch it back
Where ‘ t pales on time 's retreating wave .
By Mars ,
I 'll pass you , sir !

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Let Aratea speak . Is ‘ t not for her to choose ?

lg.l: A wedded woman
Can have no choice .
O , Dion , be a god ,
Not man , and grant it .
Choose thine own . As free
As new created star , fix where thou wilt .
Ay , choose ! Thou art my wife . Thy holy truth
Will fail thee not . Speak ! End this bitter folly
From which the gods would turn shame-burning face !

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Not if all tale be true .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: You speak too much !

lg.l: First swear , my lords , however I may choose ,
You 'll still be friends , as honored and as true
As though this face I loathe had never come
Between your loves .
I swear to you my friend
Shall be my friend .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: You , sir ?

lg.l: I will forgive him ,
For love has made him mad .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Swear it by Heaven .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: By Heaven . Now wilt speak ?

lg.l: Such sacred oaths
Need sacrificial rite , and here I give
My blood .

div.stage: Suddenly draws a dagger and attempts to stab herself . Aristocles , watching eagerly , seizes dagger , and supporting her speaks wildly

lg.l: Think not that you can fly me now !
Though thou wert dead still wouldst thou live for me
In such dear semblance of remembered show
That I would seek to woo thy houseless spirit
E'er give thee o'er unclasped to Heaven !

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Ah !Releases herself

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: But now she lives , and living she is mine .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Her lips , not yours , shall say !

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Lost man , thou'rt crazed . I pity thee . Speak , wife .

lg.l: O , blow me , winds ,
To some unpeopled sphere , and find me peace
As sweet as his who cropped the first day fruits
Of green unharrowed earth !

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: This is no answer .

lg.l: My lord , if ‘ t be my prayers can save my soul ,
In some far fane I 'll serve the priestess ’ cup
Till Death is kind and calls me .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Seizing her armAnswer me ! Art mine , or his ?

lg.l: Till truth no more is truth
Thou art my lord .

div.stage: Aristocles turns and moves apart , covering his face with his mantle . Aratea sinks feebly and Theano supports her

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: To AristoclesNow you 've your answer ! Niece , Lead out my wife .Theano takes Aratea from the room , through curtained entrance , leftAristocles — my friend — I pity and forgive thee . When Love drives , His chariot reins are veins of mortal men , Who fain must course the bright god 's destiny Nor reck the road . ‘ Tis strange — not that you loved her — But that I did not dream it must be so , She being the top and bloom of all her sex , As you , my lord , of yours . A mortal judge Would grant you her , but God gave her to me , And I doubt not He blundered to a purpose Beyond our dream . Ah me , the night 's red eyes Looked fatal on the sail that bore you hither . Cursed be my prayers that drew you from your Athens ! Farewell ! For you must go . Small Sicily No more may hold us both .

div.stage: Re-enter Theano

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: She 's better , sir .

lg.l: That 's well .
Your news ?
Our saviour of the night
Now waits to see you .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: The warrior ? Ask him in !

div.stage: Exit Calippus

lg.l: I 'll speak the thanks he waited not to hear ,
Although my heart gives none for this poor life .

div.stage: Enter warrior , rear , still in arms and helmeted

lg.l: Thou'rt welcome as the gods . As lightning makes
The world now bright , now dark , you fill and void
The circle of our sense , but , here or there ,
‘ Tis ours to grant you what you will if power
Be in us .

sp.speaker: Warrior
sp.p: KneelingFor one thing I sue — forgiveness .Removes helmet

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Ocrastes !

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Ay .

lg.l: How couldst be hid from me
Though veiled in seven-fold steel ?

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Not dead — not dead ——

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Embracing TheanoMy heart , look up . The long tale of my sins Will be as virtue 's song when in love 's ear ‘ Tis whispered . Nay , weep not . Those woes are sealed .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: O , canst forgive me ?

lg.l: It is I must sue .
Nay , nay , my sweet , no liquid gem drop now
On misery 's broken altar , too long rich
With these eyes ’ jewels .

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Ah , thou'rt mine ... still mine .

lg.l: Ere I have done your constancy shall hear
Such music of true love you 'll think those birds
That move the gentle concords of the night
In these bright locks make bower continual .
For every hour of your ungracious star ,
With the full circuit of a smiling moon
I 'll pension you , till covetous of time
You 'll wish your sorrows had been more , not less .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Not one embrace for me ?

lg.l: Before I make
My plea for pardon ?
That may wait , my son ,
For empty hours . This is too full of joy .
I did not go to Italy , my lord ,
But to the Leontines ——
O , go not back
To read the bloodprints of bewildered feet .
Now as the soft life-wooing breath that moves
So swift upon the track of orient storms
That ere the woeful people dry their tears
Earth is new-clad in garments of the sun
And balm is in the air like blessings winged ,
Fanning delight in every lifted cheek ,
So treads this hour at heel of flying woe .

div.stage: Enter Brentio , rear

sp.speaker: Bren
sp.p: My lord , the people in the banquet hall are drinking all the cellars dry . You 'd weep to see it , sir .Sees Theano and Ocrastes . Looks in bewilderment from one to the other , claps hand to his purse and runs out

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: The slave 's beset .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: He 's drunk , my lord .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: I had forgot Heraclides .GoingOcrastes , come . We 'll not so soon be parted . You to my wife , Theano .Exeunt Dion and Ocrastes , rear ; Theano through curtains , left

lg.l: Dion , how oft hast sworn I was thy dearest ,
Yet go to happiness while I droop here
As to my grave . Nor dost thou need me more
Than quickest life its century-buried dead .
Yet one is yon , behind those curtains close ,
Who starves even as you feed . Her love is mine .
By Heaven , I know ‘ tis mine ! Yet I must go —
Leave her to perish . Ay , her flower soul
Not long will bear the weight of unloved love .
lg.stage: Soldiers enter hall , rear , drinking and singing
lg.l: O , Helen had a rosy lip ,
And only one might kiss it ,
But all of mistress wine may sip
And she will never miss it .
Ho , brothers all are we ,
Brothers all are we !
We 've sworn to the last red drop ,
Be it found in a heart or found in a cup ,
And brothers all we be !
A soldier 's trade it is to die ,
And what poor fools are they
Who for a soldier 's death will sigh —
‘ Tis all in a business way .
Ho , brothers all are we , & c .

div.stage: Exeunt drunkenly

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: O , I am wounded in the character I sought to build so giant-like that as A figure on the skies all men would see And longing upward scorn their baser state ! Now am I grown deform � d with a scar That all eternity can not make fair . ... To go ... nor say farewell . To go ... to go , And see no more her face ... that face which is Imagination sighing in a word . That face where Beauty with her mysteries Sits listening to Magi of the air , Or ocean lapping on eternal sands . ‘ Tis as a star should to a flower turn , And yet remember heaven .Approaches curtains and kneelsFare thee well ! O thou whose body is a living urn Full of distill � d sweets from every mead Where Love hath set a flower ! Whose soul compacts All earth 's divinity , and leaves profane All space where it is not !Arises and starts out slowly . At the door he looks back . Aratea appears at curtains , but does not see himO , I must fly ... Must fly ... nor hear again her voice that lures As it would draw the fallen golden world O'er desert ages to man 's memory .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Sees him and advancesYou here , Aristocles ?

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Wilt say farewell ?

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Going backFarewell .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: No word but that ?

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: That is too much .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: ApproachingToo much ?

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: I — faint again . Nay , touch me not !

lg.l: Am I so perilous to thee ? My hand
Has had no commerce yet with cruelty .
The moon with silver foot steps not more soft
Among the tears of night than falls thy touch
On me , who , poorer than the night , must go
Uncomforted . Thou'lt leave this place at once
If thou hast pity .
Ah , had I a heart
Great-swelling as the sad Molurian mount ,
Or pil � d peaks that wreck the sailing moon ,
‘ Twere not enough to melt upon this woe !
Wretched , O wretched me ! To be the curse
Of what is best on earth !
Peace , unjust lips !
Thou art a rose that , rooted in Elysium ,
Leans sorrowing to the world that it may see
What beauty is and know then how to dream .
O , close those other worlds , your eyes , that I
May live in this !
Stay , I must speak !

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: No , no !

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: And you must hear me .

lg.l: Silence , sir , is best .
In her deep bosom let our woes be buried ,
As Night doth shepherd all the cares of day
Till Heaven think the world asleep , though ‘ neath
The dark are hot and staring eyes .
Nay , nay ,
Put courage in thy heart to gender wings
That we may dart as swallows to the sun
And tread the rosy air where love may breathe !

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: My lord ——

lg.l: Come ! come ! Greece is our home of light .
There you , my wife , shall rule a lesser heaven
And tutor souls for God 's .
One moment hear me !
You love me , Aratea .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Fare you well .

lg.l: First say thou lovest me !
Dost thou not hear
A voice at night when calm Eirene leads
Sleep to all eyes but thine ?

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Have mercy , sir !

lg.l: What leap of soul or dream of sense hast thou
That is not sweeter for you hold me dear ?
When Theia 's daughter , priestess gray , unhoods
Her morning face , and all her clouds of rose
With flying petals light the waking world ,
Does not your ecstasy swim on the flood
Of my remembered eyes , and their delight
Re-jewel beauty 's diadem ?

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: I beg ——

lg.l: When throbbing wonders of a dying sun
Trail off their glories like escaping souls ,
And Night with lustred heaven round her neck
Lures up immensities , whose spirit longs
Through all your longings till it leads your own
To crowned and still content ?

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Will you not go ?

lg.l: And when thy gaze is on the sibyl sea ,
Striving to read her ancient wave-writ script ,
And break the seal a differing language sets
Upon her mighty tongue , whence cometh peace
Like full and silent answer to your heart ?
If this be love , then let it be mine still .
For it may be without a touch of hands .
Ay , though in Athens you must live and move
Still are you mine in mysteries and joys .
I thank you , sir , for having taught me love
That is forever holy , wronging none .
Nay , Aratea , man can not be God
And pipe all Heaven through a mortal reed !
Come to my arms , O life and soul of me !
As chaste verbenas on an altar kiss ,
As streamlets join in soft approving shade ,
As clouds immingle in the glancing sun ,
So shall our loves unchided of the skies .
Not leafy choirs that anthem Flora in ,
Or those sweet songs that in day 's virgin hour
Their hymeneal pour from feathery pipes
That stale Apollo 's lute , shall win more smiles
From the consenting gods !
O , music , breath
Of sin !
Not so ! To love thee not were sin !
The adoration of so fair a soul
Would save me were I damned ! And thou art mine .
By stars that knit their motions with our fates ,
The season-childing sun , great Heaven itself ——

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: O , not by Heaven !

lg.l: And Heaven 's all-greater Lord ,
Who gives us souls that we may love all beauty ,
And gives us beauty that our souls may love it ,
I swear thee mine !

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: Your oath — your oath to Dion !

lg.l: Thou ‘ rt mine above all vows ! Thou canst not let
A mock-enthron � d custom speak to God ?
An atom fettered with nice consequence
Bar up the gates of love that are as wide
As His earth-belting arms ?

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: No pity , none .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: My heart , say thou wilt come .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: ‘ Tis death .

lg.l: ‘ Tis life !
Come now , O now , else are we cast apart
Far as the dismal Night heaves her vast sigh ,
Far as the laboring Chaos breathing blows ,—
Perchance to hurl eternally about
The farthest stars that from oppos � d heavens
Dart fiery scouts that die ere they have met ,
So long their journey is . Or , gloomier fate ,
Condemn � d sit like stones that once could weep
Forever in the cave of ended things
That deep in some immortal Lemnos lies
Nor ever opens its dank gates to day !
O , come ere we are lost ! Be thy fair arms
The rainbow girdle to this longing storm
And its rude breast will pillow thee as soft
As Leda when , cool-rocked on lily couch ,
The great down-bosomed god swam to her love !
Come , Aratea , heart of life ! O now
This pulse speaks back to mine — this bosom throbs
Like heaven 's Artemis unto her own !
O kiss that holds the mornings of all time ,
And dewy seasons of the ungathered rose ,
Plant once again thy summer on my lips !
How dear is death that kisses with such breath !
Thine eyes are seas where sighing ardors blow
Love 's argosies from island bowers of dream
Into my heart . Save me , Aristocles !
O me , I 'm netted in these golden curls
With web as sure as that the crafty god
Once wove round Aphrodite 's blushing bed
And trapped great Ares , sport for gazing heaven !
O , I am lost !
Away ! away ! Nor may
My lips move more on earth but in a prayer
To cleanse this moment 's madness from our souls !

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Wouldst leave me now to death ?

lg.l: Ay , unto death ,
Lest Truth and Honor die ! Thy way 's not mine .
My aspen soul would shake its house of fear ,
Imagine thunder in the bee 's soft hum ,
And mountain-rocking winds in harmless air
That would not move the purple down of clouds .
To so great compass now my horror grows
That I myself seem Chaos . ‘ Tis as I stood
‘ Mong heaps of ruined destinies with life
Still mourning in them . I am still for fear
Another world will crumble as I stir .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Move , Aratea ! Speak !

lg.l: Dost hear that sound ?
It is the rustle of tear-dropping gods
Who gather all the golden virtues up
Vouchsafed to earth and trampled low by man .
See how they rise with their immortal store ,
A moving radiance like the march of light ,
And leave us dark for want of what they bear ?
Far , far till stars must upward look to see —
A sapphire trail through the ethereal rose !
Now — earth and darkness — and you call it love !

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Lifting herFair soul , be mortal yet !

lg.l: Who leaps for stars
Must fall a million leagues too short , or else
Take vantage not of earth .
Farewell — till death .
‘ Twill not be long to wait . Thou canst not live
In Dion 's arms .
Nor thine . As well to hope
The air-winged seed will root in vacancy ,
And high mid-nothing hang with lob � d bloom ,
As that the rose of love will flower from
The wreck of men and gods .

div.stage: He kneels and kisses her robe . She goes out

lg.l: Before I die
I 've touched divinity .

div.stage: As he rises a slave rushes in , rear , and kneels

sp.speaker: Slave
sp.p: My lord !

lg.l: You serve
Lord Heraclides , do you not ?
I do ,
And know his heart — his traitor heart .

sp.speaker: Aris
sp.p: Speak , man .

sp.speaker: Slave
sp.p: You love the noble Dion ?

lg.l: Dion ? Ay ,
I love him well .

sp.speaker: Slave
sp.p: Sir , Heraclides comes To slay him . Dion , the good ! But you will save him ! � gisthus and Callorus aid my master . They 're bringing Dion here .

lg.l: Here ? Haste ! Bring you
Ocrastes and Calippus ! Freedom ! Go !

div.stage: Slave runs out . Aristocles steps back unseen as Dion , Heraclides , � gisthus and Callorus enter . The slave running out meets them

sp.speaker: Her
sp.p: What do you , sirrah ?The slave runs by without answerGo ! You 'll not outrun The hangman !� gisthus and Callorus keep in rear of Heraclides , who walks with Dion� g .To CallorusWe 're betrayed .

lg.l: Do not delay
The blow .

sp.speaker: Her
sp.p: To DionYou like our plan , my lord ? � g .To HeraclidesStrike now .

lg.l: ‘ Tis balm to Syracuse . Your hand upon it ,
And pardon me my left .

sp.speaker: Her
sp.p: With all my heart !

div.stage: Stabs at Dion , whose sword arm is still in bandage . Aristocles , watching , springs out and knocks the weapon aside . Heraclides engages with him . Callorus rushes at Dion , who has loosened his right arm , and his foe , meeting unexpected defence , is slain . As Callorus falls , � gisthus strikes at Dion and disarms him , sending his weapon against the curtains , left . Dion , unarmed and suffering , falls back . Aristocles presses before Dion , fighting desperately with Heraclides and � gisthus , Aratea appears at curtains

sp.p: Taking up Dion 's weaponO heart of Mars , beat here !

div.stage: She advances suddenly and draws upon � gisthus , who falls back in momentary astonishment , and Aristocles , relieved , slays Heraclides . Ocrastes and Calippus rush in rear , followed by guards and slaves . Theano and women , enter left . � gisthus kneels and surrenders his sword to Aratea

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Dion ! Safe ?

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: RisingMy wife — and friend — can tell you . Ask of them .

sp.speaker: Oc
sp.p: Picking up bandageMy lord , your scarf .

sp.speaker: Dion
sp.p: Let ‘ t be , my son . Let ‘ t be . I shall not need it any more .

lg.l: O joy ,
My lord !

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.p: And joy for Heraclides ’ death !

lg.l: Poor man ! His flattery so soon found friends
That he himself was caught by it , and thought
To gain a crown by Dion 's death . E'en while
They talked — O ne'er was friendly speech so punctured —
His sword was out and aimed at Dion 's bosom .
Your blade is purple , but it should be black ,
So vile his blood !

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.p: My lord !

lg.l: Your wound ! He bleeds !
O see ! This stream is gushing as ‘ twould fill
An ocean . Help ! A surgeon !
Nay , too late .
Olympus ’ power alone is potent here .
There 's not enough of life in me to wish
For life .

sp.speaker: Ara
sp.p: O , Dion !

lg.l: Kneel here , my wife .
And you ,
Aristocles , come close to me .
lg.stage: Aristocles kneels on the other side of Dion
lg.l: Two faces
Where more of heaven is writ than I have seen
In all the world beside . Ay , ye will pair
Like twin divinities , and haply by
The sweet conjunction of your beauteous stars
Make a new influence in the skies may draw
The world to heaven .
... Ocrastes , son , on you
Now falls the heavy weight of government .
... Farewell , all hearts . My way is new and long ,
And strange may be the fortunes of my shade ,
But somewhere I shall lay me down in peace ,
For death 's unmeasured sea must own a strand ,
And e'en eternity beat to a shore .
